In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Al-Hasan bin Khidr informed us from his father who said: Sufyan said: Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Husayn bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah's blessings be upon them, entered upon me and said: O Sufyan, did you know that I contemplated upon doing good deeds (Al-Ma'ruf) and I saw that it is not complete except with three things?
I said: What are they, may my father and mother be your ransom?
He said: Hurrying it, hiding it, and belittling it. For if you hurry it, you make it enjoyable; if you hide it, you complete it; and if you belittle it, you magnify it. But if you delay it, procrastinate it, and make it turbid, you diminish it and spoil it.
Then he recited a poem representing this:
(Munsarih Meter)
He nurtures his good deed and preserves it ... And indeed, beneficence is in nurturing.
I said: This, by Allah, is cold spoil (easy gain) without the burden of travel or the hardship of journeying.

Al-Akhfash recited to us regarding the meaning of Sufyan's saying:
(Munsarih Meter)
The humble resident who has not tied a saddle nor a saddle-cloth to a reddish-white camel.
Others say: Al-Shawkal: The right wing and left wing of the army. Al-Shakil: The whiteness between the ear and the temple. In the Hadith: "Inspect in purification (Wudu/Ghusl) the Shakil, the Maghfalah, and the Manshalah, for many people neglect them." [Al-Manshalah] is what is under the ring on the finger.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad told us from Al-Mazini from Al-Asma'i who said: When Khalid bin Abdullah Al-Qasri forbade singing, Hunayn bin Balu' entered upon him one day carrying his oud under his clothes. When the assembly dispersed and no one remained whom he would be shy of, he said to him: May Allah reform the Emir, I am an old man and I have a craft by which I used to provide for my family, and I have been forbidden from it.
He said: And what is your craft?
He uncovered his oud, played it, and recited:
(Khafif Meter)
O gloating one who reproaches for gray hair ... Reduce boasting about youth.
We have worn youth fresh and new ... So I found youth to be gray hair borrowed.
Khalid wept until his sobbing became loud, then he said to him: I have permitted you as long as you do not come behaving badly or foolishly.
So Hunayn, after that, whenever he was invited, would stand at the door of the house and say: Is there a fool among you? Is there a quarrelsome drunkard among you? If they said: No, he would enter.

Abu Abdullah Al-Yazidi recited to us:
(Sari' Meter)
Do not be engrossed in every error ... And do not be stubborn and contentious.
Follow the people of virtue in their virtue ... And do not spare effort nor leave it.
For some of a youth's morals are his malice ... And some are like poured gold.
So do unto people the like of which ... You love for people to do unto you.
He who is content with a sufficiency of sustenance ... Day by day, lives the life of a king.
He took the meaning of the last verse from the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever wakes up secure in his flock (Sirb), healthy in his body, possessing his daily sustenance, it is as if the world has been gathered for him in its entirety."
Al-Sarb (with Fat-ha): The road/path. Al-Sarb is also: Camels. Al-Sirb (with Kasra): A group of women, gazelles, and cows. So if it is said: So-and-so is safe in his 'Sarb' (with Fat-ha), it means he is safe in his wealth and his path. And if it is said: He is safe in his 'Sirb' (with Kasra), it means he is safe regarding himself, his women, and his harem.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abd al-Rahman told us from Al-Asma'i who said: I heard a Bedouin say: Envy is an eraser of good deeds. Arrogance brings the wrath of Allah and the wrath of the righteous. Vanity prevents increase in knowledge and calls to stumbling in ignorance. Miserliness is the worst of diseases and brings the worst reputation. Mockery is the humor and craft of the ignorant. Disobedience (to parents) calls to scarcity and bequeaths humiliation.

Al-Yazidi informed us from his uncle Abu al-Sheikh, raising it to Abu Muhammad Yahya bin al-Mubarak al-Yazidi who said: A man used to come to me asking about problematic verses from the Book of Allah, and I used to perceive obstinacy in his questioning. Whenever I answered him, I would see his color turn ashen and black. One day he said to me: Is it permissible in the speech of the Arabs to say: "I made the people enter the house, then I brought them out as a man (Rajulan - singular)"?
I said: That is not permissible unless you say: I brought them out man by man, saying it to detail the genus.
He said: Then how did Allah Almighty say: (Then He brings you out as a child (Tiflan))?
I said: This is not like that, because 'Tifl' is originally a verbal noun (Masdar), so it applies to the singular, dual, and plural with one word. So you say: "This is a child (Tifl), these two are children (Tifl), and these are children (Tifl)." Just as the Almighty said: (And the children (Al-Tifl) who have not yet attained knowledge of women's private parts). So 'Tifl' in the verse is in the place of 'Atfal' (children), as if He said: Then He brings you out as children.
He said: Then inform me about His saying: (That Day, those who disbelieved and disobeyed the Messenger will wish that the earth were leveled with them). From where will they get this earth there?
I said to him: You are mistaken. Have you not heard the Almighty's saying: (The Day the earth will be replaced by another earth)? So they wished that *that* earth would be leveled.
So he fell silent.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi who said: A path is called, if it is clear: Mahya', Wadih, Bayyin, Hannan, Jaddah, and Nahham, if it is clear, wide, or narrow. Al-Wajab is the foolish man. Al-Wajab is the plural of Wajbah, which is the single meal in a day and night. Al-Wajab: The stake in shooting (archery). It is said: Wajabtu Fulanan: If I took a stake in shooting. Al-Wajib: The fallen one. Al-Wajib: The palpitation of the heart from fear. Al-Huns (with Damma on Ha and Sukoon on Sad) is the verbal noun of Al-Hasan (chastity) in women. He recited for a Bedouin girl who went out and a man accosted her:
(Sari' Meter)
O mother, a rider saw me ... Traveling on a clear, wide path.
I kept throwing dust in his face ... Throwing (Hathyan), and protecting the domain of the absent one.
Her mother answered her:
(Sari' Meter)
Chastity, when they said you waited for him (Ta'ayyaytihi) ... From your throwing the dust at the rider.
It is said: Hatha Fulan at-turaba yahthu hathwan, and hatha yahthi hathyan (with Madd): You intended and aimed. Ta'ayyayti (with Qasr and Shadda): If you stopped and held back. It is recited:
(Majzu' al-Kamil Meter)
Stand at the dwellings the standing of a visitor ... And wait (Ta'ayya), indeed you are not humiliated.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Abu Shabbah. He said: Yahya bin Sulayman bin Mu'adh wrote a letter to Abdullah bin Tahir, the beginning of which was: May Allah make me your ransom and grant enjoyment through you. So Abdullah bin Tahir wrote back to him:
(Munsarih Meter)
Did you attain a kingdom so you became arrogant in your letters ... Or have you deviated from what I knew of your manners?
Or do you see in treating brothers equally ... A deficiency upon you in your lineage?
Indeed, the beginning of a letter of a trustworthy person ... Is in its start "And grant enjoyment through you."
You tired your hands in writing to me ... Suffice it for you what increases your fatigue.
Yahya answered him:
(Munsarih Meter)
You commit sins in your letters ... Against a brother who shudders from your anger.
How could you imagine this of me when ... I did not commit a sin? And that is from your wonder.
And is it permissible to supplicate in letters ... Between friends other than "Grant enjoyment through you"?

Al-Akhfash recited to us by Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Tahir:
(Tawil Meter)
You see every ignorant person, if he slips a slip ... Rush (Yatatyau) into its likes and aspire to it.
So be, if a person of knowledge has a lapse ... Guarding against it, striving, and asking for its forgiveness.
His saying "Yatatyau" means he rushes into it and falls without caution. From it is the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "You rush (Tata-ya'una) into lying just as moths rush into the fire."
He also recited to us by him:
(Tawil Meter)
For every father of a daughter whose righteousness is hoped ... There are three in-laws, if the in-law is praised.
A husband who fulfills her needs, a curtain that protects her ... And a grave that covers her, and the best of them is the grave.

Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Rustam al-Tabari informed us. He said: Al-Mazini told us: Muhammad bin Sulayman al-Hashimi, who was the Emir of Basra, read on the pulpit "Anna Allaha wa mala'ikatuhu yusalluna 'ala an-nabi" (Indeed Allah and His angels send blessings upon the Prophet) with Raf' (Nominative case for angels). He knew he had made a grammatical error, so he sent for the grammarians and said to them: Find a justification for it. They said: We coordinate it with the place of 'Inna' because it enters upon the subject and predicate. So he rewarded them and gave them good gifts, and he did not retract it so it wouldn't be said he made an error.

Al-Zajjaj informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us from Al-Mazini, he said: Al-Akhfash told me, he said: The Emir of Basra read on the pulpit "Anna Allaha wa mala'ikatuhu yusalluna 'ala an-nabi" with Raf'. So I went to him advising and alerting him, but he threatened me and menaced me, saying: You attribute errors to your Emirs. Then he was dismissed and Muhammad bin Sulayman al-Hashimi took over, so it was as if he learned it from the dismissed one. I said: This is a Hashimite and advising him is obligatory, but I was cowardly and feared he would meet me with the like of what the first one met me with. Then I forced myself and went to him, and he was in a room with his brother and the servants were at his head. I said to him: May Allah reform the Emir, I came for advice. He said: Speak. I said: This one, and I pointed to his brother. So his brother stood up and the servants dispersed. I said: May Allah reform the Emir, you are the people of the house of Prophethood and the mine of the Message and eloquence, yet you read "Anna Allaha wa mala'ikatuhu" with Raf', and it is a grammatical error that has no justification. He said: May Allah reward you with good, for you have alerted and advised, so leave with thanks. When I reached half the stairs, a speaker said to me: Stop where you are. So I stopped and my soul worried me, and I feared his brother had incited him against me. Suddenly, there was a swift mule, a servant, a chest of clothes, and a purse of money, and a speaker saying: This is for you, and the Emir has ordered it. So I left rejoicing.

Explanation of the Issue

Know that if you say: "Inna Zaydan qa'imun wa 'Amrun" (Indeed Zayd is standing and Amr), you have two options for the coordinated noun (Amr). Nasb (Accusative), coordinating with the noun of 'Inna', as you say: "Inna Zaydan qa'imun wa 'Amran". It can be Raf' (Nominative) from three aspects: First, coordinating with the hidden pronoun in the predicate. Second, you coordinate it with the place of 'Inna' (which is originally subject/predicate), and coordination based on meaning is permissible after the completion of the sentence. Third, you raise it by Inchoation (Mubtada) and imply for it a predicate like the preceding one. This is agreed upon with no disagreement. Based on this, it was recited: "Anna Allaha bari'un min al-mushrikina wa rasuluhu" with Raf' and Nasb (for Rasuluhu). An example of Nasb is the poet's saying:
(Rajaz Meter)
Indeed the Rabie' (season) is generosity, and the Kharif (autumn) ... Are the hands of Abu al-Abbas, and the Suyuf (summers).
He coordinated 'Al-Suyuf' with 'Al-Rabie' after the predicate. But if you coordinate with the noun of 'Inna' before the predicate, it can only be Nasb, as you say: "Inna Zaydan wa 'Amran qa'imani". If you coordinated with the place of 'Inna' and said: "Inna Zaydan wa 'Amrun qa'imani", it would not be permissible because carrying on meaning is only after the sentence is complete. This is similar to his saying "Inna Allaha wa mala'ikatuhu" with Raf'. Some Kufans allowed it, and the reason is the predicate which was mentioned previously. However, it is permissible to delay the predicate and install the coordinated noun upon it, and raise it by intending delay, so you say: "Inna Zaydan wa 'Amrun qa'im", and the estimation is: "Inna Zaydan qa'imun wa 'Amrun", then you advanced it based on this interpretation. If you wish, you say: "Inna Zaydan qa'imun", and the estimation is: "Inna Zaydan qa'imun", then you advanced it. Based on that, it is recited:
(Tawil Meter)
So whoever spent the evening in Medina intending departure ... Then I, and Qayyar, are strangers to it.
With raising 'Qayyar' and installing it, and Qayyar is the name of his camel/horse.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim informed us from Abu Ubayda who said: There was an Arab woman possessing wealth, beauty, and eloquence. She swore to herself that she would not marry anyone unless he defeated her in argument, so she cut off foolishness and people avoided her until a man volunteered for her. He came and stood at her door. She said to him: From whom are you?
He said: A human born small, and grew up big.
She said: So where is your land?
He said: On a vast carpet in a wide land, near yet far, and far yet near.
She said: What is your name?
He said: Whoever wants takes a name, and that is not a stoning (guessing) upon him.
She said: It seems you have no need?
He said: If I had no need, I would not stand at your door, connect with your means, and expose myself to your address.
She said: Is your need secret or public?
He said: Secret and public.
She said: It seems you are a suitor?
He said: That is it.
She said: Your dowry?
He said: Say it?
She said: I wondered.
He said: I wondered at the salt marsh; its soil does not dry nor does its pasture grow.
She said: I wondered?
He said: I wondered at the stones; their large ones do not age nor do their small ones grow.
She said: I wondered.
He said: I wondered at the seeker of knowledge; he does not reach its end nor fulfill his desire.
He said: I wondered at a pit between your legs; digging it does not bore one, nor is its bottom reached.
She said: You have fulfilled your need.
He said: I thanked.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Muhammad bin al-Hasan al-Hunayni informed us, he said: Ahmad bin al-Mufaddal told us from Asbat from Al-Suddi regarding the Almighty's saying "A-tad'una Ba'lan" (Do you call upon Ba'l), he said: A Lord. And thus it came in this report.
The Sheikh said: What is known among linguists is that 'Al-Ba'l' is the idol, so it was permissible because they used to worship it as they worship the Lord Almighty. 'Al-Ba'l': The husband. 'Al-Bi'al': Marriage. 'Al-Ba'l' is also: Palm trees that drink with their roots and dispense with watering. The poet meant this by saying:
(Tawil Meter)
Of those coming to water in the low ground, drinking ... With their tails (roots) before the drinking of the throats.
'Al-Ba'l' is also: The man who is a burden on his family. As for 'Al-Ba'al' with Fatha on Ba and Ayn, it is bewilderment. It is said: Ba'ila bi-amrihi yab'alu ba'alan: If he became bewildered.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Al-Hunayni told me, he said: Ahmad bin al-Mufaddal told me from Asbat from Al-Suddi regarding the Almighty's saying (Wa inna la-nahnu as-saffun), he said: Meaning prayer. Al-Sunni mentioned from Abdullah who said: There is not in the heaven a place of a hand-span except there is upon it the forehead of an angel or his feet, prostrating or bowing or standing. Abdullah recited "Wa inna la-nahnu as-saffun" (And indeed, we are the ones standing in rows) (Wa inna la-nahnu al-musabbihun) (And indeed, we are the ones glorifying).

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim informed us from Abu Ubayda who said: Muawiyah wrote to Ubadah bin al-Samit: The Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, have gathered upon me, so write to me with your allegiance and marry Yazid to your daughter. Ubadah wrote to him: If the nation of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, gathered upon an Abyssinian slave, I would hear and obey. I have written to you with my allegiance. As for marrying Yazid to my daughter, I have written to you two verses, so hear them, and they are:
(Tawil Meter)
If my soul obeyed me, I would have become ... Having grandchildren from what is considered many.
But my soul is noble to me ... Disdaining of the in-laws of the mean, capable.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Uthman al-Ushnandani told us, he said: Umara bin Aqil bin Bilal bin Jarir informed us, he said: Asma bint Mutarrif bin Aban from Banu Abi Bakr bin Kilab was eloquent and sharp-tongued. She stayed as a guest with a man from Banu Nasr bin Muawiyah, then from Banu Kulfa, but he did not host her well. So she said about him:
(Tawil Meter)
A free woman traveled with me, twisting her arms ... Towards the light of a fire between Fardah and Al-Jazr.
She traveled what she traveled of her night, then she camped ... At a Kulfi man's who does not warm nor host.
So be a stone that does not taste a drop (of water) forever ... If you are a guest descending among Banu Nasr.
She also said about him:
(Tawil Meter)
We traveled while remnants of sand were before us ... To his fire, glistening at midnight.
So Ibn Shamakh spent the night breaking open dates ... And did not give us to drink except watered-down milk (Samar Mudayyah).
He said: Al-Samar: Milk. Al-Mudayyah: Much mixed [with water]. From it is the saying of the other:
(Rajaz Meter)
Until when the mixed darkness fell ... They came with 'Dih' (mixed milk), have you ever seen a wolf?
He says: They came with milk that was mixed with much water until its color became dusty like the color of a wolf.
Her saying: "So be a stone that does not taste (Tat'am) a drop forever", for it is said 'Ta'imtu' regarding food, drink, and sleep. Allah Almighty said: "And whoever does not taste it (Yat'amhu), then he is of me." And He said: (They will not taste therein coolness nor drink). The scholars said: Coolness (Bard): Much sleep. From the speech of the Arabs: The cold prevented me from coolness (sleep), i.e., the cold prevented me from sleeping.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi who said: The Arabs say "Nazartu bi-'ayni" (I looked with my eye), and "Nazartu" meaning I waited. "Nazartu": I had mercy. "Nazartu": I thought. "Anzartu ar-rajula": I delayed him. "Anzartu ar-rajula": I made him wait for me. He said: And "At-Turab" (dust) is plural, its singular is "Turabah", and the relative adjective to it is "Turabi". It is recited:
(Tawil Meter)
And they said "Turabi", so I said: You spoke the truth ... My father is from dust (Turab), Allah created him, Adam.
He meant "Khalaqahu" (created him) but silenced the Lam. In installing "Adama" (Adam - accusative), there are two aspects: One is that it is a substitute (Badal) for the Ha in "Khalaqahu" for clarification and explanation. The other is that he installed it by implying "I mean" (A'ni).

Al-Akhfash recited to us, he said: Tha'lab recited to us, he said: I read in the handwriting of Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Mawsili by Ujayr al-Saluli:
(Tawil Meter)
O neighbor, I do not increase except in longing ... For you, and you do not increase except in distance.
O neighbor, if a soul ransomed the soul of a dead person ... I would have ransomed you, happy with my family and my wealth.
And I used to hope to possess you for an era ... But the decree of Allah came between [me and] my hope.
Lo, let whoever wishes die after you, for indeed ... My mourning was only for you from among the days.
Abu Nuwas took the meaning of the last verse and said mourning Al-Amin:
(Tawil Meter)
Death folded what was between me and Muhammad ... And there is no spreader for what death folds.
If houses are inhabited by those I do not love ... Then the graves have been inhabited by those I love.
I used to fear death for him alone ... So there remained nothing for me to fear for.
He also said:
(Majzu' al-Kamil Meter)
You were the pupil for an eye ... So upon you the onlooker weeps.
Whoever wishes after you, let him die ... For upon you I used to fear.

Al-Akhfash recited to us by Al-Nabigha:
(Wafir Meter)
For I do not blame you for [not] arriving ... But what is behind you, O Isam?
Did I not swear upon you to inform me ... Is the king (Himam) carried on the bier?
For if Abu Qabus perishes, there perishes ... The spring of the people and the Sacred Month.
And we take after him the tail of a life ... Cut off at the back (Ajabb), having no hump.
As for Isam, he is the chamberlain of Al-Nu'man. He says: I do not blame you if you prevented me from reaching him, but inform me of his news. When a king fell ill, he was placed on a bed and carried on the necks of men, justifying it by saying it is more comfortable for him. As for his saying: "Wa na'khudhu ba'dahu bi-dhanabi 'ayshin" (And we take after him the tail of a life),

It is permissible to have Raf' (Nominative), Nasb (Accusative), and Jazm (Jussive). As for Jazm, it is by coordination with his saying: "Yahlik rabi'u an-nas" (The spring of people perishes [conditional result]). Raf' is by severance and inchoation. Nasb is by diversion (Sarf) with implied 'An'. Similarly, every coordinated verb after the answer to a conditional clause in the future tense allows these three aspects. Like His saying: (Whether you reveal what is within yourselves or conceal it, Allah will bring you to account for it. Then He forgives whom He wills and punishes whom He wills). In "Yu'adhdhibu" (punishes), the three aspects mentioned are permissible. In his saying "Ajabba azh-zhahri", he means cut off at the back. This is representation and simile. It is narrated "Ajabbi azh-zhahri" with genitive (Kasra) for both, as adding 'Ajabb' to 'Azh-Zhahr'. It is narrated "Ajabba azh-zhahra" with Fatha on 'Ajabb' and Nasb on 'Azh-Zhahr', assuming 'Ajabb' is in genitive position but diptote, and 'Azh-Zhahr' is installed by resemblance to the object, with the subject implied in 'Ajabb'. As if he said "Ajabban" with nunation then prevented it from nunation because it is diptote. It is in the estimation of your saying "Marartu bi-rajulin hasani al-wajha, wa kathiri al-mala, wa tayyibi al-'aysha." It is narrated "Ajabba azh-zhahru" with Fatha on 'Ajabb' assuming it is in genitive position, raising 'Azh-Zhahr' by it, as if he said "Ajabba zhahruhu". The Kufans place Alif-Lam after the addition (Idafa), and the Basrans imply what connects the mention to the first, their estimation being: "Ajabba azh-zhahri minhu" (Cut off at the back from it).

Ibn al-Anbari informed us, he said: Idris bin Abd al-Karim Abu al-Hasan al-Ma'ri told us, he said: Abu al-Ahwas Muhammad bin Hayyan al-Baghawi told us, he said: Al-Zamakhi bin Khalid told us from Ibn Jurayj regarding the saying of Allah Almighty (Do you build at every high place (Ri'in) a sign desiring amusement?). He said: Towers (Burujan).
Al-Zajjaj and Ibn al-Khayyat informed us from Al-Hasan bin al-Tayyan from Ibn al-Sikkit. Muhammad bin Aqil and Bilal bin Jarir said: 'Ar-Ri'': The mountain. Other linguists said: 'Ar-Ri'': What rose from the ground.
Ibn al-Anbari said: My father informed me from Nasr bin Dawud from Abu Ubayd al-Qasim bin Sallam, he said: It is said: "Akhdajat an-naqah" (The she-camel miscarried): If she dropped her fetus incomplete in creation, even if at the full time of pregnancy, she is 'Mukhdij' and the fetus is 'Mukhday'. "Khadajat an-naqah": If she dropped her fetus before the full time of creation, even if complete in creation, she is 'Khadij' and the fetus is 'Khadij' and 'Makhduj'.
Abu al-Anbari said: Tha'lab informed us from Salamah from Al-Farra', he said: It is said: "Akhdajat" and "Khadajat" with one meaning. Al-Kisa'i alone narrated "Khadijat" with Kasra on Dal. Abu al-Qasim said: The origin of "Khadaj" is deficiency, whether in creation or in time, but they differentiated between them due to the difference in context. From it is the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "Every prayer in which there is no recitation is Khadaj." i.e., having deficiency. Al-Khadaj: Deficiency. From it is the saying of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, regarding Dhu al-Thudayyah "That he is Mukhdaj al-yad" (Deficient in the hand). Scholars say: "Ath-Thady" is masculine. It was only said "Dhu al-Thudayyah" with Ha because he went to the meaning of the piece of flesh and addition. Some say: "Dhu al-Yadayyah" with Ya, making it diminutive of "Al-Yad".

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Umar bin Shabbah from Mukhariq Abu al-Muhanna, he said: I entered upon Abu al-Atahiya in his illness in which he died. When he saw me, he smiled at me and said: Come close to me, may my father and mother be your ransom. So I came close to him and said to him: What do you desire? He said: I desire to hear from you:
(Khafif Meter)
Ahmad said to me, and did not know what was wrong with me ... Do you love Utbah truly this morning?
So I sighed then said yes, a love ... That ran in the veins, vein by vein.
If you discerned what my heart conceals ... You would see the heart ulcerated, bursting.
Would that I died and rested from love ... For as long as I live, I am cast from it.
He said: So I sang it. He said: I see myself as if I have revived. He asked for it to be repeated several times, so I repeated it to him. He said: Leave rightly guided and come to me tomorrow, for if you don't see me, I have died. That remained his habit until the fourth day, I was busy from him, and he died on that day.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us, he said: It was narrated from more than one source that Abu Nuwas, Abu al-Atahiya, Abu al-Shis, and Al-Husayn al-Khali' gathered in a session. Abu Nuwas said to them: O my brothers, this session has consequences and our meeting will be mentioned, so let each of us recite the best of what he has said. They said: Do so, and do not hold back from advancing Abu al-Atahiya due to his age. So he recited:
(Sari' Meter)
O my brothers, indeed passion is my killer ... So prepare the shrouds quickly.
And do not blame for following passion ... For I am in a distracting occupation.
My heart spent the evening with a lean-waisted one ... With an anxious, roaming sash.
As if she, due to her beauty, is a pearl ... Which the sea brought out to the shore.
Her love left nothing of me except ... A breath of life in a wasted body.
People think I am healthy and do not ... Know of the hidden internal [ailment].

I imagine in her mouth and her glance ... Sorceresses who came from Babylon.
My eye upon the threshold is pouring ... With its flowing, shedding tears.
O you who saw a slain one before me, wept ... Out of intense passion for the killer.
I extended my palm towards you asking ... What do you reply to the asker?
If you are in difficulty this year ... Woe is me, then promise me until the next.
Abu al-Shis recited to them:
(Kamil Meter)
Passion stopped with me where you are, so I have ... No retreating from it nor advancing.
I find blame in your love delicious ... Out of love for your mention, so let the blamer blame me.
I resembled my enemies so I started loving them ... Since my luck from you was [like] my luck from them.
And you humiliated me, so I humiliated myself striving ... What is one who is easy upon you compared to one who is honored?
Al-Husayn al-Khali' recited:
(Tawil Meter)
As if I am alone, not gladdened by a companion ... Of people until the Sacred Months pass.
I am blamed for being occupied with one whom I am his occupation ... When he circumambulates or inclines to the Corner and touches it.
We will observe in the unseen what was between us ... And we will observe for our two covenants despite whoever dislikes.
Then they said to Abu Nuwas: Come, recite to us. He said:
(Basit Meter)
Do not weep for Layla, nor yearn for Hind ... And drink upon the rose from a red [wine] like the rose.
A cup, if it descends into the throat of its drinker ... You find its redness in the eye and the cheek.
The cup is a pearl and the wine a ruby ... From the hand of a maid, slender of figure.
We give you drink from her eye a wine, and from her hand ... A wine, so you have no escape from two intoxications.
I have two intoxications, and the boon companion has one ... Something I was singled out with among them alone.
When he finished it, they stood and prostrated to him. He said: Have you done it like the Khosroes? By Allah, I will not speak to you for three, nor three, nor three. When it was the next day, he wrote to them: My brothers, the days of life are too short to bear [separation], so make your rest today at my place.

Ibn Shaqiq al-Nahwi informed us, he said: Ahmad bin Ubayd informed us, he said: It is narrated that Abu al-Darda' was asked: Why do you not say poetry when others have said it? He said: I too have said. They said: What did you say? He said: I said:
(Wafir Meter)
Man wants to be given his desire ... And Allah refuses except what He willed.
Man says: My benefit and my wealth ... And the fear of Allah is the best of what he gained.

Al-Akhfash recited to us by Al-Atawi:
(Basit Meter)
Do not weep over a friend turning away from you ... Under the sky and above the earth are substitutes.
People are more numerous than that you see no successor ... For one whom wealth turned his face away from your face.
How ugly is affection that brings closer and distances ... Between two friends, abundance and scarcity.
He recited to us by Ishaq bin Ibrahim al-Mawsili:
(Tawil Meter)
Enough sadness that no friend nor brother ... Attains richness except arrogance enters him.
Or he twists away, or thinks you are below him ... And that is one that is grave, so there is no patience for it.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim told us from Al-Asma'i, he said: 'Al-Muhjah': The pure soul/blood. From it, pure milk is called 'Uhmijan' and 'Mahij'. 'Ar-Radah': The woman heavy in her walk. 'As-Sirbah': The locust. 'At-Timsah': The lying man. 'As-Sahif': The broad arrowhead. 'Al-'Adiyy': The first to charge in war on foot. It is recited:
(Tawil Meter)
Here is a pouch containing thirty broad arrows (Sayhafan) ... When the first of the chargers ('Adiyy) sense it, they shudder.

Ibn al-Anbari recited to us, he said: My father recited to me:
(Basit Meter)
May Allah not distance a people, if you ask them ... They give quickly, and if you say help, they help.
If ample blessing befalls them ... They do not exult in it, and if it misses them, they are patient.
Breakers of bones that have no mender ... And menders, so people are unable to mend what they broke.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Umar bin Shabbah from one who informed him of his sheikhs, he said: Hassan bin Thabit ascended a hill one day and shouted: O men, O men! People gathered to him and said: What is your matter? He said: Listen. And he recited:
(Khafif Meter)
Worries prevented sleep in the evening ... And a phantom when the stars set.
From a beloved, a sickness from him struck your heart ... So it is internal, concealed.
O my people, does one like me kill a man ... Weak of grip, and bones are ominous?
A tender young girl, distant of desire ... Between the two sashes, in them is slimness.

If a year-old ant crawled upon her ... Her wounds would cause it to bleed.
Her affair is musk and bedding, and above her ... Are silver and strung pearls.
The sun of the day did not surpass her in anything ... Except that youth does not last.
Many a dream wasted by lack of wealth ... And ignorance covered by the folds of bliss.
They said to him: Is it for this you gathered us? He said: If this remained in my chest, it would have killed me.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Al-Hunayni told us, he said: Ahmad bin al-Mufaddal told us from Asbat from Al-Suddi regarding the saying of the Almighty: (This day I have perfected for you your religion...). He said: This was revealed on the Day of Arafah, and no lawful or prohibited thing was revealed after it. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, returned and died.
Asma bint Umays said: I had performed Hajj with the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, on that Hajj. While we were traveling, Gabriel appeared to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so he leaned on the she-camel. The she-camel could not bear the weight upon it, so I pulled a garment he had on over him. Then he mentioned carrion and what is with it, permitting it in necessity. He said: So whoever is forced by severe hunger - meaning in starvation - with no inclination to sin - meaning seeking a bite and not exceeding to a heap [eating only enough to survive].
Abu al-Qasim said: It is said a man performed Hajj 'Hijjatan' with Kasra, and nothing else is permissible. The meaning is he intended by it performing a Sunnah. As for 'Hajjah' with Fatha, it is the single time of action like 'Rak'ah' and 'Darbah', and 'Al-Hijjah' does not mean that, but rather it means all the actions in their Sunnahs. The origin of Hajj is: Intention/Seeking. You say: 'Hajajtu fulanan hajjatan', meaning I sought him. If you meant a single time, you say 'Hajajtuhu hajjatan' as you say 'Qasadtuhu qadatan wahidatan'. It is said: 'Huwa Hijju al-Bayti' and 'Hajju al-Bayti', two eloquent dialects. 'Al-Hijj' also with Kasra refers to the pilgrims themselves. Ibn Duraid recited from Abu Hatim from Al-Asma'i:
(Rajaz Meter)
As if their voices in the valley ... Are voices of pilgrims (Hijj) coming from Oman early.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Ibn Shabbah, he said: Al-Bahili told us from Ibn al-Kalbi, he said: Al-Hasan bin Uqbah al-Muradi told me, he said: Banu Asad bet Murad regarding a poet of theirs called Mahkan and a poet of Murad called Al-Nawwah, fifty camels against fifty camels, which of them is more poetic. Murad came to Al-Nawwah's resting place but did not find him, and found a small daughter of his. They asked her about him. She said: He is absent tending his flock. They said to her: We see he has grown old and his poetry weak. She said: Yes, by Allah, he has grown old, but he is surely the most poetic of those past and remaining. They said: We are your guests, so send for him. So she sent for him, and he was grazing at Al-Najaf. He came to them saying:
(Rajaz Meter)
O my camels, go in the evening to the guests ... If there is no overflowing evening drink in you.
Then rejoice with the pot and the tripods ... And a ladler with a scooping ladle.
They said to him: We have bet on you and on Mahkan of Banu Asad fifty camels. He said: By Allah, I have weakened, and this daughter of mine is more poetic than me. She said: He lied, by Allah, we do not come close to him. Then she said to him: May Allah disgrace you for a poet, your people stone enemies with you and you retreat from them. So he responded to what they sought from him and recited:
(Rajaz Meter)
O you who ask about Al-Nawwah ... The brother of Murad, not one to move away.
Here I am at the open dwelling ... Sharpening the two canines for butting.
O wonder if my milking camels go ... And I do not fight openly any fighting.
Thrusting spears against spears ... On a day of commotion and spilled blood.
Then he marched with them. When he and Mahkan al-Asadi met, Al-Nawwah recited saying:
(Rajaz Meter)
This is my Jamil kneeling at Al-Abtah ... Upon him is a load, a camel not opened.
Mahkan said: No, by Allah, I will not be the first to open it. Give him his bet.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abd al-Rahman told me from his uncle: That the saying of Abu Nuwas:
(Kamil Meter)
So Salma was, when she bid us farewell ... And the tear had risen to flow.
A fawn, the singing girls advised regarding him ... Until they tied an earring in his ear.
Is taken from the saying of Adi bin Zaid:
(Ramal Meter)
To a slender gazelle possessing beauty ... Long-necked, raised among maidens.
He clothed the neck with a precise necklace ... And pearls adorned by the stringing of virgins.
He said: The maids of the Bedouins used to take the young gazelles, dress them with earrings and beads, and adorn them. This is the meaning he intended.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Ibn al-A'rabi who said: Al-Mir'ah (Mirror), Al-Sajanjal, Al-Zulfah, Al-Zalaqah, Al-Hamamah, Al-'Arnas, and Al-Badhidh are synonymous. It is said: 'Amarra ash-shay'u wa huwa mumirrun' if it became bitter, and this is the high dialect. It is also said: 'Marra yamurru mararatan, wa huwa murrun'. From the first dialect in the imperative, it is said 'Amrir ya yawmu', and from the second dialect 'Murra ya yawmu' with Fatha on Meem. He recited:
(Tawil Meter)

If my day passes bitter in Kerman, for long ... Has decoration then the white milk been sweet between my sides.
'Al-Murr' is the verbal noun of 'Marartu marran wa mururan'. 'Al-Murr' is the plural of 'Murrah'. 'Al-Murr': The rope. He recited:
(Rajaz Meter)
Your husband, O possessor of white front teeth ... And well-spaced teeth and free forehead.
Was incapable, so we tied him as the tying of the rope (Al-Jarr) ... Then we tightened a rope (Mumarr) above him.
'Al-Jarr': The basket. 'Al-Jarr' in other than this is the foot of the mountain.

Al-Akhfash recited to us, he said: Tha'lab recited to us from what he saw in the handwriting of Al-Mawsili:
(Kamil Meter)
Time did not last in our separation ... And likewise Time separated between us.
And likewise it does in its vicissitudes ... And Time is not reached by vengeance.
I was stingy with whom I was bereft of ... So I became consoled when the matter became old.
And indeed the best of your luck in calamity is that ... Patience meets you at its occurrence.

Al-Zajjaj recited to us, he said: Al-Mubarrad recited to us by Ali bin Abi Talib, peace be upon him, mourning the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him:
(Tawil Meter)
Lo, the announcer of death came early at night, so he terrified me ... And kept me awake when he rose calling.
So I said to him when I saw who came ... Is it other than the Messenger of Allah if you are an announcer?
He confirmed what I hoped from him and I did not imagine ... And my friend was my might and my beauty.
By Allah, I will not forget you, Ahmad, as long as ... The white camels walk with me in a land and cross a valley.
And whenever I descend a valley from the earth ... I find a trace of him, new and worn.

Al-Ma'nawi informed us, he said: Masih bin Hatim informed us from Abu al-Fadl al-Riyashi, he said: Abu Salamah al-Qamawi told me, he said: Ibn Udhaynah told me: Ibn Harmah stopped by my father while Nusayb was with him. He said to him: O Abu Amir, I have composed verses and I have come to you early with them, and I would like these two Sheikhs to hear them. He said: Bring them. So he recited:
(Kamil Meter)
My companions and my mount knocked on Aliyyah ... Welcome to the phantom of Aliyyah, the frequent visitor.
Until he reached his saying:
Did you not ask when the stars were barren ... And the mount of the seeker of means was effaced?
And the shepherds became with their bowls suspended ... For foxes they roast and wolves.
Was anyone who sought my creation blamed ... Or was my courtyard and side criticized?
If a night visitor seeks fire ... My dogs barked then guided him to it.
And they howled so I hastened him, and they met him ... Striking him with the best parts of their tails.
And they almost, from recognizing what they were accustomed to ... Of that, speak clearly with welcome.
Kuthayyir said to him: O Ibn Harmah, this poetry of yours indicates other than the house you attribute yourself to, meaning that the poetry of Quraysh is weak and this is the poetry of a strong stallion. Al-Ma'nawi said: Envy of the craft led him to attack his lineage when he did not find a fault in his poetry. He said: And among what is considered good of Ibn Harmah is his saying:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
For I, and my leaving the generosity of the noble ... And my striking a stingy fire-stick with my palm.
Am like one leaving her eggs in the open ... And clothing the eggs of another with a wing.
Abu Abdullah al-Kirmani said: He means the ostrich because it is described as foolish, for it passes by the eggs of another and incubates them out of compassion for them, and leaves its eggs so they spoil and perish. Ibn Duraid said: The one described with foolishness is the hubara (bustard), and from it is the proverb:
(Rajaz Meter)
And everything may love its child ... Even the hubara and fly by it.
He said: Due to her foolishness, she teaches her chick to fly, so she deviates with it from straightness right and left, and thinks that is kindness to it, while it is oppression to it.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Al-Hunayni told us, he said: Ahmad bin al-Mufaddal told us from Asbat from Al-Suddi from Ibn Abbas regarding the saying of the Mighty and Majestic (Or He seizes them with gradual wasting (Takhawwuf)). He said: With diminution.

Ibn al-Anbari informed us, he said: Al-Khattali told us from Abu Ya'la from Al-Asma'i, he said: Sufyan told us from Tawus, he said: He who speaks and fears Allah is better than he who is silent and fears Allah.
Ibn al-Anbari informed us from Al-Khattali from Abu Ya'la from Al-Asma'i, he said: Al-Fudayl bin Iyad said: If it is said to you: Do you fear Allah? Be silent. For if you say: No, you have done a grave thing. And if you say: Yes, you have lied, for the fearful one does not do your deed.

Ibn Shaqir al-Nahwi informed us, he said: Ahmad bin Ubayd told us, he said: I was told from Hisham from Urwa from his father from Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, he said: Uthman or Muawiyah sent me to collect the charity (Zakat) of Banu Udhrah. I collected from them and departed. When I thought I had crossed their lands, a house appeared to me, so I headed towards it. In its courtyard was a young man lying on his back, nothing remaining of him but bone on skin. When he sensed me, he hummed with a weak voice and recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
I appointed the soothsayer of Yamama as judge ... And the soothsayer of Hajar, if they cure me.

They said: Yes, we cure from every disease ... And they stood with the visitors hastening.
They left no Ruqyah (incantation) they knew ... Nor solace, but they gave me to drink.
Then they said: May Allah cure you, by Allah we have ... No power over what the ribs contained of you.
Then he fainted. I looked and there were walnuts in the side of the tent. I said to her: O woman, bring out this young man to me, for I think he has died. She said: I think so too. By Allah, I have not heard a moan from him for a year except today, for he said at the beginning:
(Basit Meter)
Whoever among my mothers weeps for my sorrow ... Today, I see myself seized (dead).
They make me hear it, but I do not hear it ... When I ascend the necks of the people, displayed.
Then she went out to him and he was dead. So she washed him, shrouded him, and buried him, and I prayed over him. Then I said to the old woman: Who is this? She said: This is the martyr of love, Urwa bin Hizam.

Al-Zajjaj informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us, he said: A man from Banu Makhzum said to Al-Ahwas bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Asim bin Thabit al-Ansari: Do you know the one who says:
(Kamil Meter)
People nicknamed him Abu Hakam ... By Allah, we nickname him Abu Jahl.
His leadership bequeathed to his family ... Meanness of branches and thinness of root.
He said: This poetry is by Hassan bin Thabit al-Ansari, and the verse recited by the Makhzumi is by Al-Akhtal. That is because Muawiyah was angry with a group of the Ansar, so he ordered Ka'b bin Ju'ayl al-Taghlibi to mock them. He said: Should I mock the Ansar? Would you want me to disbelieve after Islam? But I will guide you to a Christian boy from the tribe whose tongue is like the tongue of a bull, meaning Al-Akhtal. When Al-Akhtal said this verse, Al-Nu'man bin Bashir entered upon Muawiyah, took his turban off his head and said: O Muawiyah, do you see meanness? He said: I see nothing but generosity. So he recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
Muawiyah, if you do not give us justice, we will scoop ... The beards of Azd with turbans tied upon them.
Does the slave of Al-Araqin insult us out of belittlement ... So what is it that Al-Araqim avail him?
I have no revenge less than cutting his tongue ... So take the one whom dirhams satisfy regarding him.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab told us from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: It is said 'Ghasistu'. Abu Bakr bin Ayyash [said]: A man from Quraysh was accused of drinking wine. Abu Bakr bin Ayyash said to him: They claimed that a prophet permits wine. The Qurayshi said to him: Then do not believe in him until he cures the blind and the leper.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab told us from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: It is said 'Ghasistu' (I choked) on food, drink, saliva, and speech. It is 'Al-Ghasas', 'Al-Ja'z', and 'Al-Harwah' with one meaning. Likewise 'Al-Tahtahah'. Al-Akhfash said: Al-Mubarrad used to narrate this very thing from the Basrans. He said: If differentiated, it is said 'Ghasistu' on food, 'Shariqtu' on drink, and 'Jaridtu' on saliva. From it is the popular proverb "Hal al-jarid dun al-qarid" (Choking prevented poetry).
Al-Akhfash said: It is narrated from Al-Khalil that he said: There was a man who had a son who started saying poetry, so he forbade him from that. Evil boiled in his chest and he fell ill. He said to his father: If you prevent me from saying poetry, I will die. He did not permit him that until he became heavy and was despaired of. When he saw him like that, he said to him: My son, say whatever poetry you wish. He said: Far from it, choking has prevented poetry. And he recited saying:
(Wafir Meter)
Does he command me, when my life has perished ... To verses he hopes from me? So I swear,
If I remained, I would have said a saying ... By which I would tail the rhymes of every Jinn.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab told us from Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar, he said: Layla al-Akhyaliyyah entered upon Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. He said to her: I adjure you, was there anything between you and Tawbah? She said: No, by the One who seized his soul and is capable of my soul, there was nothing between us. He arrived from some of his travels, so I came to him and greeted him. He squeezed my hand, so I thought he had submitted to some matter. So I recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
And possessor of a need, we said to him: Do not reveal it ... And there is no way to it as long as I live.
We have a companion whom we should not betray ... And you are to another a companion and husband (Halil).
Abu al-Qasim said: It is narrated "Khalil" with the dotted Kha, which is the friend. It is said: "Khaalaka ar-rajulu mukhalalatan wa khilalan" from affection. From it is the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
(Tawil Meter)
And I am not hated by friends (Khilal) nor...
Al-Khalil also said: The man of poor condition. From it is the saying of Zuhair:
(Basit Meter)
And if a friend (Khalil) came to him on a day of asking, he says: ... My wealth is not absent nor forbidden.
And "Al-Khalil": The husband.

Abu Sa'id al-Hasan bin Ali bin Bakr al-Adawi informed us, he said: Uthman bin Talut told us, he said: Al-Asma'i told us, he said: I entered the desert and saw a girl who was the most beautiful of people in face under the ugliest of people in face. I said to her: O you, how were you content with your beauty to be under the ugliest of people in face? She said: O you, how badly you spoke! Perhaps he did good in what is between him and his Lord, so He made me his reward. Or I sinned in what is between me and my Lord, so He punished me with him. Should I not be content with what Allah is content with for me? He said: So she silenced me.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us from Al-Mazini from Al-Jarmi, he said: 'Al-Mahl': Lying. It is said a man 'Mahal', i.e., a liar. 'Al-Mahl': Slander. It is said 'Amhala Fulan bi-Fulan Mahlan' if he slandered him to the Sultan. 'Al-Mahl': Drought. It is said 'Amhala al-balad' if it became drought-stricken. The noun is 'Al-Mahl' as it is said 'Akhsaba ikhsaban' and the noun is 'Al-Khisb' with Kasra only. 'Al-Mahl' and 'Al-Mihal': Deception and plotting. From it is the Almighty's saying (Shadidu al-mihal). It is narrated that Abd al-Muttalib, when he heard of the approach of the People of the Elephant to Mecca, vacated the Sanctuary and went out of it, and said: It has a God who defends it. He recited saying:
(Majzu' al-Kamil Meter)
O God, indeed a man ... Defends his saddle, so defend Your saddles.
Let not their cross and their plot (Mihal) ever defeat ... Your plot (Mihal).

Al-Yazidi informed us from his uncle Abu al-Qasim, he said: Di'bil was reproached for turning away from women, so he married a woman. She stayed with him for one night, then he divorced her. He was spoken to regarding that, and he recited saying:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
I saw an old woman approaching ... So she revealed to my eye a spitting place.
Short of build, squat ... She rolls in walking like a bunduq (ball).
She draws her eyebrow with ink ... And ties a pad on her buttocks.
And two breasts, a breast like an acorn ... And another like an empty waterskin.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Atawi wrote to Al-Mu'tadid while he was staying at Sinjar:
(Kamil Meter)
O you who stayed in the villages of Sinjar ... And chose it as a home for the best residence.
Did you leave Baghdad whose breeze has ... A fragrance from flowers and trees?
It is the paradise of the world, so how did you leave it ... And inhabit a house of no stability?
Are there not in it a million heavily veiled ones ... In the pages of whose foreheads is the light of moons?
And likewise in it a million virgins ... In whose face is a promenade for eyes.
Look with your heart, not your eye, do you see ... Like its men in the rest of the cities?
Who is it that you accompany there who has ... Bits of news and poetry?
Mixed with literary manners ... In the delicacy of flowing fresh water.
And if you stay and sell us and our neighborhood ... For a near covenant or a new visit.
Then I say with excess heat in the vitals ... And the blazing of a fire without sparks.
You did not deem my blood lawful while knowing that ... Whoever deems the blood of a person lawful is in the Fire.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi who said: 'Al-Hal': The meat of the two loins. 'Al-Hal': Black mud. 'Al-Hal': The bundle carried by the porter. 'Al-Hal': The banner tied for princes. It has three dialects: 'Al-Khal' which is the most rooted, 'Al-Hal', and 'Al-Jal'. 'Al-Hal': The meat of the inner thigh of the wild donkey. 'Al-Hal': The condition of a person; it is said 'Hal' and 'Halah' with one meaning. 'Al-Hal': Weight/Load; it is said 'Khaffif 'anni hali' i.e., my load. 'Al-Hal': The wife of a man. 'Al-Hal': The walker on which a child learns to walk. He recited:
(Sari' Meter)
And his luck continued to grow upwards ... Since he was born (Ludda) until the walker (Al-Hal) separated from him.
He says: His affair continued to rise and grow since he was weaned. Ibn al-A'rabi said: Some eloquent people recited to me the opposite of this:
(Rajaz Meter)
And since his membrane (Julbah) was cut from him, there continued ... To be for him from meanness a rein pulling him.
He said: 'Julbah' means 'Jalbah', which is the membrane the child is in, so it splits and he comes out of it, meaning since he was born. 'At-Tila'': The rope. He says: He still has a rope of meanness pulling him to it. 'At-Tila': Wine. 'At-Tila'': Tar. 'At-Tulla' with Damma, Shadda, and Madd: He said: I left him beating in his blood ('Tulla'ihi').

Abu Muhammad bin al-Sari al-Sarraj informed us, he said: Waki' informed me, he said: Some of our companions told me that Abu Nuwas was seen by some of his friends in a dream after his death. He said to him: What did Allah do with you? He said: He forgave me. He said: By what? He said: By verses I said. He said: What are they? He said: They are in a piece of paper in a pillow that was under my head. The man went to his house, asked about the pillow, ripped it open, and found a paper in it written:
(Kamil Meter)
O Lord, if my sins have become great in number ... Then I have known that Your forgiveness is greater.

If only the doer of good hopes in You ... Then whom does the criminal invoke and hope in?
I call upon You, Lord, as You commanded, humbly ... So if You turn away my hand, then who will have mercy?
I have no means to You except hope ... And my good opinion, then that I am a Muslim.

Al-Akhfash recited to us, he said: Tha'lab recited to us, Al-Riyashi recited to us, he said: Al-Mu'arrij recited to us for himself:
(Tawil Meter)
And I separated until I did not care about the distance ... And when neighbors, noble to me, departed.
So I made my soul fold upon the distance ... And my eye sleep upon the loss of the beloved.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim al-Sijistani informed us, he said: Abu Ubayda Ma'mar al-Muthanna informed us, he said: When Hammam bin Amir al-Bakri died, his brothers said to his sons Rabi'ah and Kurayb: Which of you will take his weapon, his quiver, his horse, and his spear on condition that he fulfills Hammam's duty among his people? And which of you will take his camels on condition that he fulfills the duty of the guest? Rabi'ah said: I take my father's honor. So he took his quiver, weapon, horse, and spear on condition that he fulfills the duty of his people in what befalls them. Kurayb took the camels. It was said to Rabi'ah: Kurayb cheated you by taking the wealth. And it was said to Kurayb: Rabi'ah cheated you by taking his father's honor. So Kurayb recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
By your life, I did not take the wealth except ... To give it, and that has a way.
I invest it and know that in it are ... Rights whose abandonment is a long shame.
And the best of wealth is what you gave from ... And the worst of wealth is what the miser kept.
And I am never one to say to a thing ... Yes, without fulfilling what I say.
So whatever people hope for from a young man ... Then I am probable for what is hoped.
And 'Ukabah has known after that I ... When a grave matter befalls it.
That my brother, when agitation is stirred ... Is the head of the spear and the polished sword.
And short-haired like a staff, tall ... Strong of build, the remains (Thamil) are his right.
So the fearful one praises me when he calls me ... Through the dust and the humiliated man.

Rabi'ah said:
(Wafir Meter)
Did you not see me leaving the camels deliberately ... For my knowledge that they are a little good?
And I said: Take the white ones and shepherd them ... And sufficient for me is the sword and the long spear.
And a tall mare, the felt slips off her ... And obscure rings of mail having looseness.
And a pot for the seekers, and its two bowls ... And a fire whose igniter is not blamed.
Matters our father had acquired ... And there is no way to oppose my father.
And they said: You have been cheated. So I said: No, rather ... You were cheated, so I do not rescind nor accept rescission.
Do I take in exchange for height an old toothless she-camel ... Blamed, having a full udder?
I spend the night eating her with an eye ... Sleepless, having a heavy look.
And leave the glory of Hammam and my grandfather ... Jamil, and those by whom I attack?
If a man does not succeed his father ... A ghoul from the days will seize him.
The camels of your companion will be worn out by the nights ... And the beautiful mention will remain after them.

Abu al-Qasim said: It is said a man is 'Mukhil' for good if he is worthy of it. 'Ukabah': Derived from 'Akub' which is dust. 'Al-Ajrad': Short-haired horse, a praiseworthy trait. 'Al-Hirawah': The stick/staff. 'Al-Mishmakherr': The tall one. 'Al-Thamil': Remainder of food and fodder in the belly. 'Al-Salhabah': The tall mare. 'Al-Qatir': Rings of mail, and in other contexts, gray hair. 'An-Nab': The aged she-camel. 'Al-Hafil': Full of milk; from it 'Ihtafala al-majlis' if it became full of people. 'Al-Ghul': What destroys man; Arabs claim it is the female of devils. It is recited for Imru' al-Qays:
(Tawil Meter)
Does he kill me while the Mashrafi sword is my bedfellow ... And sharpened blue [arrowheads] like the fangs of ghouls?

Ibn al-Sarraj informed us, he said: Waki' informed me, he said: Al-Mutawakkil sent to Al-Hasan bin Wahb saying: Say poetry about the tomorrow of this day. He said: How can an imprisoned one say [poetry]? One who was with him said: Say, for perhaps that will be a cause for relief? So he said:
(Mukhla' al-Basit Meter)
The morning has shone like the Resurrection ... And the sound of the Adhan has clashed.
A night of amusement whose morning pleases ... A day of Tanajah (?) and a festival (Mahrajan).
So give me drink and sing to me ... Every captive and every sufferer.
Allah saves every reunion ... That the accidents of time have scattered.
Do you not see the Yemeni lightning ... Truly, certainly, it has saddened me.
It reminded me of the side-teeth of the daughters of ... That one who ruled the languid ones.

A beloved of mine, I was screened from her ... So I do not see her nor does she see me.

Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Abu Najdah from Al-Asma'i, he said: I heard a Bedouin woman describing her youth saying: By Allah, I was more beautiful than the sky and more desirable than water.

Niftawayh recited to us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi:
(Tawil Meter)
Did you not see me resolving on cutting off and abandonment ... Of Layla, but I cannot bear cutting off nor abandonment?
And no day has passed since I abandoned her ... Nor an hour, but I strive to mention her.
So oh wonder at my connecting the rope so she sees ... New [love], while its ties have become cut off.
If she becomes, after neighborliness and love ... Turning away, then deafness has become in my ear.

Ibn Shaqir informed us, he said: I attended Al-Mubarrad when a man asked him about the meaning of the poet's saying:
(Tawil Meter)
If my people, their spears had made me speak ... I would have spoken, but the spears made [me] drag (Ajarrat).
He said: This is like the saying of the other:
(Tawil Meter)
And a rhyme was said, but I could not ... Defend against it if you did not strike with arrowheads.
So I defend a right with a right, and falsehood ... Was not to defend against you the sayer of truth.

Abu al-Qasim said: The meaning of this is that when a weaned camel colt persists in suckling, they put a sharp stick in its nose. If it comes to suckle its mother, that stick pricks her, so she prevents it from suckling. If it refrains from suckling her, [good], otherwise they make it drag (Ajjaruhu). 'Al-Ijrar' is to slit the tongue of the colt or cut its tip, so it is prevented from suckling by necessity. The sayer of the first verse said: My people did not fight, so I am prevented (Mujarr) from praising them because I am forbidden. As if their spears, when they fell short of fighting with them, prevented me from praising them just as the colt is prevented from suckling. So Abu al-Abbas interpreted it with the two preceding verses. 'Al-Ijrar' has another place, which is when a knight stabs another knight, embeds the spear in him, then leaves him defeated dragging the spear; that is a killer inevitably. From it is the poet's saying:
(Wafir Meter)
And another of them, I made him drag my spear ... And in the Bajali is a sharp broad arrowhead.
And the saying of the other:
(Kamil Meter)
And we protect our honors with the best of our wealth ... And we drag spears in the war and leave [them in enemies].

Al-Yazidi informed us from his uncle Abu al-Qasim from Abu Muhammad Yahya bin al-Mubarak al-Yazidi, he said: It is narrated from Al-Sha'bi that he said: Abdullah bin Mas'ud said regarding the saying of Allah Almighty (Indeed, Abraham was a leader (Ummah), devoutly obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth (Hanif)). He said: 'Al-Ummah': The man who teaches good. 'Al-Qanit': The obedient. 'Al-Hanif': The one who abandons Shirk. 'Ijtabahu' (He chose him) says: He selected him. 'Wa hadahu ila siratin mustaqim' (And guided him to a straight path) means he goes straight by it to Paradise. 'Wa ataynahu fi ad-dunya hasanah' (And We gave him good in this world). He said: Good mention and beautiful praise; there is no nation or people of religion but they ally with him and are pleased with him.
Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Qunut' in language is prolonged standing. From it the supplicant is called 'Qanit', and the one praying 'Qanit'. 'Al-Hanaf': Inclination. The Muslim is called 'Hanif' for his turning away from Shirk to Islam and his inclination with no return. From it is 'Al-Hanaf' in the feet, which is the turning of each big toe towards the other and its inclination away from the other toes. The 'Hanif' in Jahiliyyah was one who performed Hajj to the House, washed from major impurity, washed his dead, and was circumcised. When Islam came, the 'Hanif' became the Muslim.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Al-Mubarrad from Ibn al-A'rabi from Al-Mufaddal al-Dabbi, he said: The Commander of the Faithful Al-Mansur said to me: Describe to me the excellent horse (Jawad). I said: O Commander of the Faithful, if the horse is long in three, short in three, wide in three, clear in three, then that is the Jawad that cannot be outrun. He said: Explain them. I said: As for the three long ones, they are the ears, the neck (Hadi), and the thigh. As for the short ones, they are the back, the tailbone (Asib), and the shank. The wide ones: The nostril, the forehead, and the chest (Laban). The clear ones: The skin, the hoof, and the eye.

Al-Ma'nawi recited to us, he said: Al-Fadl bin al-Hubab recited to us, he said: Abu Muhammad al-Tawzi recited to me from Abu Ubayda by Unayf bin Jabalah al-Dabbi, Knight of Al-Shit:
(Kamil Meter)
And I have milked the udders of time ... So I knew what to come to and what to avoid.
And I have witnessed horses carrying my equipment ... Ready like the wolf of the thicket (Qasimah), plundering.
As for if you face him, he is like ... To the eye, a trunk from Awal, trimmed.
And if you view him from the side, his regions are even ... And as if, when viewed from behind, he is pouring down.
Abu Ghanim said: The meaning of these verses is taken from the meaning of Abu Uqaysar's saying in describing a horse: If you face him he is high, if you view him from behind he is low, and if you view him from the side he is even.

Abdullah bin Malik informed us, he said: Al-Riyashi informed us, he said: Muhammad bin Abi Raja' informed me from a man of Banu Makhzum from his father or his uncle, he said: I met Ibn Harmah returning from Medina. He said to me: This man has come out, meaning Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Hasan, and I have composed verses, so know them and memorize them:
(Tawil Meter)
I see people in a twisted matter, so do not cease ... To be cautious until you see the matter settled.
For you cannot return what has passed ... If the saying about its slips has left the mouth.
How many a person of ample honor you see silent ... And another destroyed himself if he spoke.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: My uncle informed me from Ibn al-Kalbi, he said: Abu Hatim informed me from Abu Ubayda, they said: Sama bin Lu'ay bin Ghalib went out from Mecca until he settled in Oman, so he recited:
(Khafif Meter)
Convey to Amir and Ka'b a message ... That my soul is longing for them both.
If my abode is in Oman, then I am ... Noble; I did not emigrate out of poverty.
Then he went out traveling until he stopped at a man from Azd, who hosted him and he spent the night with him. When it was morning, he sat cleaning his teeth (using Siwak). The wife of the Azdi looked at him and liked him. When he threw a piece of his Siwak, she took it and sucked it. Her husband looked at her, so he milked his she-camel into a milking vessel and put poison in it, and presented it to Sama. The woman winked at him, so he spilled the milk and went out traveling. While he was in a place called Jawf al-Khamilah, his she-camel reached for an Arfajah bush and pulled it up, and in it was a viper. She opened it (her mouth/the bush) and threw it on Sama's leg. It bit him and he died. The Azdi woman said weeping for him when his news reached her:
(Khafif Meter)
O eye, weep for Sama bin Lu'ay ... The viper clung to Sama's leg.
I do not see the like of Sama bin Lu'ay ... The she-camel carried his death to him.
Many a cup you spilled, O Ibn Lu'ay ... Cautious of death, that was not to be spilled.
And the intuition of night travel left a destroyed one ... After abandonment, boldness, and elegance.
And you took a separation with a sharp sword ... And avoided the speech of the hinderers.

Abu Abdullah Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Arafah informed us, he said: Al-Hunayni told us from Ahmad bin al-Mufaddal from Asbat from Al-Suddi, he said: It was narrated from Ibn Abbas regarding the Almighty's saying (Or did you think that the companions of the Cave and the Inscription (Al-Raqim)... the verse). He said: The youths, when they fled from their people fearing for their religion, were missed. Their news was told to the king, so he ordered a tablet of lead and wrote their names in it and threw it in his treasury, and said: There will be an affair for them. That tablet is Al-Raqim.
Abu al-Qasim said: There are five opinions regarding Al-Raqim; One is what was narrated from Ibn Abbas that it is a tablet in which their names were written. The second is that Al-Raqim is the inkwell, narrated from Mujahid, and he said: It is in the language of the Romans. The third is that Al-Raqim is the village, narrated from Ka'b. The fourth is that Al-Raqim is the valley. The fifth is what was narrated from Al-Dahhak and Qatada, they said: Al-Raqim: The book. Linguists lean towards this and say: It is 'Fa'il' with the meaning of 'Maf'ul'. It is said: 'Raqamtu al-kitaba' so it is 'Raqim' and 'Marqum', as the Almighty said 'Kitabun Marqum' (A written book).

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Al-Sijistani informed us from Abu Ubayda from Al-Utbi from his father from his grandfather, he said: Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan appointed Rawh bin Zinba' over a task, then betrayal was reported about him, so he dismissed him and ordered him to come to him. He did so, and he ordered him to be beaten. When the whips took him, he said: I adjure you by Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, that you demolish a corner of me that you built, or lower a raised status you elevated, or make an enemy rejoice at me whom you suppressed. By Allah, unless your clemency encompasses all my ignorance and your pardon covers the corruption of your favors. Muawiyah said:
(Tawil Meter)
If Allah eases the knot, it becomes easy.
Let him go.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Umar bin Shabbah, he said: Al-Hasan bin Ali married Khawlah bint Manzur bin Zabban. She stayed with him for a year not applying kohl or adorning herself until she bore him a son. He entered upon her one day and she had adorned herself. He said: What is this? She said: I feared that I would adorn and beautify myself and the women would say: She beautified herself for him but he saw nothing in her. But since this (child) has come, I do not care. When Al-Hasan died, she grieved for him intensely. Her father Manzur said:
(Kamil Meter)
I was informed that Khawlah yesterday grieved ... From the calamities of time befalling.
Do not grieve, O Khawlah, and be patient ... For the noble are built on patience.

Abdullah bin Malik informed us, he said: Al-Zubayr informed us from his uncle, he said: A son of Abdullah bin Ali died, so he grieved for him intensely and refrained from food and drink for three days, and secluded himself from people. On the fourth day, his scribe went out to the chamberlain and said: He has prevented me from that (entering). He said to him: Give permission. So they entered upon him, and the scribe sat in their way and said: Console the Emir and entertain him. So they did, but nothing of their speech entertained him until Umar bin Hafs entered upon him and said: May Allah reform the Emir, the Book was revealed to you, so you are most knowledgeable of its interpretation, and from you is the Messenger of Allah, so you are most knowledgeable of his Sunnah. We do not teach you anything we see you ignorant of, but we remind you. These are verses said by someone who was afflicted like you were afflicted:
(Tawil Meter)
By my life, if you follow your eyes with what has passed ... Of time, or what death drove to the grave.
You will surely exhaust the water of the tear ducts entirely ... Even if you were to draw them from the middle of the sea.
So I said to Abdullah when he yearned weeping ... Be consoled, while the water of the eye pours flowing.
Verify, for if weeping returned a dead one ... To anyone, then exert your weeping for Amr.
And do not weep for a dead one after a dead one, embryos ... Ali, Abbas, and the family of Abu Bakr.
And I console you with a verse I said, which is:
(Tawil Meter)
And the easiest of what I encounter of grief is that I ... Will join him in his abode today or tomorrow.
So he called for food and ate, he and his companions.

Niftawayh informed us from Ahmad bin Yahya from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: 'As-Sabr' (Patience): Verbal noun of 'Sabartu'. 'As-Sabur': A dialect in 'As-Sabr' for this bitter thing (aloes). 'As-Sabr': Confinement. It is said: 'Sabartu fulanan kadha wa kadha' meaning I confined him for it. In the Hadith, a man held a man and another killed him, so it was said: "Kill the killer and confine (Isbiru) the confiner (Sabir)" meaning imprison him. 'As-Sabr': Daring/Endurance upon something. From it is the Almighty's saying (Fa-ma asbarahum 'ala an-nar) meaning how daring they are upon it. Al-Mubarrad said: Its interpretation is: What called them to have patience upon it? Ibn al-A'rabi recited:
(Tawil Meter)
We gave them to drink a cup like they gave us to drink ... But we were more patient (Asbara) upon death.
i.e., we were more daring upon death, so we stormed the war and killed them.

Al-Zajjaji informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us from Al-Mazini from Al-Asma'i, he said: It is said: 'Arabbat an-naqah bi-l-fahl', and 'Alammat bihi', and 'Ashiqathu': If she did not leave him and became familiar with him. From this, the lover is called 'Ashiq'.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: 'Al-Ashaqah': A tree called Al-Lablabah (Ivy), it turns green then thins then yellows. From that is the derivation of 'Al-Ashiq'. He said: And it is said: 'Ghazala al-kalbu azh-zhabya': If he ran in its track, caught up with it and seized it, then let it go. From this is the flirting (Ghazal) with women, as if the man plays with her and makes her desire him, but if he tries to kiss her, she turns away from him. Al-Zajjaj said: The origin of 'Mughazalah' is from spinning and twisting because it is turning away from a matter. From it 'Al-Mighzal' (spindle) is named for its rotation and speed of turning. And 'Al-Ghazal' (gazelle) is named for its speed. The sun is named 'Al-Ghazalah' for its speed and rotation. He recited:
(Rajaz Meter)
She said to him and leaned on her elbow: O youth ... Who drives the gazelles of the forenoon (sun/early hours) with the people.

Abdullah bin Malik informed us, he said: Al-Zubayr informed us from his uncle, he said: Abdullah bin Muslim bin Jundab said: Isa bin Umar bin Talha bin Abdullah bin Ma'mar knocked on my door one night after I had slept. I went out to him and said: What brings you at this time? He said: Just now the slave girl of Ibn Humran sang to me your saying:
(Tawil Meter)
Come, help me against the night, for it is ... Upon every eye that does not sleep, long.
So I said to him: May Allah fulfill the rights for you, O son of my brother. The response was slow until Allah brought relief.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abd al-Rahman informed me from his uncle, he said: Al-Hasan al-Basri passed by the door of Umar bin Hubayra and the Quran readers were there. He greeted them then said: What is the matter with you sitting, having trimmed your mustaches, shaved your heads, shortened your sleeves, and flattened (Faltahtum) your sandals? By Allah, if you had renounced what is with the kings, they would have desired what is with you. You have disgraced the Quran readers, may Allah disgrace you. Abd al-Rahman said: I said to my uncle: What is 'Al-Mufaltah' in [speech]? He said: It is the thing whose top is wide and bottom is thin. From it is said: 'Ra's Mufaltah', and the common people say 'Mufartah'.

Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Malik informed us, he said: Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar informed us, he said: Maslamah bin Ibrahim al-Makhzumi told me from Ayyub bin Maslamah, he said: Umar bin Abdullah bin Abi Rabi'ah was infatuated and in love with Al-Thurayya bint Abdullah bin Ali bin Al-Harith bin Umayyah the Younger bin Abd Shams bin Abd Manaf. She was worthy of that in beauty and perfection. She used to spend the summer in Ta'if. During her stay in Ta'if, Umar used to wake up early, get on his horse, and ask the riders coming with fruit from Ta'if about the news to find comfort in what he heard of her news. One day he asked them about the strange news they had. They said: We have no news except that when we departed we heard loud screaming over a woman from Quraysh whose name is like the name of a star in the sky who has left us (died). Umar said to them: Al-Thurayya? They said: Yes. So Umar rode straight away, making his horse run full speed towards Ta'if, taking the Kada' route, which is the ruggedest and shortest of the two paths. When he reached Ta'if, he found her safe, coming out to watch for him, with her two sisters Radia and Umm Uthman. He told her the news. She said: By Allah, I ordered them to do that to know what (feeling) you have for me. Umar said regarding this journey of his:
(Tawil Meter)
The red-black horse complained of the galloping when I exhausted it ... And showed that if it could, it would speak.
So I said to it: If I meet a delight for the eye ... Then it is easy for me that you tire and weary.
I would then lose my wealth and my soul would depart ... If I did not say as a peer that Allah has saved.
Therefore, I bring near a tethered horse instead of my [other] horses ... And I advise that it not be humiliated, but honored.

Abu al-Qasim said: 'Ada al-faras' is said if he made it run (gallop). 'Kalla ar-rajul': If he becomes weak, 'Yakillu', 'Kallan' and 'Kalalah'. From it 'Al-Kalalah' in lineage is from weakness because it is what is other than the parent and child. Some scholars made 'Al-Kalalah' in the verse "Yurathu Kalalatan": The deceased. And some make it the wealth. Most are on what we started with. 'Al-Kall': The weak. 'Al-Kall': The heavy burden on his family. 'Al-Kall': The orphan.

Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Al-Riyashi, he said: Samura bin Jundub said: Muhammad bin Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf died. When we returned from his funeral, I passed by an old man from Banu Uqayl. He said to me: From where? I said: From the funeral of Muhammad bin Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf. The old man recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
So taste as we tasted on the morning of Muhajjar ... Of rage in our livers and anguish (Tahawwub).
He said: Al-Hajjaj had killed a son of the old man.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad told us from Al-Mazini from Al-Asma'i from Abu Amr bin al-Ala', he said: It was said to a man from Bakr bin Wa'il who had lived two hundred and thirty years: How did you find the world? He said: I lived a hundred years in which I did not have a headache, then in the hundred and thirty, I was afflicted with what afflicts people.

Al-Akhfash recited to us from Tha'lab:
(Munsarih Meter)
Indeed, Mu'adh bin Muslim is a man ... Who has groaned from the length of his life, eternity.
The head of time has turned gray and the age has become old ... And the clothes of his life are new.
O vulture of Luqman, how long will you live and how long ... Will you drag the tail of life, O Lubad?
The house of Adam has become ruined ... And you are in it as if you were the peg.
You ask its crows when they hop ... How is the headache and the ophthalmia?

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Ahmad bin Yahya informed us from Abu al-Fadl al-Riyashi from Al-Asma'i, he said: I heard an old man from Banu al-Ujayf say: I wished for a house, and I remained four months thinking about the staircase, how it would be placed. And it was said to a man from Al-Dabab: Wish. He wished for a worn tent, a bow in a basket (Jullah) on a rainy night, and that a dog would come and enter the tent with him.
Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Qaws': Remainder of dates in the basket. 'Al-As': Remainder of honey in its vessel, or the place from which it is gathered. 'Al-Ka'b': Remainder of ghee in the skin. 'Al-Hilal': Remainder of water in the trough. 'Al-Shafa' (shortened): Remainder of anything. It is said: Honey is 'Al-Asal', 'Al-Laws', 'Al-Ary', 'Ad-Dahk', 'As-Su'abib', 'At-Tarm', and 'At-Turaym'. It is said 'Tamanna ar-rajul': If he spoke to himself and thought. 'Tamanna': If he asked his Lord. 'Tamanna': If he lied. Some Arabs passed by Ibn Da'b while he was narrating to people and said: Is this something you narrated or fabricated (Tamannaytahu)? It is said: 'Tamanna ar-rajul': If he recited the Quran. From it is the Almighty's saying: (They do not know the Scripture except through hearsay/wishful thinking (Amani)). It is recited:
(Tawil Meter)
He recited (Tamanna) the Book of Allah at the beginning of his night ... And at its end, he met the decree of death.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim told us from Al-Asma'i, he said: Four did not make grammatical errors in seriousness or jest: Al-Sha'bi, Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf, and Ibn al-Qariyyah. Al-Hajjaj was the most eloquent of them. He said one day to his cook: Cook for us 'Mukhallalah', and increase the 'Fayjan' on it, and make for us 'Muza'za''. The cook did not understand what he said. So he asked some of his boon companions, and he said: Cook for us 'Sikbaj' (vinegar stew), and increase the rue (Sadhaba) on it, and make for us smooth 'Faludhaj' (sweet pudding). He said: And another time a grilled fish was presented to him, and he said: Take it, woe to you, and 'Sammimha' and return it. He did not understand him, so his boon companion said to him: He says to me, cool it down for it is hot.
Al-Asma'i said: It is called 'Al-Faludh', 'As-Sartrat', 'Al-Muza'za'', 'Al-Luwwas', and 'Al-Lummas'. As for 'Al-Faludhaj' it is Persian, and 'Al-Faludhaq' is Arabized (Muwalladah).

Abu Ghanim recited:
(Tawil Meter)
O who is for a heart delighted by calamities ... The events of time threw at it from every side.
It became clear on the day of separation that his resolve ... To have patience was one of the lying thoughts.

Niftawayh recited to us: He said Tha'lab recited to us from Ibn al-A'rabi:
(Wafir Meter)
In the sides of Hijaz is a buried love ... That keeps me awake when eyes are calm.
I yearn for Hijaz and its inhabitants ... The yearning of the tame one separated from the companion.

Abu al-Fadl Zubayd recited to us, he said: Muhammad bin Dawud al-Isbahani recited to me for himself:
(Tawil Meter)
Your brother who became fond of your love ... Repents to you today from what preceded.
If you do not connect with him out of desire for his brotherhood ... And you are not longing, then connect with him out of generosity.
