For, by the One who saved you from what he was afflicted with ... He regretted, if it pleases you that he regrets.
By Allah, the avoidance that passed was not ... Coquetry, nor was the harshness boredom.
And do not reward him with abandonment if he turned away forced ... And showed avoidance and displayed frowning.
And forgetfulness did not distract him from you, but rather ... He delayed when he did not find a way forward.

He also recited to me for him:
(Tawil Meter)
He has an eye that shoots hearts with arrows ... More severe than the continuous striking with the sword.
My friend says: How is your patience after us ... I said: Is there patience so one asks about 'how'?

Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Mansur known as Ibn al-Khayyat al-Nahwi informed us, he said: Abu al-Hasan bin al-Tayyan informed us from Abu Yusuf Yaqub bin Ishaq al-Sikkit from Al-Asma'i and Abu Zayd and others. Regarding the names of head wounds (Shajjaj) mentioned in this section, the speech of some entered into others. They said: 'Shajj' (wound) is in the face and head specifically, excluding the rest of the body.
The first of Shajjaj is 'Al-Harisah', which splits the skin lightly and no blood flows from it yet. From it 'Harasa al-qassar ath-thawba': If he tore it lightly.
Then 'Ad-Damiyah': Which its blood appears but does not flow.
Then 'Ad-Dami'ah': Which its blood drips like the eye tears.
Then 'Al-Badi'ah': Which exceeded the skin to the flesh and cut it.
Then 'Al-Mutalahimah': Which took into the flesh.
Then 'Al-Simhaq': Which exceeded the flesh into the thin skin that is between the flesh and the bone. That skin is called 'Simhaq', so the wound was named after it. 'Al-Simhaq' is also called 'Al-Milta'', extended and shortened. From it the Hadith "Al-Milta' bi-damiha", i.e., judgment is passed on it immediately and not waited to see its outcome.
Then 'Al-Mudihah': Which pierced the Simhaq and exposed the bone, i.e., made it visible.
Then 'Al-Muqarrishah' (Iqrashan with Qaf): Which cracked the bone but did not fracture it.
Then 'Al-Hashimah': Which fractured the bone.
Then 'Al-Munaqqilah': Which bones come out of it.
Then 'Al-Ammah': Also called 'Al-Ma'mumah' and 'Al-Amim', which reached the 'Umm al-Ra's' (meninges), which is the gathering of the brain. Its owner faints at the sound of thunder and roaring of camels, and cannot go out in the sun.
Then 'Ad-Damighah': Which crushes the bone (to the brain), and there is no survival for its owner.

Al-Zajjaj and Al-Akhfash informed us, they said: Al-Mubarrad informed us, he said: It was narrated from more than one source that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, gave a sermon one day. He praised Allah and extolled Him - as He is worthy of - and sent blessings upon His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Then he turned to the people and said: O people, indeed you have landmarks, so end at your landmarks. And indeed you have an end, so end at your end. For the servant is between two fears: a term that has passed, he does not know what Allah will do in it, and a term that remains, he does not know what Allah will decree in it. So let the servant take from himself for himself, and from his world for his Hereafter, and from youth before old age, and from life before death. For by the One in Whose hand is Muhammad's soul, there is no appeasement after death, and there is no abode after the world except Paradise or Hell.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us, he said: Ibn al-A'rabi informed us, he said: It was narrated from Abu Abdullah al-Jadali, he said: I entered upon the Commander of the Faithful Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and I saw poured gold before him. I said: What is this, O Commander of the Faithful? He said: This is the Ya'sub (leader) of the hypocrites. I said: And what is the meaning of the Ya'sub of the hypocrites, O Commander of the Faithful? He said: This is what the hypocrites seek refuge with, just as the believers seek refuge with me. So I am the Ya'sub of the believers, and this is the Ya'sub of the hypocrites.
Tha'lab said: Ibn al-A'rabi said: 'Al-Ya'sub' among people: The master (Sayyid). And 'Al-Ya'sub': The chief of the bees; if he flies, they fly with him, and if he lands, they land. It is said: They are 'An-Nahl', 'Ath-Thawl', 'Ad-Dabr', 'Al-Khashram', 'Al-Kharshram', 'Ar-Rasah', 'Ad-Dakha' (with light Kha and Qasr), and 'Al-Ya'asib' and 'An-Nub' are synonymous. It is recited:
(Tawil Meter)
If the bees sting him, he does not hope (Yarju) for their sting ... And he opposes them in a house of working bees (Nub).
'Ar-Raja'' (Hope) here means: Fear. That is why the commentators said regarding the Almighty's saying: (What is the matter with you that you do not hope for Allah an honor [Waqar]) meaning you do not fear greatness for Him.

Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Malik al-Darir informed us, he said: Al-Zubayr informed us, he said: Sulayman bin Ayyash al-Sa'di from Sa'd al-Ashirah told me, he said: Jamal bint Awn bin Muslim told me from her father from her grandfather, he said: I went out one day and saw a man black like the night with a woman white like milk. I approached him and the scent of musk overwhelmed me. I said: Who are you? He said: I am the one who says:
(Tawil Meter)
Oh would that I knew what the estrangement of separation ... And the distance at Umm Bakr's will bring us tomorrow.
When the distance is coupled with us ... Then the enemies are alone with her after me.
Will you cut me off when the enemies are present ... So they gloat at me, or will you remain faithful to the covenant?
The woman shouted at him: No, by Allah, but we will remain faithful to the covenant. I asked about him and was told: This is Nusayb, and this is Umm Bakr.

Abu al-Qasim al-Sa'igh informed us, he said: Abdullah bin Muslim bin Qutayba told us, he said: Al-Sijistani informed me from Abu Ubayda, he said: When death approached Qays bin Asim al-Minqari, he gathered his sons and said: O my sons, memorize from me, for no one is more advising to you than me. When I die, make your elders leaders, and do not make your youngers leaders, for people will belittle your elders and you will all become insignificant to them. And you must preserve wealth, for in it is a sign of nobility for the generous, and independence from the mean. And beware of asking people, for it is the last earning of a man.

Ibn Mujahid informed us from Muhammad bin al-Jahm, he said: It reached me that a man from Khath'am said:
(Kamil Meter)
If I were to ascend in noble deeds and high status ... Like the descent (Tahabbut), I would be the master of Khath'am.
He said: Then he became the master of his people after a while. He was spoken to about that, so he recited saying:
(Kamil Meter)
The houses became empty so I became a master, not made a master ... And it is of suffering that I am alone in sovereignty.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: I was one day in the presence of Tha'lab, so I hastened to leave before the session ended. He said to me: Where to? I do not see you patient away from Al-Khuldi's session? I said: I have a need. He said: I see him preferring Al-Buhturi over Abu Tammam. So when you go to him, say to him: What is the meaning of Abu Tammam's saying:
(Wafir Meter)
O one familiar with weeping, how many a separation ... I shaded, so it was a caller for meeting.
He said: So when I went to Al-Mubarrad, I asked him about it. He said: The meaning of this is that lovers and those in passion may cut off and abandon each other out of coquetry, not out of resolve for severance. When departure time comes and they sense separation, they return to affection and meet out of fear of separation, and that the time of meeting might be long after it. So separation then becomes a cause for meeting, as the other said:
(Khafif Meter)
They enjoyed the separation on the day of separation ... Seeking refuge in weeping and embracing.
How much they hid their passion fearing people ... And how much they concealed the burning of longing.
So separation misguided therein a separation ... That came to them by agreement.
How can I call upon the separator for injustice ... When on the morning of separation was the meeting.
He said: When I returned to Tha'lab in the other session, I asked him about it, and repeated the answer and the verses to him. He said: How intense is his obfuscation! He did nothing. The meaning of the verse is only: That a person may leave his beloved hoping to gain in his travel, so he returns to his beloved independent of moving about, so his meeting with him prolongs. Do you not see him saying in the second verse:
(Wafir Meter)
And the joy of returns is only ... For one stopped upon the grief of farewell.
This is parallel to the saying of the other, rather Abu Tammam took from him:
(Tawil Meter)
I will seek distance of the abode from you so you come near ... And my eyes pour tears so they freeze (dry up/stop).
This is exactly that.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab told us from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: I entered upon Sa'id bin Salm and Al-Asma'i was with him reciting a poem by Al-Ajjaj until he reached his saying:
(Rajaz Meter)

If I exchanged strength ('Ad) for strength ... It would not be equal, so I became bent.
Indeed, he saw me leading the sitting ones (Al-Qu'ad).
I said to him: What is the meaning of Al-Qu'ad? He said: Women. I said: This is a mistake. The plural of women (sitting) is 'Al-Qawa'id' as Allah Almighty said: (And the women sitting (Al-Qawa'id) among women). And in the plural of men (sitting) it is said: 'Al-Qu'ad' as it is said: 'Rakib' and 'Rukkab', 'Darib' and 'Durrab'. So he was silenced.
His way was to argue against me saying: Some plurals may be carried on others, so the plural of feminine is carried on masculine, and masculine on feminine when needed, as they said in masculine "Halik" in "Hawalik", and "Faris" and "Fawaris", so it was pluralized as the feminine is pluralized. And as Al-Qatami said regarding the feminine:
(Basit Meter)
Their eyes incline towards the youths ... And I see them not turning away (Suddad) from me.

Al-Yazidi informed us, he said: My uncle Al-Fadl bin Muhammad informed us from Abu Muhammad Ibn al-Mubarak al-Yazidi, he said: We were one night in Balad with Al-Mahdi in the month of Ramadan, four months before he became Caliph. They discussed grammar and Arabic language one night in his presence. I was connected to Khalid bin Yazid bin Mansour, and Al-Kisa'i was with the son of Al-Hasan the Chamberlain. The governor sent for me and Al-Kisa'i. I went to the house and found Al-Kisa'i at the door, having preceded me. He said to me: I seek refuge in Allah from your evil, O Abu Muhammad. I said to him: You will not be harmed from my direction unless I am harmed from yours.
When we entered upon Al-Mahdi, he turned to me and said: How did they form the relative adjective for 'Al-Bahrayn' saying 'Bahrani', and for 'Al-Hisnayn' saying 'Hisni'? Why didn't they say 'Hisnani' as they said 'Bahrani'?
I said: O Emir, if they said 'Bahri' in relation to 'Al-Bahrayn', it would be confused, not knowing if the relation fell on 'Al-Bahrayn' or 'Al-Bahr' (The Sea). So they added an Alif to distinguish between them, as they said in relation to 'Ar-Ruh' (Spirit) 'Ruhani'. 'Al-Hisnayn' did not have anything to be confused with, so they said 'Hisni' according to analogy.
I heard Al-Kisa'i say to Umar bin Nuh: If the Emir asked me about it, I would have answered with a better reason than this.
I said: May Allah reform the Emir, this one claims that if you asked him, he would answer better than me.
He said: Then I ask him.
He said: May Allah reform the Emir, they disliked saying 'Hisani' combining two Nuns, and there was only one Nun in 'Al-Bahrayn', so they said 'Bahrani' for that.
I said: How do you form the relative adjective for a man from Banu Jinan if you stick to your analogy? You said: 'Jinni', combining it with the one related to Jinn. And if you said 'Jinani', you went back on your prohibition and combined three Nuns.
Then we discussed speech until I said to him: How do you say: "Inna min khayri al-qawmi wa afdalihim aw khayrahum battata Zayd" (Indeed among the best of the people and their most excellent or their best definitely is Zayd)?
He lowered his head thinking and prolonged his thought. I said: May Allah reform the Emir, let him answer and err so he learns better than this speech.
He said: "Inna min khayri al-qawmi wa afdalihim aw khayrahum battata Zaydan" (with Zaydan accusative).
I said: You erred, O Emir.
He said: And how do you raise it before bringing the noun of 'Inna', and installing it after raising, which no one allows?
Shaybah bin al-Walid said, partial to him: Perhaps he meant by 'Aw' (or) 'Bal' (but).
I said: This, by my life, is a meaning.
Al-Kisa'i picked it up and said: I intended nothing else.
I said to him: You both erred, because it is not permissible [to say]: "Indeed among the best of the people and their most excellent, nay their best, is Zayd (Zaydan - acc)."
Al-Mahdi said: O Kisa'i, nothing like today has passed you by. He said: So what is the correct way according to you?
I said: "Inna min khayri al-qawmi wa afdalihim aw khayrahum battata Zaydun" (with Zaydun nominative), on the meaning of repeating 'Inna'.
Al-Mahdi said: You have differed and you are both just witnesses, so who will judge between you?
I said: The eloquent Arabs of natural disposition.
So he sent for Abu al-Mutawwaq. I composed verses until he came. Al-Mahdi was inclined towards his maternal uncles from Yemen. I said:
(Munsarih Meter)
O you who ask me to inform him ... About those in Sana'a of noble lineage.
Himyar are its masters, you acknowledge them ... The best of all the multitudes of Arabs.
So indeed among their best and most excellent ... Or their best definitely is Abu Karib.
When Abu al-Mutawwaq came, I recited the verses to him and asked him about the issue. He agreed with me:
(Khafif Meter)
Live with luck (Jadd) and stupidity will not harm you ... For the life of whom you see is only by luck.
Live with luck and be Habannaqah al-Qaysi ... In ignorance, or Shaybah bin al-Walid.
Shayb, O Shayb, O Hani' of Banu al-Qa'qa', you are not the forbearing, the rational.
No, nor is there in you a trait of traits ... Of good that you attained by forbearance or generosity.
Except that you are proficient in beautifying ... Singing by striking a tambourine and oud.
So upon this and that you endure time ... Being glorified by it and not glorified.

Abu al-Qasim said: The issue is built on corruption for the sake of deception (trickery). As for Al-Kisa'i's answer, it is not satisfactory to anyone. Al-Yazidi's answer is not permissible according to us because he hid 'Inna' and made it operate, and it is not in its power to be hidden and operate. As for repeating it, it is permissible, it has come in the Quran. Allah Almighty said (Indeed, those who have believed and those who were Jews and the Sabeans and the Christians and the Magians and those who associated with others - indeed, Allah will judge between them). He made the second 'Inna' with its noun and predicate a predicate for the first. The poet said:
(Basit Meter)
Indeed the Caliph, indeed Allah clothed him ... With a cloak of kingship by which endings are hoped.
The correct view according to us in the issue is to say: "Inna min khayri al-qawmi wa afdalihim aw khayruhum al-battata Zaydun", so the noun of 'Inna' is hidden in it, and what follows is a new sentence. Sibawayh mentioned: 'Al-Battata' is a source the Arabs did not use except with Alif and Lam, and deleting them from it is a mistake.

Al-Zajjaj informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us, he said: Al-Mada'ini told us from Al-Ajlani from Isma'il bin Yasar, he said: A son of Arta'ah bin Suhayyah al-Murri died, so he stuck to his grave for a year, coming to it in the morning standing over it saying: O Amr, are you going with me or shall I stay with you until the evening? Then he comes to it in the evening and says the like. When it was after the year, he recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
Until the year, then the name of peace be upon you both ... And whoever weeps for a full year has excused himself.
Then he left his grave and recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
I stood at Layla's grave and my standing ... Upon it was nothing but weeping and anxious.
Are you Layla's son if I waited for you going ... With the caravan or tomorrow, tomorrow then with me?
If my mind was present with me, I would not have been struck by ... Forgetfulness at a grave in the sides of Ajra'.
I was nothing but distraught after losing her ... Over losing her, following the repeated yearning.
If you do not find it, turn to your intentions ... From the earth or come to a thousand so graze.
Upon Time, so blame, for it is not blameworthy ... And in other than whom the earth has hidden, have hope.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us from Al-Mazini from Al-Asma'i, he said: Khalaf, when he went to his bed, would not lie down until he recited:
(Basit Meter)
A man does not cease exploring his lying places ... Until he spends the night lying in the furthest of them.
And he never stops purifying his drinking places ... Until he gulps from the muddy water of decay, gulps.
So prevent your eyelids all night their slumber ... And knock your vitals with the deliciousness of quenching and satiety.
And feel righteousness and piety, prepare them ... Until you attain with them success and elevation.

Ibn al-Anbari informed us, he said: Al-Khattali informed me from Al-Asma'i, Al-Khalil said: I looked into the science of stars (astrology), and I stumbled from it upon what obligated me to leave it. And he recited saying:
(Khafif Meter)
Convey from me to the astrologer that I ... Am a disbeliever in what the stars decreed.
Knowing that what will be and what was ... Is a decree from the Guardian (Al-Muhaymin), obligatory.
Abu al-Qasim said: Al-Muhaymin: The Trustworthy (Al-Amin). Linguists say the Ha in it is a substitute for Hamza. It is recited for Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib praising the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him:
(Munsarih Meter)
Before it, you were good in the shadows and in ... A repository where the leaves are sewn.
Then you descended to the lands, not human ... You, nor a chew of flesh nor a clot.
But a drop riding the ships, and ... The drowning had bridled Nasr and his people.
Transferring from a loin to a womb ... When a world passed, a layer appeared.
Until your house, the guarded (Al-Muhaymin), contained from ... Khindif a high place under which are the zones.
And when you were born, the earth shone ... And the horizons were illuminated by your light.
And we are in that illumination and in ... Paths of guidance and rationality, piercing through.

Al-Akhfash recited to us from Tha'lab:
(Kamil Meter)
And upon Quddam I carried the equipment of a determined one ... In fear, his heart is not burdened.
As for if you face her, you imagine her ... Like the trunk trimmed by the marrow of the sickle.
As for if you view her from the side, she is flown ... Her hooves repel the crushed stones.
As for if you view her from behind, she is noble ... Elevated in the place of her girth and the spurring place.
And if you describe, you describe the middle of a locust ... And if you possess her rein, you will not fail.
And she was a Hiri waterskin, filled ... With which a croup, strong of joint, is raised.
So my sight chose her for my knowledge that she ... Running, will advance in the first rank.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Al-Sijistani told us from Al-Asma'i from Abu Amr bin al-Ala', he said: It was said to a man from Banu Bakr bin Wa'il who had grown old until the pleasure of food, drink, and marriage had gone from him: Do you love to die? He said: No. It was said: So what remains of your pleasures in the world? He said: Hearing wonders. And he recited saying:
(Tawil Meter)
And the destruction of a youth is that he does not rest towards generosity ... And that he does not see a wonderful thing and wonder.
The meaning of 'Yurah': 'Yartah' (finds rest/joy). The meaning of the speech: And that he does not wonder when he sees a wonder.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim told us from Al-Asma'i, he said: Ru'ba said in describing horses and erred. He said in describing the legs:
(Rajaz Meter)
With four that do not cling to the bending ... They fall in pairs and land in agreement.
Salm said to him: This is wrong, this is harm. Do you make him gallop with his leg and swim with his hand (arm) as Abu al-Najm said:
(Rajaz Meter)
He gallops his rear and follows his front.
He said: O my son, you are more knowledgeable about horses than me, but bring me close to the tail of this camel. Al-Asma'i said: So he was brought close to it but did nothing.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn Shabbah, he said: It was narrated from Hisham bin Urwa that Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Bakr Al-Siddiq entered Damascus in the Pre-Islamic era and saw a girl like an Arabian filly, surrounded by maids ransoming her and swearing by her head, saying: No, by the right of the daughter of Al-Judi. So she fell into his heart. He turned away from her and recited:
(Tawil Meter)
He remembered Layla while Al-Samawah was between them ... And what has the daughter of Al-Judi to do with Layla and my wealth?
And how can a Harithiyyah concern his heart ... Who frequents Busra or inhabits Al-Jabiya?
And how can he meet her? Nay, but perhaps she ... If people attend a season, she might come.
He said: He continued to mention her in poetry. When it was the Caliphate of Umar and he sent to the Levant, he said to them: If you storm Damascus, give the daughter of Al-Judi as spoil to Ibn Abi Bakr. So she was given to him. He preferred her over his wives until they complained about him to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. She scolded him for that and said to him: Indeed your wives have a right upon you. He said: It is as if I am sipping a pomegranate seed with her saliva.

Muhammad bin al-Qasim al-Anbari told us, he said: My father told us from Ahmad bin al-Harith from Al-Mada'ini, he said: Umar bin Abd al-Aziz used to say: If it is the Day of Resurrection and the Romans come with their Caesars and the Persians with their Khosroes, we will come with Al-Hajjaj and he will be equal to them.

Ibn Shaqir Ahmad bin al-Husayn informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: It is said 'Laqa'a Fulanun Fulanan bi-'aynihi', and 'Zalaqahu', 'Azlaqahu', 'Shaqadhahu', and 'Shawwahahu': All that if he hit him with the evil eye. A man says to his companion if he does well in an action: 'La tushawwih 'alayya': i.e., Do not say to me you did well lest you hit me with your eye. It is said: A man 'Ma'yun': If he has the evil eye (is affected). It is said: A man 'Sha'ih', 'Shah', 'Mushawwih', 'Shaqidh', and 'Shaqidhan': If he is severe in hitting with the evil eye.
He said: Muawiyah and Ibn al-Zubayr were traveling together and saw a rider from afar. Muawiyah said: It is so-and-so. Ibn al-Zubayr said: It is so-and-so. When we verified it, it was as Ibn al-Zubayr said. Muawiyah said: O Abu Bakr, how excellent is this sharpness with old age? He said: Your blessing (Birraka), O Commander of the Faithful. He said: Your blessing, O Commander of the Faithful. He said: Your blessing, O Commander of the Faithful. So he fell silent. He said the third one, so I fell silent and laughed. Ibn al-Zubayr said: How excellent are these incisors and how charming is this face with the length of life and abundance of worries. Then they separated. Ibn al-Zubayr complained of his eyes until they were almost gone, and Muawiyah's incisors fell out. They met in the second year, so he said to him: O Abu Bakr, I am 'Ashwa' than you: i.e., greater in luck than you in hitting with the evil eye. And I am less harmful than you. Tha'lab said: It is from their saying 'Ramahu' (He shot him): If he did not hit his killer spot.

Ibn al-Anbari informed us from his father from some of his sheikhs from Muhammad bin Hazim, who was a witty poet, he said: Bashar bin Burd invited us, and he had two singing girls. In the gathering, some of us were toying with them and extending hands to them. I disdained that for him, so I wrote to him the next day:
(Khafif Meter)
Fear Allah, you are the poet of Qays ... Do not be a stain upon the poets.
Indeed your brothers residing yesterday ... Came for adultery, not for singing.
You are blind, and adulterers have lapses ... Denounced, hidden from the sighted.
Granted you master speech, but what is your knowledge in it ... Of winking and gesturing?
And signals with eyes and hands ... And taking appointments for meeting?
They settled their affair while you are a donkey ... Loaded with stupidity and dim-wittedness.
He said: So he took them to the market and sold them.

He said: Abu Isa Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Qatan al-Simsar al-Ajli informed us, he said: Abu Ja'far bin Abi Shaybah informed us, he said: I saw Ibn Abi al-Atahiya standing in the graveyards saying:
(Kamil Meter)

O people of the graves, I came to you inquiring ... And behold, your gathering is deaf and dumb.
Indeed, a man who remembers the Return out of fear ... Is luckier than one who does not fear it, and wiser.
O greedy man, do you not see ... The signs of your life being erased every day?
With you, may you have no father, since you were created, entrusted ... Is an angel counting against you what you breathe.
So when the term decreed for you ends ... And passes, you have no place of confinement after that.
Abu Isa said: I heard our sheikhs saying: The son of Adam breathes in every day and night twenty-four thousand breaths, in every hour a thousand breaths. So the exit of his soul is with the last breath decreed for him.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Ishaq bin al-Husayn bin Maymun Abu Ya'qub al-Harbi told us, he said: Al-Husayn bin Muhammad told us from Shayban from Qatada regarding the Almighty's saying: (Or do We treat those who believe and do righteous deeds... the verse). He said: The people separated in their religions at death and at the destination. And Qatada said: (Or He seizes them with gradual wasting (Takhawwuf)). He said: With diminution.
Abu al-Qasim said: Our companions say: Al-Akhfash Sa'id bin Mas'adah used to recite for this letter:
(Basit Meter)
The journey diminished (Takhawwafa) from her a tall hump ... As the file (Safan) diminished the wood of the Nab' tree.
Linguists and commentators are on this interpretation except what was narrated from Al-Dahhak, for he used to say: Its interpretation is that He destroys their people and frightens others with them.

Ibn Shaqir al-Nahwi and Al-Akhfash informed us, they said: Tha'lab informed us, he said: Al-Kisa'i and Al-Asma'i met in the presence of Al-Rashid, and they were accompanying him, staying when he stayed and traveling when he traveled. Al-Kisa'i recited:
(Basit Meter)
How did they reward Amir with evil for their deed ... Or how do they reward me with evil for good?
Or how does what the nursing camel ('Aluq) gives benefit ... Affection (Ri'man) of a nose when the milk is withheld?
Al-Asma'i said: It is only 'Ri'mana' with Nasb (Accusative). Al-Kisa'i said to him: Be silent, what are you and this? It is permissible 'Ri'manu', 'Ri'mana', and 'Ri'mani' his nose, with Raf', Nasb, and Khafd. As for Raf', it is by returning to 'Ma' because it is in the place of Raf' by 'Yanfa'u', so the estimation becomes: Or how does affection of a nose benefit. Nasb is by 'Tu'ti'. Khafd is by returning to the Ha that is in 'Bi-hi'. He said: So Al-Asma'i fell silent, and he had no knowledge of Arabic (Grammar), but was a man of Language (Lexicography). The meaning of this verse: It is a proverb struck for one who promises you with his tongue every beautiful thing but does nothing of it because his heart contains the opposite. As if it was said to him: How does your beautiful speech benefit me if you do not fulfill it? Its origin is that the 'Aluq' is the she-camel that loses her calf by slaughter or death, so its skin is skinned and stuffed with straw or grass and presented to her so she accepts it (Tar'amuhu), i.e., inclines towards it and lets down her milk so she is benefited from. She sniffs it with her nose but her heart denies it, so she inclines towards it but does not release the milk. He likened this to that.

Ibn Duraid informed us from Al-Ukli from Abu Ubayda, he said: Alexander passed by a city that had been ruled by seven kings, all of whom perished along with their offspring. He asked: Did any of their offspring remain? They said: One man who shelters in the graveyards. He summoned him and said: What drove you to stick to the graves? He said: I wanted to separate the bones of kings from the bones of their slaves, but I found them equal. He said: Would you like to follow me so I can revive through you the honor of your days if you have ambition? He said: My ambition is indeed great if you have my desire. He said: And what is your desire? He said: A life with no death, a youth with no old age, and a joy with no dislike and no fear of poverty with it. He said: That is not up to me. He said: Then go about your business and let me seek it. Alexander said: This is the wisest person I have seen.

Ibn Rustam al-Tabari informed us, he said: I attended the session of Al-Mazini when it was said to him:

Why did you reduce your narration from Al-Asma'i? He said: I was accused in his view of Qadar (Free Will doctrine) and leaning towards the doctrines of the Mu'tazila. I came to him one day while he was in his session, and he said: What do you say about the saying of Allah Almighty (Inna kulla shay'in khalaqnahu bi-qadarin)? I said: Sibawayh holds that Raf' (Nominative) in it is stronger than Nasb (Accusative) in Arabic due to the verb being occupied with the pronoun, and there is nothing here that is more entitled to the verb. But the general reciters refused anything but Nasb, so we read it so following that because reading is a Sunnah. He said to me: So what is the difference between Raf' and Nasb in meaning? I knew his intent and feared he would incite the common people against me, so I said: Raf' is Inchoation (Mubtada) and Nasb is by implying a verb, and I feigned ignorance to him. He said: Our companions told me that Al-Farazdaq said one day to his companions: Come with us to the gathering of Al-Hasan Al-Basri, for I want to divorce Al-Nawar and make him witness against myself. They said: Do not do it, for perhaps your soul will follow her and you will regret. He said: It must be done. So they went with him. When he stood over Al-Hasan, he said: O Abu Sa'id, know that Al-Nawar is divorced thrice. He said: I have heard. Then his soul followed her after that and he regretted and recited saying:
(Wafir Meter)
I regretted the regret of Al-Kusa'i when ... Al-Nawar went from me divorced.
She was my Paradise, so I left it ... Like Adam when necessity expelled him.
And if I owned my hand and my soul ... The choice would have been mine against destiny.
Then he said: And the Arabs say: If I were given choice I would have chosen; bearing it on destiny. And they recite:
(Rajaz Meter)
It is the decrees, so blame me or leave ... If I erred, destiny did not err.
Then he put his sandals together and said: You are the mask for the Qadari. So I reduced my visits to him.

Al-Akhfash recited to us, he said: Tha'lab recited to us:
(Ramal Meter)
And how many things we buy with money ... So if they perish (nafaqat), they are the most stagnant (aksad) things to be.
He said: He means horses. 'Nashriha': We buy them. 'Nafaqat': Died.

Al-Yazidi informed us, he said: Abd al-Rahman bin akhi Al-Asma'i recited to us from his uncle:
(Kamil Meter)
They said: Be consoled, so I despaired, for you will not attain her ... Until the sweetness of the bitter tree (Al-Amr) becomes bitter.
We are not of the Muta'azzimin (those humbled by hard times) when ... The touchstone reveals the established poverty.
He says: You will not attain her until what cannot be happens. It is said: 'Amara ash-shay'u yamurru fahuwa mumirrun', and 'Marra mararatan fahuwa murrun'. 'Al-Muta'azzimun': Those humbling themselves to the difficulty of the year (famine). 'Al-Lamusan': When his lineage is touched, weakness is found in it, so he rejoices in the difficulty of time to desire and marry one who is nobler than him. So he says: We are not of those who do this and feign status by the severity of time.

Al-Zajjaj recited to us, he said: Al-Mubarrad recited to us by Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf:
(Kamil Meter)
O you who corresponds with me then changes his heart ... I will restrain myself before he becomes bored.
I will turn away from you while in my hand is a remnant ... Of the rope of your connection before it is cut.
O for hope! Like two lovers who agreed ... So we spoke without speaking.
Until when they feared eyes and were wary ... They made signaling with fingers a peace (greeting).

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim informed us, he said: Abu Ubayda informed us from Yunus bin Habib, he said: Mus'ab bin al-Zubayr killed Nabil bin Zabyan, one of Banu Aish bin Malik bin Qays bin Tha'labah. His brother Ubaydullah was a recluse, evil. He vowed to kill a hundred of Quraysh for him. He killed eighty, then killed Mus'ab. His head was brought to Abd al-Malik. When Abd al-Malik looked at him, he prostrated. He intended to kill him (Ubaydullah) treacherously, then refrained and recited:
(Tawil Meter)
I intended but did not do, and almost, and would that I ... Left Marwan's wives weeping over him.
He also said:
(Tawil Meter)
Mus'ab thinks I forgot what happened to me ... And by the life of Allah, it is not what Mus'ab thought.
By Allah, I will not forget him as long as a night star passes ... And as long as a star shines in the dark night.
He leaped upon him unjustly so I killed him ... So your rain from me on a day of evil is pouring.
I killed for him from the tribe of Fihr bin Malik ... Eighty, among them arrows (Nashibun) and gray-haired.
And sufficient for them is a pledge for twenty, or is seen ... Upon me with the morning wailing women wearing mourning clothes.
Do I raise my head in the midst of Bakr bin Wa'il ... And I did not quench my sword with blood pouring down?
Then Basra became narrow for him, so he fled to Oman and sought refuge with Sulayman bin Sa'id bin Al-Samr bin Sa'id Al-Julandi. When he was informed of his treachery, he feared and blamed himself to kill him publicly. So he sent him half a melon which he had poisoned, as he liked melon. He said to him: This is the first thing we saw of melon, and I ate half of it, and gifted you half of it. When he ate it, he sensed death. Then Sulayman entered upon him to visit him. He said: O Emir, come close to me so I may confide a saying to you. He said to him: Say what appears to you. He said: Upon you regarding Oman is a conscious ear (Wa'iyah). It is narrated: Caring (Ra'iyah). So he died there.

Abu al-Qasim al-Zajjaji informed us: 'An-Nuh' is the plural of 'Na'ihah' (wailing woman), and it is a verbal noun 'Yanuhu' used for singular, dual, plural, masculine, and feminine with one wording, as it is said: 'Qawm Rida' and 'Adl' and 'Sawm', and 'Niswah Rida' and 'Sawm' and 'Adl'. 'As-Salab': Those who wore 'Al-Silabah' which is black clothes. He brought out its verb for emphasis carried on the wording of 'Nuh'. The poet said:
(Kamil Meter)
Do my camels scratch their faces over me ... Or bind their heads with mourning clothes (Silab)?

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: It is said: 'La'ibtu' and 'La'abtu', two dialects. And it is said: 'Abithtu a'bathu', the past is 'Al-Abath' like 'Alimtu a'lamu'. And 'Abathtu a'bathu' from 'Al-Abithah' which is a type of 'Aqit' meaning milk. He said: And it is said: 'Sharata al-hajjamu yashritu' and 'Ashrata', and in other than it 'Yashritu' only. He said: 'Al-Qadd': Cutting lengthwise, and 'Al-Qatt': Cutting crosswise. It is narrated about Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, that if he rose over a man he 'Qaddahu' (cut lengthwise), and if he intercepted him he 'Qattahu' (cut crosswise).

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab from Al-Riyashi from Al-Asma'i, he said: The Ravens of the Arabs (Aghrabat al-Arab - black poets) are three: Khufaf bin Nadbah al-Sulami, and Nadbah is his mother, she was a black Abyssinian woman from Banu al-Harith bin Ka'b, and his father was Umayr bin al-Harith bin Amr bin al-Sharid. And Sulayk bin al-Sulakah is his mother, and his father was Yathrabi bin Sayyar. And Antara bin Muawiyah al-Absi. He said: I have not narrated poetry softer than the saying of Khufaf:
(Tawil Meter)
Asma' did not knock (visit in dream) without a cause ... And indeed, if she settles in Najran, we meet.
With a reveal (Bi-bawhin), and what is my mind with a reveal and her mind ... And whoever meets one day the confusion of love palpitates.

Al-Husayn bin Isma'il al-Mahamili told us, he said: Abu Hashim Ziyad bin Ayyub al-Tusi told us, he said: Sa'id bin Muhammad al-Warraq told us from Bassam bin Ikrimah from Ibn Abbas, he said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade the milk of the 'Jallalah', the dowry of the prostitute, and the price of the dog.
Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Jallalah': The camel that eats dung. The origin of 'Al-Jallalah' is dung (Ba'r). It is said: The slave girls went out 'Yajtalilna' (collecting dung). 'Al-Bigha'': The immoral woman. 'Al-Bigha'': Adultery. Allah Almighty said: (And do not compel your slave girls to prostitution (Al-Bigha')). 'Al-Baghy' in other than this verse is the slave girl. 'Al-Baghiah': The scout (Rabi'ah), who is the vanguard for the people. Al-Asma'i recited:
(Tawil Meter)
And there was behind the people a scout (Baghiah) from them ... So he ascended a high place from afar and announced.

Isma'il al-Warraq told us, he said: Al-Husayn bin Muhammad told us, he said: Shamah bin Suwar told us, he said: Furat bin al-Sa'ib told us from Maymun bin Mahran from Ibn Umar, he said: The first to enter upon Umar when he was struck were Ali and Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them. When Ibn Abbas looked at him, he wept and said: Rejoice with Paradise, O Commander of the Faithful. He said: Are you a witness for me of that? He seemed to hesitate, so Ali struck him and said: Yes, bear witness for him, and I am of the witnesses to that. Umar said: How? Ibn Abbas said: Your Islam was glory, your rule was justice, and your death is martyrdom. He said: No, by Allah, do not console me from my Lord and my religion - or he said religion, Al-Za'farani doubted - Umar's mother be bereaved of him if his Lord does not forgive him.
It is said: 'Ka'a 'an al-amr fahuwa ka'i'': If he hesitated from it out of cowardice and fear. As for 'Al-'Akk': Intensity of heat. It is said: 'Yawm 'Akk wa 'Akik', and 'Akk wa Akik': If it is intensely hot. 'Al-'Ukwak' among men: The short, strong of build. 'Al-'Akanka'': Male of the ghouls (Sa'ali). Al-Khalil recited:
(Split Rajaz Meter)
A ghoul disputing with a wicked Akanka'.

Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi, he said: It is said for the turban: It is 'Al-Imamah', 'Al-Mishwadh', 'As-Sib', 'Al-Muqatta'ah', 'Al-Isabah', 'Al-Isab', 'At-Taj', and 'Al-Iqti'az' which is for a man to turban himself without passing it under the chin (Tahannuk). In the Hadith, he forbade 'Al-Iqti'az' and ordered 'At-Talahhi' (Tahannuk). He also mentioned that he said: The man came 'Mutakhattiman' i.e., turbaned, and how beautiful is his 'Takhattum' i.e., his turbaning. This is a word no one narrated except Ibn al-A'rabi.

Al-Akhfash recited to us, he said: Al-Mubarrad recited to us:
(Majzu' al-Kamil Meter)
Man hopes to live, and length of life harms him.
His cheerfulness vanishes and remains, after the sweet of life, its bitter.
And days betray him until he sees nothing that pleases him.
How many a gloater over me if I perish, and sayer: To Allah is his goodness (derision/praise depending on context).

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us, he said: Al-Riyashi informed us, he said: Abd al-Qahir bin al-Sari informed us, he said: Qutayba bin Muslim obtained a shirt woven with pearls, so he sent it to Al-Hajjaj, who sent it to Al-Walid. Then Al-Hajjaj's soul followed it (desired it), so he wrote to Qutayba: As for what follows, we had sent what you sent to us to Al-Walid, and I reckon you have kept the like of it with you for your wives and daughters, so prefer us with what is with you of it. So he wrote to him: "That I eat carrion, blood, pig meat, and what was dedicated to other than Allah is dearer to me than that I withhold a valuable thing ('Alaq) from you." So he wrote to him: That is the opinion of you.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Ishaq bin Muhammad told us, he said: Al-Hasan bin Muhammad told us from Shayban from Qatada regarding the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic (And whatever strikes you of disaster - it is for what your hands have earned; but He pardons much). He said: It was mentioned to us that the Prophet of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: No scratch of a stick strikes the son of Adam, nor a stumble of a foot, nor a twitch of a vein, except due to a sin, and what Allah pardons is more. And with his chain from Qatada (And do not be like she who untwisted her spun thread... the verse). He said: This is a parable Allah struck for one who breaks his covenant. He says: If you heard of a woman who untwisted her spun thread after twisting it firmly, would you not say: How foolish is this one? What others besides Qatada go to is that they were forbidden from disbelief after Islam so they wouldn't be like she who untwisted her spun thread after twisting it firmly. The singular of 'Ankath' is 'Nikth': It is what is untwisted from tents and clothes to be spun a second time and returned with the new.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Ishaq bin Muhammad told us from Al-Hasan from Muhammad from Shayban, he said from Qatada regarding the saying of Allah Almighty (Perhaps you would kill yourself (Bakhi'un nafsaka)). He said: Killer of yourself. Niftawayh said: Tha'lab said: It is said: 'Bakha'a Fulanun Fulanan': If he killed him. 'Bakha'a bi-hi': If he exaggerated in blaming him. 'Bakha'a Fulanun wa Jatha'a': If he humiliated himself and submitted. It is recited for Dhu al-Rumma:
(Tawil Meter)
O you who kills himself (Al-Bakhi'u) with grief ... For a thing fates have carved from his hands.

Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin Malit al-Nahwi al-Darir informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed me from Umar bin Shabbah, he said: Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan had a spy in the lands of the Romans. He said: So he wrote to him: That this tyrant said in his assembly that this is a time to eradicate the Arabs because they have differed. So Muawiyah wrote a letter to him swearing to him and saying: If you resolve on what you showed in your assembly, I will surely reconcile with my companion (Ali) and I will surely be his vanguard against you, so I will make you descend the Constantinople of the Jaramiqah and I will return you to being a farmer (Arlasiyyan) as you used to herd piglets (Khananis). The King of the Romans wrote to him swearing to him by innocence from baptism and entering into Hanifiyyah (Islam) that he did not intend this nor spoke it, and he gifted him many gifts, most of which was 'Al-Yuzbun' (hyssop?). With Damma on Ya, and Kasra is wrong. It is narrated from Tha'lab that he said: 'Al-Arlas': The Akadir (farmers/peasants). I reckon it is not Arabic and perhaps it is in the language of the people. 'Al-Khananis': Piglets, singular 'Khannus'.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us from Al-Mazini from Al-Asma'i, he said: Buthayna was nicknamed Umm Abd al-Malik. When Jamil's fame with her and his passion for her increased and their matter escalated, her family threatened him and menaced him, and swore that if they caught him they would kill him. So he said regarding that:
(Rajaz Meter)
O Umm Abd al-Malik, cut me off ... So clarify my cutting off or connect me.
Indeed the sons of your uncle threatened me ... That they would kill me, then they would not pay blood money for me.
Lo, by the Lord of the House, if they met me ... Paired and odd, they would have feared me.
The enemies have known that before me ... Is a striking like the driving of the black pregnant camels.
Then he went out to Egypt and died there. When death approached him, he recited saying:
(Kamil Meter)
The announcer of death came early and did not use a kunya for Jamil ... And he stayed in Egypt a stay with no return.
Rise, Buthayna, and mourn with wailing ... And weep for your friend above every friend.
And indeed I dragged the garment in Wadi al-Qura ... Intoxicated among farms and palms.
When these verses reached Buthayna, she said two verses, and she had never said poetry before them nor after them other than them, and they are:
(Tawil Meter)
It is equal to us, O Jamil bin Ma'mar ... When you die, the hardships of life and its softness.
And indeed my silence regarding Jamil for an hour ... Of time has not come nor has its time arrived.

Al-Akhfash recited to us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi:
(Wafir Meter)
Is she weeping, afflicted, if an announcer comes to her ... Or will she have patience?
When the people of affection bid me farewell ... And departed with dust on their palms.
Leave him and my bones in the niche of a grave ... Exchanged by side winds and rain.
The wind blows around the station of my grave ... And the white wild bull (Al-Lahaq al-Nawar) grazes around it.
Distance, not abandonment, removed a year ... And a year, then the abodes will gather.
'Al-Lahaq al-Nawar': The white wild animal. It is said for a white thing: It is 'Lahaq', 'Luhwaq', and 'Luhaq'. He said: If the whiteness of a human intensifies until he looks like a leper, it is said: He is 'Amhaq' and 'Amhaq'.
Niftawayh recited to us for Dhu al-Ruqqah:
(Wafir Meter)
When in a stark white (Amhaq) desert fluttered ... The heads of the people and they committed to departure.
He said: 'Al-Amhaq': The white land, intensely white with no plants.

Al-Akhfash informed us from Tha'lab, he said: Al-Riyashi informed us, he said: Abu Amr al-Razi informed us from Abu Sahl from Muhammad bin Salim, he said: Yahya bin Ya'mar was brought to Al-Hajjaj in his shackles. He said to him: Are you the one who claims that Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn are the sons of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him? You will bring me it from the Book of Allah or I will cut off your hands and feet. He said: I will bring you it from the Book of Allah Almighty. Then he recited: (And of his descendants, David and Solomon and Job and Joseph and Moses and Aaron. Thus do We reward the doers of good. And Zechariah and John and Jesus). So He made Jesus of his descendants, and he has no father.

Abd al-Aziz bin Ali bin al-Muntasir recited to us, he said: Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz recited to me for himself:
(Kamil Meter)
My heart wanders in the beauty of his image ... Where sickness is by the glance of his eye.
As if the scorpion of his temple (curl) stood ... When it approached the fire of his cheek.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim and Abd al-Rahman bin akhi Al-Asma'i both informed us from Al-Asma'i, he said: I was on a journey, and in one of the resting places a boy stood over us and said: Which of you is a man from the people of Basra? We said to him: What do you want from him? He said: Indeed my master is dying from what is in him, and he wants to entrust his will to him. So I got up with him, and behold, it was Al-Abbas bin al-Ahnaf, breathing his last, having thrown himself on wet mud. I sat at his head, so he raised his glance to me. When he recognized me, he recited saying:
(Madid Meter)
O one far from home, away from his homeland ... Alone weeping over his sorrow.
Whenever the escape became serious with him ... Illnesses became serious in his body.
Then he fainted, and did not wake up except by the sound of a turtledove on the branch of a tree near him. So he recited saying:
(Madid Meter)
And indeed, the heart increased in sadness ... The voice of a turtledove on its branch.
It was afflicted by what afflicted me, so it wept ... Each of us weeping over his dwelling.
Then he passed away, so I took charge of his funeral preparations.

Al-Zajjaj recited to us from Al-Mubarrad:
(Tawil Meter)
So we spent the night just above the tribe, we were not of them ... And we were not mixed with the enemies.
And we spent the night shielding against the falling dew and moisture ... Of the night, a garment whose lining was tar.
We ransom with the remembrance of Allah in the essence of His House ... When a wandering heart was [smitten] by a Jinan (garden/shield/madness?).
And we return from the attire of chastity, and perhaps ... We quenched the burning of longing with sipping.
Abu al-Abbas said: He took the meanings of these verses from the saying of Imru' al-Qays:
I sent to her while the stars were setting ... Fearing for her that she might rise and hear.
So she came, slow of walk, fearing the night travel ... Her corners pushing four buxom maidens.
They drive her, the walk of the drained one, and the dregs ... Of sleep had run in her brain so it was cut.
She says, and I had stripped her of her clothes ... Concealing what the kohl-eyed, long-necked one grazes.
By your grandfather, if anything came to us as his messenger ... Other than you, but we found no repulsion for you.
Then we would have returned him, even if his stay was long ... With us, but we are fond of your love.
So we spent the night repelling the wild beasts from us as if we were ... Two slain ones whose death place the people did not know.
If the tremor of fear seized her, she held on ... To the shoulder of a bold one, fearless in terror.

Abu Abdullah al-Yazidi informed us, he said: Al-Yazidi informed us from Al-Asma'i from Abdullah bin Ru'ba bin al-Ajjaj from his father from his grandfather, he said: I recited to Abu Hurayrah my poem which begins:
(Rajaz Meter)
Praise be to Allah, by whose permission the sky rose ... And by whose permission the earth settled, so it did not suffer.
And He extended it with anchors (mountains), fixed ... And revealed to it the settlement, so it settled.
Until I reached its end, he said: I bear witness that you are a believer.

Abu Abdullah al-Akhfash and Al-Yazidi informed us, they said: Tha'lab told us from Al-Riyashi from Al-Asma'i, he said: Nafi' bin Abi Nu'aym told me, he said: Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf said to Nafi' bin Jubayr: Strike the neck of this man who is before him (me?). He said: Indeed my hand is 'Tabaqah'. He said: Then leave us. So he left, and a messenger followed him with two hundred dinars saying: The Emir says to you, seek help with this in your journey.
Al-Asma'i said: It is said a hand is 'Tabaqah' and 'Tabiqah': If it sticks to the pocket (side) and does not strike.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Ibn Mu'adh Khalaf bin Ahmar told us from Dummad bin Rafi' from Abu Ubayda Ma'mar bin al-Muthanna, he said: Yazid bin al-Hakam al-Thaqafi arrived from Ta'if to Al-Hajjaj in Iraq, and he was a noble poet. So he appointed him over Fars. When he came to take his covenant (appointment), he said to him: O Yazid, recite to us from your poetry. So he recited saying:
(Wafir Meter)
And whoever asks about me, then I ... Am the son of the hunters (lions/nobles) from my ancestors of Thaqif.
And in the middle of the valleys is the place of my house ... The place of the lion in the middle of the thicket.

And in Ka'b, and who is like the tribe Ka'b ... I settled in the peak of lofty glory.
I loved its pride, lowland and highland ... And that is the utmost honor of the noble.
Every proud one traced my lineage, neither weak ... To carry burdens, nor violent.
Al-Hajjaj was struck dumb and lowered his head for a while, then raised his head and said: Praise be to Allah, I praise Him and thank Him that a time has not come except that the most poetic of Arabs is among us. Then he said: Recite to us, O Yazid. So he recited saying:
(Kamil Meter)
By my father who conquered the lands with his sword ... And humbled the past sons of time to it.
And by my father who stripped the son of Kisra of a banner ... In the kingdom, flapping like the flying eagle.
And if I boast, I boast not denied ... A boast by which I crush the boast of the boaster.
Al-Hajjaj stood up angry and entered the palace. Yazid left with the covenant in his hand. Al-Hajjaj said to his servant: Follow him and tell him: Return our covenant to us. If you take it, say to him: Did your father bequeath you the like of this? The servant did so and conveyed the message. He returned the covenant to him and said: Say to Al-Hajjaj: My father bequeathed to me his glory and deeds, and your father bequeathed to you goats in Ta'if to herd. Then he traveled under the night and joined Sulayman (bin Abd al-Malik), who was the Crown Prince. He joined him to himself and made him part of his entourage. He said praising Sulayman:
(Basit Meter)
If the beautiful women walk away from me turning aside ... Then you see them leaning towards us, craning their necks (Sayda).
And if we were heedless of their appointments ... Then our appointment with them might be a feast (Eid).
We all meet, distracted with his companion ... And we do not fear refutation from the blamers.
Say to youth when gray hair chases it ... Do not distance the chased one of gray hair, chased.
Whoever accompanies gray hair, it hates him and drags for him ... Slapping to the hands and chaining to the legs.
O most rejecting of people for the world and its pleasure ... Most intense of them in asceticism in it and making others ascetic.
If people have become stagnant (in market) ... Then piety and righteousness have become present with you.
If they envy you, then how many righteous ones have they envied ... This is the Prophet of Guidance, he was envied.
The wicked ones who opposed you from Kalb bit ... The rocks and the hard deaf stones (Sayahid).
You were named the name of a man whose character you resembled ... In justice and virtue, Solomon son of David.
Praise him, there was a king among the past ones ... And you have become praised among the remaining ones.

Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Gharif': The thicket, and likewise 'Al-Ghabah', 'Al-Khis', and 'Al-Qabil'. 'Al-Gharaf': A tree used for tanning. 'Al-Mu'dilat': Plural of 'Mu'dilah', which are difficult matters. From it 'Addalat al-mar'ah': If her child got stuck during birth and did not come out. 'Addala ar-rajul ibnatahu': If he prevented her from marrying. 'Al-'Udal': The severe disease with no cure. 'Al-Munif': The overlooking/high. 'Al-'Anif': Opposite of gentle. His saying: 'Tarahunna suwaran nahwana': It is the plural of 'Aswar' and 'Sur': i.e., leaning towards us, from your saying 'Saraftu ash-shay'': If you bent it and inclined it. 'As-Sid': Plural of 'Asyad' and 'Sayda'', which are those tilting their necks out of pride. Its origin is from 'As-Sayad': A disease in the camel's neck tilting it to a side. 'Al-Akhashib': Plural of 'Akhshab', which is the thick mountain. 'As-Salb': Whetstones.

Al-Akhfash recited to us by Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
(Khafif Meter)
A magician of the eyes, showed avoidance ... Allah crafted him in beauty, unique.
A lover called to my heart by breaking his eyelids ... The soul found no escape from his separation.
May Allah have mercy on one who wept, infatuated ... It is not decreed for his heart to be returned.
He spends the night wailing over one who ... Grew roses of beauty upon his cheeks.

Ibn al-Anbari recited to us by Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
(Basit Meter)
May Allah not give sleep to the one who gifted me sleeplessness ... And deposited the fire of love in the heart, so it burned.
A full moon exposed himself to me deliberately to kill me ... His lights drive away the dusk from his face.
Varying in him from parting (of hair) to foot ... Are novel beauties that arrest the eyes.
So how many a mind was bewildered and how many a look ... In him, and how many a heart strayed and how many throbbed.
O inheritor of sickness to my body after its health ... Hasten my release or catch the last breath.
Longing, since you were hidden from my sight, has not left ... A character for me in patience nor a creation.
And creation erased a promise I was hoping for ... And my despair blocked the roads against my hopes.
I was not the first servant raising his hand ... Seeking sustenance of his master's sympathy, but was not provided.
Indeed I envy a cup when he kisses it ... Until it becomes warm, embraced by the lips.

Pushing his sleeve in a walk playfully ... He does not fear rage or anger for my blood.
He turned a curl on his cheek adorning it ... And they earned his collar a ring from his hair.

Issue in the Quran
The saying of the Mighty and Majestic: (Then We will surely extract from every sect which of them (Ayyuhum) is most intense against the Most Merciful in insolence). There are six opinions in it, three for the Basrans and three for the Kufans.
Sibawayh said: 'Ayyuhum' here is in the interpretation of 'Alladhi' (who), and it is in the place of Nasb (Accusative) by the occurrence of extraction (Naz') upon it, but it is built on Damma because it is connected with a single name (Mufrad - as predicate without the copula 'huwa'). If it were connected with a sentence, it would be declinable. 'Ashaddu' is the predicate of a hidden inchoative (Mubtada) estimated as 'huwa ashaddu'. 'Itiyyan' is accusative as specification (Tamyiz). If the Mubtada were shown, 'Ayy' would be installed (Accusative) and it would be said: 'La-nanza'anna min kulli shi'atin ayyahum huwa ashaddu'.
Al-Khalil said: This is based on imitation (Hikayah), as if it was said to them: 'We will surely extract from every sect the one who it is said they are most intense.' Sibawayh said this is wrong and compelled him to allow 'La-adribanna al-fasiqu al-khabithu' (I will surely strike the corrupt the wicked - Nominative) on the estimation 'I will surely strike the one who it is said he is the wicked.'
Yunus said: The verb is nullified (Mulgha) and 'Ayy' is raised by inchoation and 'Ashaddu' is its predicate, as it is said 'Alimtu ayyuhum 'indaka' (I knew which of them is with you). Sibawayh said: This is also wrong because only verbs of doubt and certainty like 'Zhanantu' and 'Alimtu' and their category can be nullified. And it is as he said.
Al-Farra' said: 'Then We will surely extract from every sect which of them is most intense.' i.e., We will surely extract by calling, so they will be called by 'which of them is most intense.' He has another opinion in this, which is that he said: It is possible that the saying falls on the place of 'Man ashaddu'. He has a third opinion in it, he said: It is possible that its meaning is 'Then We will surely extract from those who followed each other and supported each other by following, which of them is most intense,' so 'Ayy' would be in the connection of the following (Tashayu').
Abu al-Qasim said: The best of these opinions is Sibawayh's opinion, and the other opinion from Al-Farra' which we ended the issue with.

Issue of Connections (Silat)
Know that 'Alladhi', 'Man', 'Ma', 'Ayy', and Alif-Lam are incomplete nouns in the report that are not complete except with a connection (Silah) and a returner (A'id), and on other than definite, except 'Ayy' alone which is declinable. These nouns were not declinable because they are incomplete, not complete except with a connection and returner, so they became like some letters of the noun, and parts of letters do not deserve inflection; rather the noun deserves inflection in its entirety. Also, when they became ambiguous, they resembled in their ambiguity the particles of meaning indicative of what they were placed for with common indication. When these nouns resembled particles, they were not inflected due to their resemblance to what is not inflected like it. If you dualize 'Alladhi' alone, you inflect it and say: 'Al-ladhani fi ad-dar akhawaka', and 'Marartu bi-alladhayni 'indaka'. It was only inflected in the dual because it separated from particles of meaning, because particles of meaning are not dualized or pluralized. Therefore, all indeclinable nouns that allow dualization become declinable if dualized. If you pluralize 'Alladhi', among the Arabs are those who use the singular form for the plural and do not inflect it, saying: 'Alladhi fi ad-dar az-Zayduna'. Allah Almighty said: (And the one who brought the truth and [those who] believed in it - those are the righteous) and He said: (Their example is like the example of the one who kindled a fire; then when it illuminated what was around him, Allah took away their light). Some of them make it in the plural form and do not inflect it, saying: 'Ra'aytu alladhina 'indaka', and 'Ja'ani alladhina 'indaka', saying it is a plural on the pattern of the dual, so it became like a single noun applying to the plural, so it was not inflected. Some of them inflect it and make it a sound plural, saying: 'Ja'ani alladhuna 'indaka', and 'Marartu bi-alladhina 'indaka', and 'Ra'aytu alladhina 'indaka'. The poet said in this dialect:
(Kamil Meter)
And Banu Nuwayjiyah, those who (Alladhuna) are like ... Striped coats pierced from the Khazzan.
If it is said: Why is 'Ayy' inflected in the report while it is an incomplete noun needing a connection and returner as 'Alladhi' and its sisters need, and 'Alladhi' and its sisters were not inflected? The answer is: 'Ayy' is a noun that became empowered by addition (Idafa) so it was inflected because its meaning is not understood except by what it is added to. What it was added to brought it out by addition to empowerment, so it was inflected. Do you not see that 'Amsi' (yesterday) is built on Kasra, but if you add it, you inflect it and say: 'Mada amsuka bi-ma fihi' (Your yesterday passed with what was in it), and 'Qad kana amsuna atyaba min yawmina'. Similarly 'Ayy', when added, became empowered and inflected, then it was singularized, so its singular was carried on that and inflected because inflection was established in it before its singularization.
If he says: Why were 'Alladhi', 'Man', 'Ma', and the rest of the incomplete nouns not added? The answer is: 'Alladhi' is defined by Alif-Lam, and addition does not combine with it. 'Man' and 'Ma' are more ambiguous than 'Alladhi' because they can be interrogative resembling the interrogative Alif, and conditional resembling the conditional particle, so they became like 'Huwa' in ambiguity compared to 'Ayy', so their addition was not permissible. Therefore, they were not dualized, pluralized, or feminized as was done with 'Alladhi'. So know that.

Ibn al-Anbari informed us, he said: Al-Khattali informed us, he said: Abu Ya'la al-Saji told us, he said: Al-Asma'i told us, he said: Sufyan bin Uyaynah told us, he said: Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The command of Allah is not established except by one who does not flatter (Yusani'), nor show weakness (Yudari'), nor follow greed.
His saying 'Yudari'': From 'Dhara'ah' which is weakness. It is said: 'Dhari'a ar-rajulu yadhra'u dhar'an wa dhara'atan': If he became weak. A man 'Dhari'', a people 'Dhari'', and women likewise. 'Ad-Dar'': Also the young animal. 'Al-Mudara'ah' in other than this: Resemblance. Al-Zajjaj said: Its derivation is from 'Ad-Dar'' (udder). It is said 'Tadara'a al-fasilani': If they drank from one udder, which is 'Al-Khilf'. This is metaphorical.

Ibn al-Anbari informed us, he said: Al-Khattali informed us from Abu Ya'la from Al-Asma'i, he said: Sufyan bin Uyaynah told us, Ali, peace be upon him, said: If you learn knowledge, then restrain it (Akzhimu 'alayhi) and do not mix it with play or jest, lest hearts reject it.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: My uncle Al-Husayn bin Duraid informed us from his father, he said: Hisham bin Muhammad al-Kalbi told us from his father Al-Kalbi and from Abu Miskin and from Abd al-Rahman bin al-Mu'arra Abu Husayn Zuhair al-Dawsi, he said: Hamamah bin Rafi' bin al-Harith al-Dawsi was one of the most beautiful of Arabs. He had a lock of hair called 'Al-Ratbah'. He used to wash it with water, then it would absorb it, retaining the water. When two days passed, he would untie it then undo it, and it would fill a sitting mat with water. He performed Hajj on a horse of his with a long tail. Al-Hamamah al-Kinaniyyah, who is Khunas, looked at him, and she was one of the most beautiful women, so he fell into her heart. She was married to a man from Kinanah called Ibn al-Humaris al-Kinani. She said to Hamamah: Who are you? By Allah, I do not know if your face is more beautiful, or your hair, or your horse. You are not the disheveled Najdi nor the dirty Tihami, and you have fallen into my soul, so tell me the truth? He said: I am a man from Azd then from Daws, and my home is in Tharuq. She said: Then you are the most beloved of people to me, so carry me with you. So he put her behind him and went with her to his family. When he brought her to his land, he said to them: You have known how your proximity was with me, and by Allah, you will not approach a man after me. So he cut her hamstrings (disabled her from marrying/leaving?), and she stayed with him. She bore Amr bin Hamamah, and he was a generous master. Amr begot Dhu al-Nur who came as a delegate to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and asked him for a sign to be for him to return to his people and call them to faith. He was given a light between his eyes like a shining lamp. He said: O Allah, in other than my face. Lest my people think it is a mutilation for leaving their religion. So He placed that light in the tip of his whip, in a long Hadith. So he was named Dhu al-Nur for that.
Ibn al-Humaris went out seeking his wife Khunas but could not find her, and he recited saying:
(Wafir Meter)
Lo, greet Al-Khunas despite her hatred ... And even if she has gone far and her distance is remote.
She exchanged the watermelon and the land of Daws ... For Jumlat Faris, whose peaks are protected.
And I was informed she hungered and was humiliated ... And that the free woman is from a mountain that leveled her.
And I was informed she sifted a caravan ... And flowers whose thorns were stripped.
And I was informed she gave birth to a boy ... So may the boy not survive nor give her joy.
When Umar bin al-Khattab recited this poetry, he said: By Allah, the boy survived and gave her joy.

Al-Akhfash recited to us, he said: Tha'lab recited to us, he said: Ibn al-A'rabi recited to us:
(Basit Meter)
Like the tick (Baram), he appeared in a worn shirt ... Not shaving his pubes, while the causes of death cover him.
So I returned from him with a herd of camels for a widow ... And a miserable one whose meaning came like his meaning.
Ibn al-A'rabi said: describing a beggar. He said: He is like the 'Baram', meaning the tick (Qurad), likened to it for his skinniness and slenderness. It is said: It is 'Al-Qurad', 'Al-Baram', 'At-Tammah', 'Al-'All', 'Al-Qirsham', 'Al-Hajn', 'Al-Hamnah', 'Al-Hamnanah', and 'Al-Hashdal'. The Lam is extra. He said: From it is 'Al-Hasad' (Envy), as if envy sticks to the human heart as the tick sticks to the camel's skin and sucks it. He said: As for his saying "Ghada fi asdati khalaqin", 'Al-Asdah' is 'As-Sadrah' (vest/shirt). It is said: It is 'As-Sadrah', 'Al-Asrah', 'Al-Mijwal', 'Al-Baqir', 'Al-Khay'al', 'Al-Fad'ah', 'Al-'Alaqah', and 'Al-Itb', all with one meaning. His saying "Lam yasta'in": Did not shave his pubic hair. "Hawami al-mawt": Its causes, originally 'Hawa'im' then inverted. "Bi-sara'ayna": Many camels differing in walk due to their number. 'Al-Mashy' is plural of 'Mashyah'.

Niftawayh recited to us:
(Tawil Meter)
If the messenger came to me announcing her death ... I secluded myself where I was on the earth.
And I weep for myself out of mercy for her weeping ... And some of me weeps over some due to abandonment.
And indeed I love her despite her bad action ... And I decree upon myself regarding her with what I decree.
So until when will the spirit of passion not reach me ... And until when will the days of your anger not pass?

Al-Zajjaj informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us from Al-Mazini, he said: A man told me from Al-Asma'i, and I did not hear it from him myself, he said: Khalaf al-Ahmar told us: Kuthayyir bin Harasah, a man from Banu Kilab who used to exaggerate in his speech, said: Indeed among people are those who disdain you if you honor them and belittle you if you increase them (in honor). There is no place for their satisfaction that you know, nor a location for their anger that you beware. So if you know them or blame them (?) [Correction: If you know their vileness (Awlamahum - doubtful reading) / If you know them, blame them?], then offer them the place of affection and deny them the place of privacy. What you offered them of affection will be a barrier against their evil, and what you denied them of privacy will be cutting off their sanctity (intimacy).

Abu Abdullah al-Yazidi recited to us for his uncle:
(Munsarih Meter)
Do not humiliate your honor for the friend you honor ... Until you are counted among his servants.
He loads his burdens upon you just as ... He loads his burdens upon his camel.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us, he said: Ishaq al-Mawsili wrote to Arib al-Ma'muniyyah:
(Tawil Meter)
Fear Allah regarding one whose heart you have captivated ... And hid it so it is as if he is bewitched.
Observe the promise/covenant (An-Najd - or Al-Majd?), I do not hear of your day, rather ... I asked you for something whose back is not bare to you.
He said: She signed the note: You spoke the truth, may I be your ransom, its back is not bare to us, but it fills a belly of ours.

Ibn Duraid recited to us for himself mocking a rich man:
(Rajaz Meter)
O scholar whose article is unknown ... But what he says is carried.
If interpretation and revelation missed you ... Simile and representation did not miss you.
An issue Al-Khalil neglected ... In which the object raises the subject.
And he sees the genitive lengthening ... And hides the Wafir and Tawil (meters).
Its prosody is 'Mufta'ilun', you say ... For it 'Mustalahun Ma'mul'.

Al-Yazidi recited to us, he said: Al-Riyashi recited to us:
(Tawil Meter)
And when we finished every rite at Mina ... And whoever wipes rubbed the corners.
We took to the edges of conversations between us ... And the broad valleys flowed with the necks of the mounts.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Al-Husayn bin Ishaq bin Ishaq bin al-Hasan informed us, he said: Al-Husayn bin Muhammad told us from Shayban from Qatada regarding the Almighty's saying: (Wa 'indahum qasirat at-tarf) (And with them are women limiting their glances). i.e., restraining the glance from looking at other than their husbands. 'Al-Qasr' is also: The evening, which is 'Al-Qasr' then 'Al-Qasar', and after it 'At-Tifl'. 'Tafalat ash-shamsu': If it approached setting. After it is 'Al-Junuh', which is when it inclines in the horizon of the west. It is said: 'Qasruka an taf'ala kadha', 'Qasaruka', 'Qasraka', and 'Qasarak'.

Niftawayh informed us, he said: Ishaq bin al-Hasan told us from Al-Husayn bin Muhammad from Shayban from Qatada regarding the Almighty's saying: (And is this a favor of which you remind me - that you have enslaved the Children of Israel?). He said: Moses, peace be upon him, said to Pharaoh when he enumerated his upbringing and being with him: Do you remind me of favor because you took the Children of Israel as slaves while they were free people? It is said: 'Abbadtu ar-rajula' with Shadda on Ba, and 'A'badtuhu': If you took him as a slave and placed him in the status of slaves. The poet said:
(Basit Meter)
Why does my people enslave me when there are many ... Camels among them, whatever they wish, and slaves?
'An-Ni'mah' with Kasra on Nun: The hand (favor). 'An-Na'am' with Fatha on the first: Prosperity. It is said: 'Manna Fulanun 'ala Fulan': If he did him a favor and was good to him. 'Manna Fulanun 'ala Fulan': If he reminded him of his favor and kindness and reproached him with it. From it is said: The bane of kindness is 'Al-Mann' meaning reminding. They said regarding the Almighty's saying (Wa la tamnun tastakthir): Do not give to take more than what you give, and let your giving be for Allah Almighty.

Al-Akhfash informed us, he said: Tha'lab informed us from Al-Riyashi, he said: Abu Salamah al-Ghafari told us, he said: Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Uthman bin Affan said to me: Our mother Fatima bint al-Husayn bin Ali gathered us and said: O my sons, by Allah, the people of foolishness have not said anything in their pleasures with foolishness except that the people of chivalry have said the like of it or more with their chivalry, so cover yourselves with the covering of Allah.

Al-Yazidi informed us from his uncle Abu al-Qasim Ubaydullah bin Muhammad, he said: Salm al-Khasir entered upon Al-Fadl bin al-Rabi'. When he stood before him, he recited saying:
(Mujtath Meter)
He sleeps who does not stay awake ... Would that this morning would shine.
Is this not strange ... I die at times and am resurrected?
A resurrection every day ... For a youth who is not gathered.
Allah is my sufficiency and Fadl ... So I do not fear nor dread.
Fadl has hands with me ... And a favor not to be denied.
If my praise is much ... Then Fadl's giving is more.
He said: Ask your need. He said: Connect me to the Commander of the Faithful, Al-Rashid. He said: I will. And he ordered him five hundred dinars. He was to ride to the House (Palace), so he was carried with him. When he entered upon the Caliph and people took their seats, he said to some servants:

Bring in Salm. When he entered, Al-Rashid asked permission to recite, and he permitted him. He said:
(Majzu' al-Ramal Meter)
Let us hear or inform us ... O dwellings of the departing ones.
Indeed my heart is a hostage to you ... For that which you know.
The days called out in it ... With decay until we decayed.
How often we trod amusement in the house ... Types and arts.
Of gazelles, their buttocks ... Attract the backs (riders).
Heavy ones, swaying in it ... Houris and wide-eyed.
Flashes of longing from it ... Resurrection the buried disease.
He won in intimacy, a lover ... Who was stingy with intimacy.
The more I increased in distance ... He increased in love, fascination.
She left in my heart ... Burns that do not end.
There is no resting place for sleep ... In the eyes of lovers.
The sea of love became a flood ... After we waded it for a time.
Indeed Abdullah Harun ... Is the Commander of the Faithful.
A king who spread his gifts ... Left and right.
Indeed, to Allah is a guardian gathering ... World and religion.
He gives the world but ... Prevents the protected religion.
A king who became, to what was mighty ... Of the world, humiliating.
You are the best of people living ... And the son of the best of those gone.
Many a day for deaths ... We meet, red and black.
Like the Day of Gathering, casting ... The marked brave ones.
Mothers of wild beasts in it ... Do not have mercy on a fetus.
And handkerchiefs (weapons) of deaths ... In the hands of unsheathing ones.
If you called war a slave ... And enslaved death.
The gifts of peace obediently ... Following or submissive.
Al-Rashid said to Al-Fadl: O Fadl, give him. He said: What, O Commander of the Faithful? He said: Give him ten thousand dirhams and carry him on three horses (Thalathin min al-khayl). His saying 'Ala thalathin' (on three - feminine form), he dropped the Ha because 'Al-Khayl' (horses) is feminine, so the number in it is carried on the word, masculine or feminine. You say: 'Lahu 'indi thalathun min al-khayli dhukurun' (He has with me three horses, males), or 'Lahu thalathun min al-khayli inathun' (three horses, females). Likewise women, camels, cows, and the like; its number runs on the feminine because of what I mentioned to you, as they are all females.

Ibn Duraid and Al-Yazidi informed us, they said: Abd al-Rahman bin akhi Al-Asma'i informed us from his uncle, he said: The Arabs say 'Darabtu Fulanan hatta ahda'tuhu', i.e., I quieted him. 'Matala Fulanun al-qawla': If he prolonged it one part upon another. 'Tamattala al-jawadu': If he extended one part upon another. It is said: 'Askantu Fulanan wa ahfaztuhu': If I angered him. 'Al-Muqallis': The one who plays before the Emir when he enters the city. 'Al-Sa''at': The one who rents out camels. The Arabs say: 'Inna la-fi sanatin tajada'at afa'iha': If they ate each other due to severe drought. And they say: 'Asabatha sanatun khafiya fiha al-bayadu wa zahara as-sawadu': i.e., milk decreased due to lack of vegetation, and dates (black) appeared, i.e., he has dates and water. He said: It was said to a man from the Kilabis: Did you marry so-and-so? He said: Yes. They said: She does not cover you from nakedness ('Awra) nor cure you from 'Surah'. Meaning 'She does not cover you from nakedness': She is clumsy and does not know how to build a house for you to cover yourself with. 'Nor cure you from Surah': i.e., she does not oil your head nor delouse it.

Al-Akhfash recited to us, by Ibn al-Mu'tazz:
(Khafif Meter)
The full moon promised a visit at night ... So when he fulfilled, I paid my vows.
I said, O my master, why did you not prefer ... The night over the joy of the fresh day?
He said to me: I do not like changing a custom ... Such is the custom in the rising of full moons.
He said: So some of them competed with him in this meaning and said:
(Khafif Meter)
My nurse said to me and showed passion ... After avoidance, aversion, and distance.
He said I am coming with the evening ... So wait for me and do not fear a breach.
I said: O my master, then why not by day ... It is the announcement of the joy of union.
He said to me: I do not like changing a custom ... Thus the full moon comes in the darkness.

Al-Zajjaj recited to us, he said: Al-Mubarrad recited to us:
(Basit Meter)
If they envy me, then I do not envy them ... Before me, people of virtue among men were envied.
So what is with me and what is with them lasted for me and them ... And most of us died of rage at what he finds.
I am the one whom they find in their throats ... I do not ascend (Artaqi) a form (Suwaran) in them nor do I go down (Aridu).
He said: Similar is the saying of Marwan bin Abi Hafsa:
(Kamil Meter)
And I was gifted a million million, not mixed ... Except with a cause of a Caliph and a Wazir.

I never disdained to compose his praise ... Except for an owner of a pulpit and a throne.
The envy of the mean did not harm me, and always ... The possessor of virtue is envied by those of shortcoming.

Abu al-Fadl al-Nahwi recited to me for his father:
(Wafir Meter)
He says I am the big/old one (Al-Kabir), so revere me ... Lo, may your mother be bereaved of a big one.
If the small one is more general in benefit ... And sharper at the calamity of affairs.
And more effective in accidents if they befall ... Then what is the merit of the big over the small?

Ibn Duraid informed us from his uncle from his father from Ibn al-Kalbi, he said: A man from the people of Kufa from Banu al-Tamuh bin Kindah told me, he said: I was attending the session of Shurayh while he was holding the judgeship for the Commander of the Faithful Ali bin Abi Talib, peace be upon him. A man came to him, short (Jaydar), small-headed (Sa'l), protruding forehead, ugly-faced (Shatim), as if he were a poker (Mihrath), and with him a woman like a white she-camel (Faqah 'Ansa'), turning two wide eyes (Najlawayn) as if their eyelashes were the primaries of a swallow. She revealed a forearm like the spadix (Ighrid) in whiteness and fingertips like the plants of the sand dune (Nabat an-Naqa).
