Then she said with the sweetest and most eloquent wording, showing teeth like hail, then said: O Judge, this is my husband (Ba'li). Shurayh said: Is he so? He grinned with two receding lips revealing huge teeth like the spinal vertebrae of a wild ass. Shurayh said to her: What is his matter? She said: O Judge, he is my cousin. I am Khawlah bint Muharramah, one of the women of Jarm. He migrated me from my family and took me away from my relatives, so I became looking only at him, and attacking only him. And he, by Allah, is gluttonous when he eats, sinister when he asks, locked of hands with miserliness, loose of tongue with obscenity. He eats alone, withholds his aid, and breaks his promise. If I treat him gently he frowns, and if I try to please him he gets angry. He preserves his money and humiliates his family. The man shouted: O men, for the slander (Afikah)! Then he knelt on his knees and said: O Judge, rather ask the nobles of Banu Jarm, for they will inform you of the clear news:
(Basit Meter)
Do I leave the huge-humped she-camel playing ... When the strong wind plays with the dangerous matter?
For the neighbor, the guest, and the poor, they have worked ... In a night where the cold spears spring from the cold.
And I invalidate the opponent possessor of the one-eyed argument ... Until he stammers from stuttering and restriction.
And I leave the peer yellow of fingertips ... Bloody of the collarbones, thrown on the dust.
And ask them, did they throw me towards a calamity ... And I did not fight something with cut fangs?
And ask them how is his defense of their harem ... When the borrowed war throws sparks.
Indeed I am great in the eye of the brave despite ... What was in me of shortness and thickness (Tajdir).
Until he turns away seeking shelter from confronting me ... The turning of fox cubs from the lion, crusher.
By Allah, our two persons will not be gathered by harmony ... After this day in Bedouin life or city.
Shurayh said to him: Clarify your intention regarding her. He said: She is divorced thrice, and this young man, Ibn Aban bin Abi Waliha, will undertake her maintenance until the end of her waiting period. Then he rose.

'Al-Jaydar': Short, like 'Al-Buhtar', 'Al-Bahtar', 'Al-Ku'alik', 'Al-Hanbal', 'Ad-Dakdak', 'Ad-Dinamah', and 'Ad-Dina'ah'. 'As-Sa'l': Small-headed. 'Ash-Shatim': Ugly-faced. 'Al-Mihrath': The stick with which fire is stirred, blackened and burnt. 'Al-'Ansa'': The white she-camel. 'Al-'Aynan an-Najlawan': Wide eyes. 'Al-Hudb': Hair growing around the eye; the place of hair is called 'Ash-Shu'r'. 'Al-Ighrid': The spadix when its cover splits; the cover is 'Al-Jufra'. 'Al-Anamil': Fingertips. 'Nabat an-Naqa': Roses the Arabs liken fingertips to for their softness and whiteness; also 'Al-Asari'', singular 'Usru''. 'An-Naqa': Sand dune, shortened. 'An-Nahm': Gluttony. 'Al-Falhas': The dog. 'Al-Musanah': Cajoling and softening. From it the poet's saying:
(Tawil Meter)
Do not despair and ask Allah for provision (Nawwirah), for He ... If Allah eases the knot of difficult things, it eases.
'Istanyira': He says: Ask Him for 'An-Nirah' which is provision. Meaning of 'Sanna': Eased. 'Al-Afikah': Slander and lie, originally speech turned from its direction. 'Al-Jali min al-khabar': The clear. 'Al-Kawma'': Large-humped. 'As-Saghan': Cold spears. 'Al-Khasar': Cold. 'Al-Maradigh': Between the collarbone and neck, singular 'Mardaghah', like 'Al-Badil', singular 'Badil' without Ha. 'Al-Kami': The brave, derived from 'Takammat li-sh-shar' if he intended it. Some said: Derived from 'Kama Fulanun shahadatahu' i.e., concealed it,

As if he concealed his bravery. 'Al-Hajaris': Fox cubs. 'Al-Hasur': The lion that crushes everything, i.e., breaks and bends it. 'Al-Liwadh' and 'Al-Mulawadhah', Al-Farra' said: 'Ladha Fulanun bi-Fulan': If he took shelter with him (yaludhu). 'Al-Liwadh': Taking shelter from something. 'At-Tajdir': Shortness with thickness; it is said a man is 'Mujaddar': If he is short and thick. 'Al-Mula'amah': Agreement; it is said 'This thing does not suit (yula'imuni) me', i.e., does not agree with me. And 'Fulanun yulawimu Fulanan' with Waw if each blames the other.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Arab al-Husayn bin Duraid informed me from his father from Ibn al-Kalbi from his father from Abu Mikhnaf, he said: Two sheikhs from the people of Al-Sarat told me, they said: Qusayb bin al-Qasim, one of Banu Minhab bin Daws, was one of the men of the Arabs famous for bravery, might, and boldness. He was generous, keeping nothing. He went out once in a march with his companions intending to raid Bajila, but he encountered them prepared, having been warned of him. His wealth was for the poor of his people and others; he raided with them if they were fertile, and provided for them if they were destitute (awraqu). So he turned back intending Khath'am, which has forbidding mountains, reefs, and stagnant water with connected thickets. He lay in ambush in some of them for days, he and his companions eating the insects of the earth until that harmed them. They considered returning to their lands empty-handed. One day they woke up exhausted by hunger. Qusayb said to them: O people, if we stay in this state we will die quietly. Then he looked out for them and lo, near the mountain in the middle of a depression was a herd of camels like dark night filling its sides. He went down to his companions and said: O people, I see near this mountain a depression filled with meat. Will you raid it with the rest of our energy and drive away what we can? If we are repelled so we fight until we embrace (wrestle), it will water us [?]. And if we overcome it and are killed, we are more excused among our clan. They said: We see what you saw. Then they went out from their ambush towards the direction until they overlooked the depression. They drove away the nearest cattle to them, a herd, then urged them on and did not sense anyone until they thought they had escaped with them. They made them kneel and benefited from a slaughter for them. The night effaced the trace and blinded the sight, and they spent the night safe, having filled their hands. When the darkness thinned and the dawn column flew and rose, they did not ask until the road ended with them at a pass. When they started up its path, lo, a figure on a peak of it like an eagle wrapped in a cloak. When they approached him, he leaped and shouted at the camels, so they turned back striking whatever they passed as if spears were in their rears. Then he came shuffling in their tracks. We intercepted him, so he shot a man of us, splitting his heart as if he had been warned yesterday. Then he shot another and made him sit, then shot another joining him to them. A man of us shot him, and the arrow stuck in his arm. Then he came chewing the arrow shaft until he broke it. He shot another of us, piercing his thighs. So we retreated from him, four of us; nothing was dearer to us than leaving him nor more hateful to our eyes than him. Then he went out following the camels which had scattered from him until he gathered them. Then he shouted: Let one of you come to me. My companions refrained, so I stood up, by Allah, reluctant, and came to him. He said: Who are the people? I said: What is your need to ask about this? By Allah, you do not seek blood from us, nor do we hope in you for loss of protection. He said: You must tell me, for I have seen faces of yours I feared for. My companions, when I approached him, followed me out of pity for me. I said: We are a people from Azd. He said: Which of them are you? I said: This is what you do not need, and I am not telling you about it. You have driven away who you saw, and our blood is in your people and is not wasted, so mind your business, O Sheikh. He said: Are you not telling me about your affair? Bear witness then, if you do not tell me your lineage. I said: No, by Al-Lat, there is no way to that. He said: Then inform your people that your blood is in the broad [arrows?] of Ath'ath bin Hadiyah al-Tahafi. And here is this herd, take it as spoil, for I am not informing about you. So take if you wish or leave. We returned to the herd, and lo, it was forty increasing by a few. We drove them and came with saddles, looted and avenged. We covenanted not to tell our affair to anyone of our people. We returned to the tribe and were asked about our companions, so we informed that a Hanafi killed them. Three days after our return, in a night gathering of the tribe, a caller called out saying:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
Do you not ask the youths returning ... To the tribe with the foulest spoil.
With the most miserable herd acquired ... And bringing the most disturbing news.
Would that Qusayb and his followers ... The morning they attacked Ath'ath.
The earth had swallowed them up ... And they became rotten bones in the Kanakith (plants).
And did not wear the bodice of a menstruating woman ... And dirtier than the bodice of menstruation.
O men, for a story ... Attached to the smeared weakling.
Would that you, in the pouring rain before it ... Were a slipped fetus raided in a place of dung.

Ibn al-Kalbi said: Some Dawsis told me that Qusayb was in the club, so he slipped away under the night, and it is not known where he went nor where his children are to this day.
His saying 'Awraqu': Their wealth decreased. It is an auto-antonym. It is said 'Awraqa al-qawmu': If their wealth decreased, and 'Awraqu': If their wealth increased. 'Al-Waraq' with fatha on Waw: Wealth of camels, sheep, etc. Al-Ajjaj said:
(Rajaz Meter)
You I call, so accept my flattery ... Forgive my sins and increase my wealth (Waraqi).
i.e., my wealth. 'Al-Wriq' with kasra on Waw: Silver, likewise 'Ar-Riqah', plural 'Ar-Riqin'. Their proverb: 'Ar-Riqin gives the stupidity of the stupid'. 'Al-Hadirah': The troop. Abu Dhu'ib said:
(Kamil Meter)
They come to the waters as a troop and a scouting party ... The coming of the sandgrouse when the follower (shadow) shrinks.
'At-Tabi'': The shadow. 'Isma'alla': Shrank. 'Al-Arin': The lion's thicket. 'Al-Mutawasi': Connected. 'Ahnash al-ard': Its small creeping things. Origin of 'Hanash': Snake, plural 'Ahnash'. 'Al-Asbar': Sides. It is said: He filled the vessel to its sides. 'An-Natish': Movement, from it 'Natshan'. Their saying 'Takhtakha an-nazar': Repelled it. 'At-Takh': Lifting, from it 'Tuba liman kanat lahu mitakhkhah'. His saying 'Asha'a': He shouted at them to gather. It is said 'Shaya'tu bi-l-ibil' and 'Na'aqtu bi-l-ghanam'. 'Al-Karir': The shepherd.
So throw your hairy buttocks upon her young camel ... And urge her (Shayi') and gather to you the urinating ones.
'Al-Hadhjan': Short steps in speed. 'Hasastu laha': I sensed/perceived. 'Al-Mujabbith': Disturbing. 'Tawadda'at': Cut up. 'Al-Kankath': Dust (or plant). 'Al-Asdah': Bodice. 'An-Nataf': One who wears the 'Nutafah' which is the small one of people. 'Al-Marth' like 'Al-Mars'. 'Al-Malis': Miscarriage of she-camels. It is said 'Amlasat an-naqah' and 'Amlatat': If she throws her young before completion. Likewise for 'An-Nghas' if thrown before settling. It is 'Malis' and 'Mumlas', 'Malit' and 'Mumlat'. 'Al-Mafrath': Place where dung is thrown.

Abu al-Qasim Ibrahim bin Muhammad al-Sa'igh informed us, he said: Ibn Qutayba told us, he said: Ibn Uyaynah narrated from Umar bin Dinar from Muhammad bin Habib bin Jubayr from his father Mut'im from Ibn Jubayr, he said: I lost a camel of mine on the Day of Arafah, so I passed to Arafah looking for it. Lo, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was standing with the people. I said: This is from the Hums, so why did he leave the Sanctuary?
Al-Asma'i said: 'Al-Hums': Quraysh and those who followed their religion among Arabs. Named so because they were strict ( تشدد - Tashaddud) in their religion. 'Al-Hamasah': Severity. It is said 'Hamisa al-amru hamasan': If it became severe. From it the brave is called 'Ahmas'. Quraysh used to say: We are the people of Allah so we do not leave His Sanctuary. They did not stand (at Arafat) until Islam came, so Allah revealed (Then depart from where the people depart). So they were ordered to stay with the people and depart with them. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went out to Arafah and stood with the people. Jubayr did not know this reason at that time, so he denied his standing, peace and blessings be upon him, at Arafah and his opposing the Quraysh school in that.

Al-Sa'igh informed us, he said: Ibn Qutayba informed us, he said: Al-Sijistani told me from Al-Asma'i, he said: Ishaq bin Yahya bin Talha told me, he said: Mina is from the descent of Al-Aqabah to Muhassir. The standing of Muzdalifah is from Muhassir to the markers of the Sanctuary. The standing of Arafah is in the Hill (Al-Hill - non-sanctuary), not in the Sanctuary.

Al-Yazidi informed us, he said: Sulaym bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abi Na'ib from the descendants of Abd al-Rahman bin Awf informed me from his father from Abdullah bin Ja'far raising it to Ibn Abbas from his father Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib, he said: Abd al-Muttalib went out to Yemen in the winter journey. A man from the people of the Psalms (Zabur) met him and asked his lineage, so he told him. He said: Do you order me to look at something of you? He said: Yes, as long as it is not my private parts. He started turning the septum of his nose and saying: I see magic in which is the light of Prophethood, but we do not find the command to be except in Banu Zuhrah. Do you have a 'Sha'ah'? He said: What is the 'Sha'ah'? He said: A wife. He said: As for today, no. He said: So return and marry in Banu Zuhrah. So he returned and married Halah bint Wuhayb bin Abd Manaf bin Zuhrah, and married his son Abdullah to Amina bint Wahb bin Abd Manaf bin Zuhrah. Quraysh said: Abdullah succeeded over his father Abd al-Muttalib. Halah bore him Hamzah and Al-Muqawwam and Safiyyah children of Abd al-Muttalib, and Amina bore Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, for Abdullah.

Ibn Duraid informed us, he said: Abu Hatim informed us from Abu Ubayda, he said: Ibn Da'b said:

People named the perfumes Al-Ghaliyah, Al-Sahiriyah, and Al-Abir after the daughters of Abd from Banu Abdullah bin Sakhr bin Nafi' bin Salaf bin Yaqzan from the people of Yemen from the pure Arabs. He had three daughters called: Al-Ghaliyah, Al-Sahiriyah, and Al-Abir. They gathered and crushed musk, ambergris, and oud. Al-Ghaliyah mixed it with ban oil, so it was said: This is the perfume of Al-Ghaliyah. Al-Sahiriyah mixed it with mercury, so it was said: This is the perfume of Al-Sahiriyah. Al-Abir mixed it with rose water, so it was said: This is the perfume of Al-Abir. This is how this report was narrated to us. As for linguists, they differ. Al-Asma'i claims that Al-Abir is: Saffron, and argues with the saying of Al-Asha:
(Mutaqarib Meter)
And she cools with the coolness of the bride's cloak ... In the summer, into which you poured Al-Abir.
Others besides Al-Asma'i claim that Al-Abir is mixtures gathered with saffron, thus differentiating between Al-Abir and Saffron. 'At-Tumah': A bead made of silver like a pearl.

Al-Yazidi recited to us for his uncle:
(Sari' Meter)
I have become impatient with you while seeking reform ... While you turn away from the duty.
Who is there for me to ensure we do until you see ... How many absent ones you have in the world.
He also recited to us for him:
(Kamil Meter)
There was later a friend who quarreled ... With affection, giving his love, not hostile.
Until he passed, and his enemy and friend ... Are equal in hate for him and affection.

Al-Zajjaj informed us, he said: Al-Mubarrad informed us, he said: Ibn al-A'rabi used to attack Abu Nuwas and belittle his poetry. He attended a session where there were some narrators of Abu Nuwas. So he recited to him for Abu Nuwas:
(Kamil Meter)
The trace of sleep between the eyelids is altered ... Wiped over by weeping for you that is long.
O looker, whose glances did not cease ... Until a slain one was dragged between them.
He said to him: Woe to you! Whose is this? For by Allah he did well and reached the limit. He said: The one who says:
(Tawil Meter)
Weak of returning the glance, she thinks she is ... Recently recovered from illness.
And indeed I come to the matter from where it is feared ... And my bow knows when I pull whom I shoot.
He said to him: Woe to you! Whose is this? For by Allah rejection has taken me regarding him. He said: This is the one who says:
(Basit Meter)
Riders gave each other drink from cups, among them ... The cup of night travel, so the giver and receiver became intoxicated.
As if their heads, while sleep describes them ... Upon the shoulders, were not placed on necks.
They waded towards you seas of longing at times ... Until they made the camels kneel to you before sunrise.
From every clearly fat, safe one ... Longing, carrying the burdens of a longing one.
He said to him: Woe to you! Whose is this? For by Allah he was witty with all wit. He said: I will not tell you until you write the verses. When he wrote them, I said: This is the one whose poetry you diminish and attack, Abu Nuwas. He said: O son of my brother, conceal it for me, for I will not return to it, by Allah, ever.

Al-Akhfash recited to us from Tha'lab for Zayd bin Amr bin Nufayl al-Qurashi:
(Khafif Meter)
You two asked me for divorce when you saw me ... My wealth became little, you came to me with a strange thing.
Woe, whoever has a lover responds ... And whoever becomes poor lives a life of harm.

Issue
Know that 'Asa', 'Kada', 'Karaba', 'Ja'ala', and 'Akhadha' are for the approach of the verb. As for 'Asa', it is used with 'An', and the rest of its sisters are used without 'An', like your saying: 'Asa Zaydun an yaquma' (Perhaps Zayd will stand), and 'Asa Amrun an yarkaba'. The place of 'An' is accusative, and the estimation is: Zayd approached departure. 'An' with the verb is in the interpretation of the source (Masdar), as if you said: 'Asa Zaydun al-qiyama'. If you said: 'Asa Zaydun al-qiyama' it would not be permissible; it is only permissible if you mention 'An', even if the meaning is the meaning of the source. The reason for forbidding that is that if you mentioned 'An' with the verb, you indicated the future, not the meaning (essence), therefore using the source with 'Asa' is not permissible, nor the active participle, except that it came in one proverb of the Arabs, which is their saying:
(Manhuk Rajaz Meter)
'Asa al-ghuwayru ab'usa'

This is a proverb struck for a man who brings a matter, attributes it to another, while he is suspected of it. 'Ghuwayr': Diminutive of 'Ghar' (Cave). The first to strike this proverb was Al-Zabba', the Roman woman, when Qasir came to take vengeance for Amr. He had a fortified fortress, so he put men in boxes and came to her fortress. It had a tunnel, so he placed men over it. When she sensed the calamity, she intended to exit from the tunnel but discerned men upon it, so she said: 'Asa al-ghuwayru ab'usa' (Perhaps the little cave is misery), meaning I have been approached from the direction of the cave. Then it became a proverb struck for everyone accused of a matter. In the Hadith: A man was found 'Malfutan' (strangled?), so Umar was brought to him. Umar said to him: "Asa al-ghuwayru ab'usa", suspecting him of it. Then an Arif praised him with good, so he said: "Rabbata dhalika wa la marrah" (Perhaps that, not even once).
If you advance 'An', saying: 'Asa an yaqula Zaydun', the place of 'An' is nominative, estimation: 'Zayd's standing approached'. Allah said: (Perhaps your Lord will raise you). This is the rule of 'Asa'. You say regarding the rest of its sisters: 'Ja'ala Zaydun yaqulu kadha wa kadha' (Zayd started saying such and such). And 'Kada Zaydun yakhruju' (Zayd almost went out). You do not say: 'Ja'ala Zaydun an yaqula', nor 'Kada an yakhruja' except in poetic necessity. Among Arab proverbs: 'Kada an-na'amu yatiru' (Ostriches almost fly), and 'Kada al-'arusu yakunu amiran' (The bridegroom almost becomes a prince), due to their nearness to that state. Allah Almighty said: (The flash of its lightning almost takes away the eyesight). The reason for using 'Asa' with 'An' and its sisters without 'An' is that 'Kada' and 'Akhadha' and similar verbs are made for the comparison of the action and overseeing its occurrence and existence. Do you not see that you do not say: 'Kidtu adkhulu al-madinata' (I almost entered the city) except when you are overlooking it, and you do not say: 'Ja'ala Zaydun yaqulu kadha wa kadha' except to narrate his state in saying. So this does not need 'An' because it falls upon the state. As for 'Asa', it is as I mentioned to you, seeking the verb as future and awaited, so it is for the approach of its name not its essence. Do you not see that you say: 'Asa an ahujja' (Perhaps I will perform Hajj), while you have not left your place yet. This is clear and evident. Then 'Asa' may come in poetry out of necessity without 'An', and 'Kada' and its sisters with 'An'. Hudba bin al-Khashram said regarding 'Asa' without 'An':
(Wafir Meter)
Perhaps the distress I have ended up in ... Behind it will be a near relief.
Ru'ba said regarding 'Kada':
(Rajaz Meter)
It almost, from the length of decay, became effaced (an yamsaha).
The original is what I mentioned to you.

Issue on Nouns: Why are they not Jussive? And Verbs: Why are they not Genitive?
If a questioner asks and says: Why are nouns not jussive (Majzum)? There are answers to that. Among them is what Sibawayh relied on and those who followed him after. He said: Nouns are not jussive due to their empowerment (tamakkun) and the attachment of Tanwin (nunation) to them, so they would not combine the loss of it (Tanwin) and the loss of the vowel (Harakah) upon them. The summary of that: Basrans and Kufans have agreed that Tanwin is necessary for nouns, not verbs and particles. If a noun like 'Ja'far' were jussive, silencing the Ra would be necessary for Jazm, and after it is Tanwin based on the principle agreed upon between them. So two sakin (still) letters would meet, which are the Tanwin and the Ra. It would be necessary to move one of them or delete it. According to the conventions of Arab speech, if two sakins meet and the first is a sound letter, not a letter of Madd (extension) or Lin (softness), the first must be moved (voweled), as you say: 'Idrib Zaydan', then you say: 'Idribi al-ghulam', moving the Ba due to the meeting of two sakins. If the first of them is a letter of Madd and Lin, which are Ya, Waw, and Alif, the first is deleted, as you say: 'Zaydun yaghzu al-qawma', 'Amrun yaqdi al-yawma', and 'Zaydun yakhsha an-nasa', as Allah Almighty said (And you fear the people, while Allah has more right that you fear Him), and His saying (Those who believed and did righteous deeds). These letters drop from pronunciation even if they are fixed in writing, except if two sound sakins meet in the assimilated (Mudgham), then you move the second of them, like your saying in the imperative: 'Mudda' and 'Shudda', because there is no way to move the first, for if the first moved and the second was still, the doubling (Tad'if) would appear, like saying: 'Madadta' and 'Shadadtahu' and similar. So if you moved the Ra of 'Ja'far' based on this analogy, Jazm would be nullified from speech, because whenever you made a noun jussive you would be correct to silence its end then move it due to the meeting of two sakins. If you deleted the Ra due to the meeting of two sakins, the noun would be nullified because its meaning is completed by its entirety. If you deleted the Tanwin due to the meeting of two sakins, you would have deleted the vowel, returning to Sibawayh's saying of deleting a vowel and Tanwin, and you would be unjust to the noun by the loss of two things. Moreover, among nouns are those whose penultimate is sakin like 'Bakr' and 'Zayd'. If such a noun were jussive on this estimation he mentioned, three sakin letters would meet in it, and the meeting of such is impossible. This is Sibawayh's school, and it has become clear from it that the entry of Jazm on nouns is not permissible in wording.

Al-Farra and his companions said: Nouns are not made jussive (majzum) because they are light, so if they were made jussive, it would add to their lightness. And verbs are not made genitive (makhfud) due to their heaviness, so if they were made genitive, it would add to their heaviness. Thus, they balanced the speech by making nouns genitive and verbs jussive, so that the heavy enters upon the light and the lightness upon the heavy, resulting in equilibrium. A group of the Basrans and a group of the people of speculation (theorists), including Al-Mubarrad and Tha'lab, said: Nouns are not made jussive due to the impossibility of a jussive particle entering upon them, because the jussive particles are only for negation, command, prohibition, and conditional reward, and whatever does not revert in meaning to one of these meanings, such as 'lam' (did not), the 'lam' of command, the 'la' of prohibition, and the conditional particles 'in' (if), 'mahuma' (whatever), and the like. It is impossible to negate nouns because minds necessarily indicate that negation does not apply to the name nor the named object; rather, it applies to a state among its states, an action among its actions, or an attribute among its attributes. Like your saying: 'Zayd is not rational' (Laysa Zaydun 'aqilan), you only negated his rationality. And 'Zayd is not in the house', you only negated his being in the house. Likewise: 'Zayd did not stand' (Lam yaqum Zayd), and 'Abdullah did not speak', and 'You have no servant' (La ghulama laka), and the like. Negation does not attach to the named object itself, but rather attaches to its actions, news, and states. This is agreed upon by the theorists, and minds testify to its correctness. Similarly, command, prohibition, conditional reward, and the like only occur with verbs. He said: If a claimer claims that negation connects to nouns in their essence, without meaning by that the non-existence of the essence from a time or place it exists in, let him provide evidence for the validity of that which minds testify to be correct, and he will never find a way to do so. There is no disagreement among scholars regarding what we mentioned about negation. It suffices as proof of the error and 'inqita' (being silenced/defeated) of the one opposing this that he has departed from what the collective testifies to be correct. Know that the 'inqita' (defeat/silencing) of an opponent is not only by his silence and interruption. Scholars have categorized 'inqita' into compilations and clarified its aspects. One of them is that a person holds a doctrine in jurisprudence, grammar, theory, or other sciences, then meets an opponent who holds a contrary doctrine, with the difference established between them. They debate an issue, and one of them continues to press the other with arguments until he forces his companion to believe what contradicts the doctrine he supports. If he believes that, he is 'munqati' (defeated) by exiting his doctrine which he started observing and was stubborn about shifting from. If he does not adopt what he was forced into and brings something to repel his opponent with a clear argument, he has come close. But if he cannot do that and acknowledges the truth, he is 'munqati' (defeated) while being fair and following the path of observation/theory, and he is more excused than the first stubborn one. The second type of 'inqita' is when the cause (illah) does not consistently apply to the effect. The third type is that the matter leads the debater to believe in the impossible and say it is the truth if, in his claim, it supports his doctrine; and a doctrine supported by impossibility is sufficient evidence of corruption. It is as if he believes that a single body can be moving and stationary in one state, or not stationary and moving, or existent and non-existent in one state. Or that a human is standing and sitting in one state, or speaking and silent, or moving and stationary. Or he says fire is cooling and water is heating. Or he claims that yesterday has not passed yet and tomorrow is present or has passed. And similar attempts. Similar in impossibility is the saying of one who claims that if we say: 'Zayd did not stand' (Lam yaqum Zayd), or 'Lam Zayd qama'—if that were proper—that the negation applies to the essence of Zayd, not his action. There is no difference between this and the first regarding impossibility for anyone of sound mind and discernment. Whoever's matter leads to this has been cut off (defeated) and his limbs cut, and speech will not benefit him as his failure and defeat have become clear, and it is not within his opponent's power to force him to silence, and there is nothing more upon him than what he has clarified. Another type of 'inqita' is when something is presented to the opponent which he does not know the direction of, so he acknowledges the truth and says: 'I do not have an answer at this time, and I will consider it.' This is the way of scholars, and this acknowledger of what was presented to him does not decrease from the rank of knowledge by this characteristic; rather, he increases in majesty among scholars by this characteristic. Al-Zajjaj informed us, saying: I heard Al-Mubarrad say: It was narrated from Al-Sha'bi that it was said to him: 'Aren't you ashamed of how often you say "I don't know" when asked?' He said: 'But the angels of Allah, the drawn-near ones, were not ashamed when they were asked about what they had no knowledge of, for they said: "Glory be to You, we have no knowledge except what You have taught us."' Ahmad ibn al-Hasan ibn Sufyan informed us, saying Ahmad ibn Ubayd ibn Nasih informed us, saying: 'Umarah ibn 'Aqil ibn Bilal ibn Jarir visited Ja'far and Muhammad, the two sons of Sulayman ibn Ali ibn Abdullah ibn Abbas. They interceded for him with Al-Mahdi until they brought him in to him. He ordered wealth and slaves for him, so he ('Umarah) said: [Poem in Tawil meter] May Allah water ruins and a blessing... to Malhaz when the tribe dwells in Muhallaz. A herd from Buhtan drove them... and another from the north when it moved...

I knew in it a white woman from the family of Mazin... whenever she traces her lineage, she counts Hilal ibn Ajwaz. The riding camels departed, ascending towards you... with fat camels until they began to be thought of as emaciated from travel. How many a rugged hill I crossed towards you, and sand... and dark dusty storms and stony ground. Young female hares aiming at ostriches by the nose-rings... when the fifth day (of thirst) in the desert clings to the riders. [Repeat of verse] Young female hares aiming at ostriches by the nose-rings... when the fifth day in the desert clings to the riders. They did not reach until their eyes seemed... like small wells in stones that had become depleted. May Allah reward Ja'far and Muhammad on my behalf... with Allah's honor, and the best of rewards. For they facilitated my entry to the Caliph... and they bestowed upon me abundantly, so he fulfilled. Their palms are moist (generous) and their merit is known... when the palms of people become depleted. How many a weary one hoped for their goal... so he fell short, blamed and tired, while they surpassed. Their two spears, the possessor of hatred found no... softness in them, nor did enemies find a weak spot in war. They are the two sons of the Messenger of Allah and the two sons of his cousin... Sulayman, the best of people in branch and root. And indeed, you two, O sons of Sulayman, are my equipment... and my sanctuary when I find no sanctuary. And indeed, you are the most fulfilling of Nizar in pact... and the most noble ascent for a visitor when he is in need. Ibn 'Umarah said: So I recited these verses to my father, and he said: 'Your father heaped praise upon them, so did they give us a servant to serve him?' I said: 'They gave us a servant and much wealth.' Ibn Shuqayr informed us, saying Ahmad ibn Ubayd informed us from Ya'qub ibn al-Sikit, saying: There was a man among the Arabs who was bad at demanding payment, and another who was bad at paying debts, called 'Aqrab (Scorpion). The Arabs said: We wish a transaction would occur between them so we can see what they do. So a transaction occurred between them for a set term. When it was a month before the term, the demander came to 'Aqrab's door, built a bench opposite it, and sat on it. 'Aqrab came out and said: 'What brought you?' He said: 'Good.' He said: 'Has your debt come due?' He said: 'Have I demanded payment from you?' He said: 'Then why are you sitting at my door?' He said: 'Do you prevent me from the road?' So he remained staying on the bench for thirty days and nights until the term fell due. 'Aqrab came out to him and struck his hand into his (paid him), and he did not leave him until he paid his debt. He recited saying: [Poem in Sari' meter] A scorpion ('Aqrab) traded in our market... No welcome to the wicked scorpion. Every enemy fears his evil... and his stinging tail is feared. Indeed an enemy whose plot is in his rear... is not possessor of evil nor a provider. If the scorpion returns, we return for it... and the sandal/shoe was present for it. Issue: The saying of Allah Almighty: (Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - for them is forgiveness and a great reward) [Quran 48:29], so it is in the nominative case (raf'). And He said at the end of Surah Al-Fath regarding the companions of Muhammad (PBUH): (Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah; and those with him...) until He ended at His saying: (Allah has promised those who have believed and done righteous deeds among them forgiveness and a great reward) [Quran 48:29], so it is in the accusative case (nasb) by the action falling upon it. The estimation is: Allah promised those who believed among them forgiveness, meaning covering of their previous sins before Islam, and overlooking them, and a great reward for their supporting the Prophet (PBUH) and their assisting him, a virtue for them over others of the believers who did not assist him. As for the first verse, He said: (Allah has promised those who believed...), so it came generally, then He explained that promise and said: (for them is forgiveness and a great reward). So the estimation is: Allah promised them a promise, then He clarified the promise and said: 'for them is forgiveness'. If it were in the accusative case while the 'Lam' (for) was present, it would not be permissible and the speech would be invalid, and it would be like saying: 'I promised Zayd for him a dirham'. But He implied the promised object as a verbal noun (masdar), because implication (idmar) in the speech of the Arabs and in the Book of Allah is famous and frequent due to the indication of the speech upon it. From it is His saying: (Then it appeared to them after they had seen the signs to imprison him for a time) [Quran 12:35]. The estimation is: 'It appeared to them an appearance (badw)', because the verb must have a subject. And from it: (After the hearts of a party of them had almost deviated) [Quran 9:117], so in 'kada' (almost) there is an implied subject, otherwise it would not be a verb. And from it is the saying of the Arabs: 'Whoever lies, it was evil for him, and whoever speaks truth, it was good for him', so they implied 'truth' and 'lying' due to the indication of the verb upon them. And from it is his saying: 'Whoever resembles his father has not wronged the resemblance', meaning he did not put it in [other than] its place. And from it: (And let not those who greedily withhold...) then He said: (it is bad for them) [Quran 3:180]. Its interpretation: The stinginess is bad for them. He said Muhammad ibn Abd al-Malik told us, saying Yazid ibn Harun told us, saying Muhammad ibn al-Rabi' ibn al-Hakam told me:

Niftawayh informed us, saying Yazid ibn Harun told us from Salim ibn Sa'id ibn Mina, saying: I heard Ibn al-Zubayr while on the pulpit when he wanted to demolish the Kaaba and rebuild it, saying: My aunt Aisha told me that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: 'O Aisha, were it not that your people are close in time to polytheism (recently converted), I would have demolished the Kaaba and then added six cubits to it from the Hijr. Indeed, Quraysh fell short in funds when they built it, and I would have made for it two doors: an eastern door and a western door.' He said: So I witnessed him when he demolished it and added six cubits to it from the Hatim (Hijr), and there were rocks like the rumps of camels, and he made two doors for it and rejoiced greatly at that. Niftawayh said: When Ibn al-Zubayr was killed in the year seventy-three, Abd al-Malik appointed Al-Hajjaj over the Hijaz, so he demolished what Ibn al-Zubayr had built and returned it to its first state, and it remains so until now. Regarding this, Jarir says: [Poem in Tawil meter] I see the birds with Al-Hajjaj running our days... for you, O Commander of the Faithful, and helping. You returned to the House of Allah the covenant of His Prophet... and you repaired what the two concealers (Al-Khabiyan) had corrupted. He said: Abdullah ibn al-Zubayr was nicknamed Abu Bakr and his brother was nicknamed Abu Khubayb, so he was nicknamed by his brother, thus it was said: The two Khubaybs (Al-Khabiyan). Niftawayh informed us, saying Tha'lab informed me from Ibn al-A'rabi, saying: The Arabs say: Make this matter one 'Ba'j' (method/way), one 'Simat', one 'Bayan', one 'Sikkah', 'Unbub', 'Razdaq', 'Shawkal', 'Qiddah', 'Shirak', 'Ru'bub', 'Hanan', 'Waddah', and 'Mahajjah'. All with one meaning. This is the narration from Ibn al-A'rabi. He said: This is expansion and approximation. 'Al-Ba'j': The one horn, and it is Arabized Persian. As for 'Sikkah', 'Hanan', 'Waddah', and 'Mahajjah', they mean the road/path. As for 'Satr', 'Razdaq', and 'Simat', they mean the row of people and others. As for 'Qiddah' and 'Shirak', they mean the strip/way. Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Tha'lab recited to me, and I read to Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Ahwal, by Ta'abbata Sharran: [Poem in Tawil meter] And they said to her: Do not marry him, for he is... at the first peer meeting, to encounter a death. He says: He will be killed in the first war he meets because he exposes himself to death. So she did not see one who saw a 'Fatil' (tiny thread/worthless thing) and she was cautious... so her widowhood is from one wearing the night, most terrifying. He says: She did not see one who saw prudence worth a 'Fatil' in her leaving marriage. 'Fatil': The thread in the slit of a date stone. Little of the 'Ghirar' (sleep) of the eye, his greatest concern... is the blood of vengeance or meeting a bold brave warrior. 'Ghirar': Little sleep. 'Ghirar' in other contexts: The edge of a sword and the like. And 'Ghirar': The pattern/example; it is said: Their houses are on one 'Ghirar', i.e., on one pattern. And 'Ghirar': Slump of the market; it is said: Our market has a 'Dirrah' (flow) and 'Ghirar' (slump), i.e., exhaustion and slump. 'Al-Kami': The brave one, named so because he covers ('yatakamma') himself in fighting and evil, i.e., intends them; or it is said he is named so because he covers his bravery, i.e., hides it. 'Al-Mushayya'': Also the brave one. He fights (yumasiu) every one who encourages his day... and his striking the skulls of enemies is not to be encouraged (called brave). 'Mumas'ah': Deception/skill with swords, and likewise 'Sa'a'. And his saying 'yushajji'u yawmahu' (encourages his day) which he meets. 'Ma' is extra/redundant. The meaning: His striking the skulls of enemies is to be described with bravery. Tha'lab said: It is better that 'ma' is negation (Jahd), and the meaning is that his creation is the creation of the brave. So his bravery is nature, and his striking of the enemy's skulls is not to be described with bravery but is nature. Little saving of meat except for a sustenance... for the rib cartilage has expanded and the intestines stuck. He says: He does not eat meat except the amount to sustain himself. 'Nashara al-Sharsuf' means: The volume of his rib cartilages appeared due to the meeting of the 'Aqlab' (belly/intestines?) and the skin. 'Al-Sharsuf': Cartilage attached to every rib like the cartilage of the shoulder. He spends the night as the meaning of wild beasts until they become familiar with him... so he became such that he does not protect a pasture from them forever. But the owners of pregnant camels, it grieves them... when they see him bareheaded or masked. He says: That the owners of camels grieve because of him and fear him because he chases them in every state, bareheaded or armed. 'Al-Makhad': Pregnant camels, singular is 'Khalifah' from a different wording. And I, even if I live long, know that I... will meet the spearhead of death shining, bald (exposed). Abu Ja'far Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Muslim ibn Qutaybah informed us, saying my father told me, and Abu al-Qasim al-Sa'igh informed us, saying Ibn Qutaybah told us, saying Al-Sijistani informed me from Abu Ubaydah regarding His Almighty's saying: (And extended shade) [Quran 56:30], he said: Permanent, not removed by the sun. Abu Muhammad said: And in the tradition (The shade of Paradise is 'Sajih'), he said its meaning is there is no heat in it nor cold. Some scholars said it is like the mornings of summer before the sun rises. The meaning of the shade of Paradise is only... and from it is people's saying: So-and-so is in the shade of So-and-so, i.e., in his shelter and protection. The shade of the night is its blackness because it settles and covers everything with its darkness. Dhul-Rummah said: [Poem in Basit meter]

The distant unknown [desert] has forced the traveler off the road... in a green [dark] shade where the owls call its skulls. Meaning: in a black shade. Ahmad and Abu al-Qasim al-Sa'igh informed us. He said: Abdullah ibn Muslim told us from Al-Sijistani from Abu Ubaydah regarding the saying of Allah Almighty (A place of settlement and a place of storage) [Quran 6:98]. He said: Settlement in the loins, and storage in the womb. Al-Akhfash and Al-Zajjaj informed us from Al-Mubarrad who said: Three poets whose poetry became professional (as a trade), all from Himyar: Al-Musannad, Yahya ibn Nawfal, and Abu al-Hawl. Al-Fadl ibn Yahya al-Barmaki sat at Al-Nahrawan in a session exclusive for poetry. Abu al-Hawl advanced to recite to him. He said: 'I will not hear any praise from you until you recite to me what you satirized us with.' He refused, but he swore upon him that he must do it. So he recited saying: [Poem in Mutaqarib meter] If polytheism is mentioned in a gathering... the faces of Banu Barmak light up. And if a Surah is recited among them... they bring tales from Mazdak. So he ordered twenty thousand dirhams for him, and said: 'Bring the praise.' So he recited saying: [Poem in Tawil meter] To my knowledge of this sea, none crosses it... except one fearful of his sin or a risk-taker. So your generosity became populated... as if upon it were firm bridges. So he ordered twenty thousand dirhams for him. When he received the money, he said to him: 'May Allah amend you, this money will not arrive safely with me to my home.' So he sent horsemen with him until they brought him close to his home. Al-Zajjaj recited to us, saying Al-Mubarrad recited to us, saying Al-Mazini recited to me by Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali: [Poem in Wafir meter] I love Muhammad a strong love... and Abbas and Hamza and the Trustee (Ali). I love them for the love of Allah until... I come when resurrected upon my passion. A passion I was given since the mill of Islam... rotated, not equating [them] equally [with others]. The vile ones, Banu Qushayr, say... throughout time: 'You do not forget Ali.' The cousins of the Prophet and his closest kin... are the most beloved of all people to me. So if loving them is guidance, I have attained it... and I am not mistaken if it is error. Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Mahmud al-Wasiti told us, saying my father told us, saying Al-Salt ibn Mas'ud al-Jahdari told us, saying Haytham ibn Adi al-Ta'i Abu Abd al-Rahman told us from Mujalid ibn Sa'id from Al-Sha'bi who said: We asked Ibn Abbas or Ibn Abbas was asked: Who was the first of people to embrace Islam? He said: Abu Bakr. Have you not heard the saying of Hassan: [Poem in Basit meter] If you remember a sorrow from a trustworthy brother... then remember your brother Abu Bakr for what he did. The best of creation, the most pious and most just... after the Prophet and the most fulfilling of what he bore. The follower, the second, whose scene is praised... and the first of people among them to believe the messengers. Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Salamah from Al-Farra who said: Everything round is 'Kuffah', and everything elongated is 'Kiffah'. And 'Kaffah': The single instance of 'Kaff' (refraining/hem) with Fatha, and according to Al-Kisa'i 'Kaffah' of the scale (pan) is with Fatha as well. And 'Kiffah' with Kasra: Whatever is round of sand. And 'Kiffah' also: The ring of the sieve. And 'Kiffah' also: The trap of the hunter, and it is called 'Al-Bayda' (The White). He recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a 'Bayda' (trap) from the wealth of the youth, if he removes it... he gains, otherwise his wealth is the wealth of a destitute. He says: If he removes it (the trap/calamity), he has gained some wealth, otherwise he is destitute. And 'Al-Bayda': The sun. He recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a 'Bayda' (sun/woman) not stamped with a defect seen in her... the eyes of youths look below her squinting. And 'Al-Bayda': The ostrich egg. He recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a 'Bayda' (egg) which does not move away from us, and its mother... when she sees us, her strutting ceases. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying Isa ibn Yazid ibn Bakr ibn Da'b said: When Mu'awiyah became seriously ill, he sent for Yazid, who was at his estates, with a servant of his named [Name missing/unclear] to inform him of his father's heaviness. When he informed him, he came rushing and recited saying: [Poem in Basit meter] The messenger came with a paper dragging it... so the heart sensed fear from his paper. We said: Woe to you, what is in your scroll?... He said: The Caliph has become in pain among us. So the earth shook or almost shook with us... as if a dusty [mountain] from its corners was uprooted. I ascended upon it [the news/journey] to bridled white camels... covering the mountain passes with them, not coming to a water-way. We do not care, if they destroy our saddles... what died of them in the desert or limped. He whose soul ceases not to overlook a height... the destinies of that soul are about to fall. When we arrived and the door of the house was closed... for fear of widowhood, the heart was frightened and deterred.

When he entered upon him, he was alone with him and sent his family out. He said: 'O Yazid, the command of Allah has come, and this is the time of my perishing. So what will you do with the affair of this nation after me? For your sake, I preferred the world over the Hereafter and carried the burden on my back so that you may rise above the sons of your father.' He said: 'I will take them by the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet, and I will fight them upon it.' He said: 'Woe to you! Will you not proceed with the conduct of Abu Bakr who fought the people of apostasy and passed while the Ummah was pleased with him?' He said: 'No, except I take them by the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet and fight them upon it.' He said: 'Will you not proceed with the conduct of Umar who mobilized the armies, established the garrison cities, prescribed the stipend, protected the spoils, fought the enemy, and passed while the Ummah was pleased with him?' He said: 'No, except I take them by the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet and fight them upon it.' He said: 'Will you not proceed with the conduct of your uncle Uthman who ate during his life and fed after his death, and employed his relatives?' He said: 'No, except I take them by the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Prophet and fight them upon it.' He said: 'Will you not proceed with the conduct of your father who ate during his life and fed after his death and carried the burden on his back?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'O Yazid, hope is cut off from you regarding that you will fight all of these, so you will kill the best of your people, and invade the sanctuary of your Lord with the riffraff of people and feed them their day unjustly without right, then death will surprise you, so neither world did you attain nor Hereafter did you realize. O Yazid, since you will not hit the right path, indeed I have paved the matters for you and humbled the mightiest of Arabs for you, and submitted the people of honor and generosity to you, and sufficed you the settling and traveling, and gathered for you what no one has gathered. I do not fear that anyone will dispute this matter with you except three persons: Al-Husayn ibn Ali, Abdullah ibn Umar, and Ibn al-Zubayr. As for Ibn Umar, he has become weary, occupied with worship, emptied of the world and busied himself, so he will not dispute you over it unless it comes to him effortlessly. As for the one who crouches the crouching of the lion and dodges the dodging of the fox, if an opportunity enables him he leaps upon it, that is Ibn al-Zubayr. If he does and you gain power over him, then cut him piece by piece, unless he seeks peace; if he seeks it, then accept, and spare the blood of your people, their hearts will incline to you. As for Al-Husayn ibn Ali, indeed he has sanctity, a right, and kinship from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). I do not think the people of Iraq will leave him alone until they bring him out against you. If he does and you gain power over him, then pardon him, for if I were his companion I would have forgiven him. Rise from me.' Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Al-Mubarrad recited to us by Muslim ibn al-Walid: [Poem in Basit meter] There did not remain after the settling of gray hair in the head... except the anticipation of a disease that has no healer. When I resolved on forgetfulness and my soul... was deterred, and I brought close after ignorance my horses. There passed, presenting to me, the reddish-white wine shining... from the hand of a cupbearer with his eyes and with the cup. She revealed herself, withdrawing from the other, and her saliva... mixes the coolness of satisfaction in the heat of my breaths. Ibn Shuqayr informed us, saying Tha'lab told us from Ibn al-A'rabi, saying: The Arabs say for anyone who cheats: 'He struck fifths for sixths' (Daraba akhmasan li-asdas). The origin of that is that a man had sons tending wealth (camels) for him, and they had wives. They used to say to their father: 'We will tend for a sixth (watering every six days)', so they would tend for five and steal a day to come to their wives. Likewise, they would say 'in the fifth, in the fifth', so they would tend for a fourth and steal a day. So he realized it and said: [Poem in Wafir meter] And that is striking fifths intended for sixths... perhaps they will not be. Al-Kumayt transferred this verse into his poem because it became a common proverb, so he said: And that is striking fifths... [the verse]. Ibn al-A'rabi recited similar to it: [Poem in Basit meter] By Allah, by Allah, were it not that I fear... the Emir, I would have blamed Ibn Nibras. regarding a promise he told me then broke... 'Tomorrow, tomorrow', striking fifths for sixths. Until when we forced his promises... to the truths with gentleness and sociability. His cloud revealed a 'No', so I said to him... 'If only you had started with it, there would be no harm.' And a free man of the people does not return to 'No' after there has passed... from him a 'Yes' obediently. As for the saying of the other: 'And glory is attained in fifths and sixths', its meaning is: It is scattered, hardly found gathered in one. Ibn al-A'rabi said: And 'Al-Nibras': The lamp. It is said: It is 'Al-Nibras', 'Al-Siraj', 'Al-Qirat', 'Al-Qurt', 'Huzluq', 'Al-Misbah', 'Al-Wabisah', 'Al-Wabis', 'Al-Wabis', 'Al-Ma'nus', and 'Al-Haykah', all with one meaning. Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Al-Mubarrad recited to us by Abu al-Ghanahiyah: [Poem in Madid meter] A dweller remaining, he has a dwelling... Not with this does time inform. We are in a house, informing about it... regarding its trial is a speaker, eloquent. A house of evil, joy does not last... neither the enjoyable in it nor the sadness. In the path of Allah are our souls... all of them are pledged to death.

Every soul at its death... its share of its gathering is a shroud. Abu Bakr Yusuf ibn Ya'qub ibn Ishaq ibn al-Bahlul told us, saying Al-Zubayr ibn Bakkar told us, saying Abu Ghaziyyah told us, saying Ibn Abi Dhi'b told us from Al-Zuhri from Urwah from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: 'Indeed, the servant, when he falls ill, Allah removes sins from him in his illness just as the bellows (al-kir) removes the dross of iron.' Ibn al-Sikit said: 'Al-Kir' is the bellows of the blacksmith. And 'Al-Kur': The camel saddle, and its plural is 'Akwar' and 'Kiran'. He said: And I heard Abu Amr al-Shaybani say: 'Al-Kur' is built of iron and clay, and 'Al-Kir' is the skin bag that is blown into. Bishr said describing his horse: [Poem in Wafir meter] As if the rustling of his nostril whenever... they suppressed the heavy breathing was a round bellows. Yusuf ibn Ya'qub told us, saying my grandfather told me reading to him, saying Ishaq al-Azraq told me from Sufyan and Hamza al-Zayyat from Al-A'sha from Abu Wa'il who said: I heard Abdullah ibn Mas'ud saying: 'Indeed, I have heard the reciters and found them close to each other, so read as you were taught. And beware of excessiveness (tanattu'), for it is only like the saying of one of you: "Halumma" (Come), "Ta'ala" (Come), and "Aqbil" (Come).' Ya'qub told us, saying my grandfather told me reading to him, from Abu Dawood from Muhammad ibn Abdullah from Abu Ishaq from Al-Bara' raising it to the Prophet (PBUH) who said: 'Indeed, some poetry is wisdom and some speech is magic.' Abu al-Qasim said: Thus we narrated this report, and I consulted the Sheikh about it, so he said to them: It is 'Inna min al-shi'ri hukman' (Indeed, from poetry is a judgment/wisdom) with Damma and Sukun on the Kaf. Its interpretation in my view, if narrated this way: That from poetry is what binds the one spoken of like the binding of a legal judgment on the judged, hitting the meaning and aiming for correctness. Regarding something like this, Abu Tammam says: [Poem in Tawil meter] Were it not for a path established by poetry, seekers of high status would not know... from where noble deeds are approached. You see wisdom in what is in it while it is amusement... and it judges for what it judges while it is unjust. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying: I read it to Khalaf, so he told me that he heard it from Abu Amr al-Shaybani and others, that Abdullah ibn Mas'ud al-Fazari and Amr ibn Hubayrah al-Sakuni discussed poetry in the presence of Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan. Al-Sakuni said: Imru' al-Qays is the most poetic of people. Al-Fazari said: Nay, indeed among us are poets whom I do not think anyone reaches, until the argument between them reached a point where they said: 'You decide between us, O Commander of the Faithful.' So he said to Al-Sakuni: 'Recite to me from them.' But he found no narration with him. So Al-Qazari (Al-Fazari) said: 'I will recite to you from them. His cousin says: [Poem in Tawil meter] So I became bidding farewell to youth, except that I... observe four traits from people. Among them is my visitor, the young woman, dew has wetted her... watching a nursing infant adorned with amulets. My suspicion is hard on her and her crying grieves her... so she bends the neck lest it smells (or spreads). And his cousin who says: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a nursing mother or weaner I visited at night... so I distracted her from an infant with amulets, crying. When he cried in his cradle, she turned to him... with a half, while under me her half did not turn. And Mu'awiyah says: 'Uff to him.' He said: And my cousin who says: [Poem in Basit meter] And I do not oppose my neighbor regarding his wife... nor my cousin if he is assassinated (taken unawares). And I do not sharpen my fingernails to slap him... Indeed insulting and bad speech are borne. And I do not say, while the water has an excess breath... from heat, that the water is occupied. And I am not a tie for the provision, withholding it... while I have known that provision is to be eaten. Until it is said, while I have been elevated in a litter... that Ibn Awf Abu Quran is made (generous/noble).' Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying: I read it to Khalaf, so he told me that he heard it narrated from Al-Zuhri that he said: I used to go to Ubayd Allah ibn Abdullah to write from him. I would stand for him when he came out and arrange his clothes on him when he rode, until I thought I had exhausted what he had. He came out one day and I did not stand for him. He said to me: 'You are in the rough ground (Al-'Azaz), so stand.' Abu al-Qasim: 'Al-'Azaz': What is hard of the earth, and it is only at the edges of lands and beginnings of roads, but if you are in the middle, you come to softness and ease. So he says to him: 'You are still in the beginnings of sciences and have not reached their middle, so return to what you were on of organization and honoring me.' Al-Akhfash informed us from Al-Mubarrad, saying some of Al-Fakhdhami's companions told me from him that he said: There was a Bedouin woman who had four sons. Four brothers, peers of her sons in age, used to pass by her, and she would find comfort in them. Then her sons were afflicted (died). The brothers stopped visiting her to spare her from sadness when she saw them. Then they resolved a resolve to pass by her out of joy and maintaining ties. When she saw them, she began to say: [Poem in Kamil meter]

The peers will not delay to separate... night and day cycle upon them. Then one of them fell ill and died, so the three cut her off for a time, then they passed by her. She began to say: [Poem in Sari' meter] All sons of a mother, even if numerous... one day they will become one. Then one of them fell ill and died, so the two cut her off for a time, then they passed by her. She said: [Poem in Wafir meter] And every brother, his brother departs from him... by your father's life, except the two Farqads (stars). Then one of them fell ill and died, then the remaining one passed by her. She began to say: [Poem in Sari' meter] And the single individual is like the one who has passed... neither left behind nor immortal. He said to her: 'Accept me, may I be your ransom, for by Allah I am not returning.' Abu al-Qasim said: As for his saying 'Al-Farqadan' (The two Farqads), he raised it (nominative) because he made 'illa' (except) serve as 'kull' (all) and carried it on the meaning of 'ghayr' (other than). As if he said: And every brother *other than* the two Farqads, his brother departs from him. And 'illa' can be an adjective for indefinite nouns because it resembles 'ghayr', like your saying: 'Law kana ma'ana rajulun illa Zaydun lahalakna' (If there were a man with us except Zayd, we would have perished), or as Allah Almighty said: (If there were in them gods except Allah, they would have been corrupted) [Quran 21:22]. Sibawayh said: This is an adjective, and the meaning is: If there were in them gods *other than* Allah, they would have been corrupted. And he recited: [Poem in Basit meter] If there were *other than* me for Sulayma today, *other than* him... the falling of accidents except the sharp sword. Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Ahwal recited to us by Bishr ibn Hudhayl al-Fazari: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a blamer woman woke up at night blaming me... and a blamer did not miss me before that. She says: 'Go slow, let not people see you destitute... and it disgraces who you support, O son of the nobles.' So I said: 'A noble soul refused upon me... and a night visitor says other than that.' He traveled in the darkness of the night, his garment struck by... a 'Dhara'iyyah' (wind/rain) driving the frost in a wet wind. And it was said: 'So-and-so or So-and-so', and a north wind blew with a cold cloudless sky in a wet wind. For I am not ashamed if it is said 'destitute... generous', and it is more fitting that it be said 'miser'. So if my reach is not long, then I... am a reacher for it with righteous traits. If I am among the tall people, I surpass them... with a favor until it is said 'tall'. And how many have we seen of many branches... dying if roots do not give them life. And if matters turn moderate among men, then I... when a matter settles in my courtyard, am great. And do not look at what pleases the eye, but look... at the element of lineages, where it ends up. And there is no good in the beauty of bodies and their height... if minds do not weigh the beauty of bodies. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Mumliq': The poor. Its derivation is from 'Al-Malaqah', which is the smooth rock to which nothing clings. Its plural is 'Malaqat'. Ibn al-Sikit recited: [Poem in Wafir meter] A small sturdy [camel] with a sound was destined for her... when she bargained on the smooth rocks, she bargained. 'Al-Dhara'iyyah': A cloud that originated during the Nau' (star setting) of Al-Dhira', or a wind that blew at its heel. 'Al-Saqit': Frost and snow. 'Al-Balil': The cold wind. 'Al-Jaham': The cloud that has no water. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us from Al-Riyashi, saying: A wolf used to come to the people of Qaran and harm them in their fruits. A hunter came to them and said: 'What will you give me if I catch him?' They said: 'A sheep from every flock.' He said: So he went and brought him, having tied him. They shouted 'Allahu Akbar' and began to laugh at him. He sensed betrayal from them, so he cut the rope and the wolf leaped. They leaped on him to kill him. He said: 'No harm on you, if you fulfill [the promise] to me, I will bring him back.' So they released him to bring him back. He left saying: [Poem in Basit meter] I attached a rope to the wolf then said to him... 'O catch up with your family and be safe, O wolf. If you were from the people of Qaran, then return to them... or Al-Kanizah, then go unsought.' He asked him how the best of his living was... He said: 'Passing through terrors, feared.' Al-Nahl, I am called by it as long as it has fresh dates... and if I winter, then among the sheep of the Bedouins. Some people narrate it—and it is from the narration of Qutrub—: [Poem in Basit meter] Either you lead a sheep with it so we eat it... or you sell it in some of the Bedouin [lands]. As for his saying: 'Ya al-haq bi-ahlika' (O catch up with your family): He intended: 'O this one, catch up with your family', so he implied the vocative object, as Allah Mighty and Majestic said: (Only that they prostrate to Allah) [Quran 27:25]. Just as the poet said: [Poem in Basit meter] O curse of Allah and all the people... and the righteous upon Sam'an from a neighbor.

As for his saying: 'fa-ud lahum' (so return to them), this is the [correct] way with Sukun on the Dal and lightening, because it is from 'ada ya'udu' (to return). Some narrated it: 'fa-udda lahum' with Tashdid (counting), and its explanation in my view is that he intended pausing on it, then transferred it for that reason, then treated the connection like the pause, as Sibawayh recited: [Rajaz] I feared that I would see drought (jadaba)... in this year of ours after it was fertile. And as he said: [Sari'] Huge, loving the huge creation (al-adkhama). As for his saying: 'kayfa kanat khayra 'ishatihi' (how was the best of his living). He made 'khayr' feminine because he added it to 'ishah' (living) and it is part of it, as they said: 'dhahabat ba'du asabi'ihi' (some of his fingers went [fem.]), and 'takharraqat ba'du hullatihi' (some of his suit tore [fem.]). As for his saying: 'faqala madin 'ala al-ahwali marhubun' (He said: passing through terrors, feared). That is from the anomalies of the Arabs, as the other said: [Wafir] So the sayers said to those I protected... so the listeners said: 'He has a vizier.' Its interpretation: 'The protected one has a vizier.' Like the saying of Allah Almighty: (And when it is said to them, "What has your Lord sent down?" They say, "Legends of the former peoples") [Quran 16:24]. Yunus said: They did not affirm that Allah sent down anything because it is mentioning the disbelievers, so they cut the answer and started [newly] and said: '(This is) legends of the former peoples.' 'Al-Nahl' is a place name, and in another narration: 'Al-Nakhl' (The Palm trees). Its most inhabited is what has fresh dates... And 'Al-Rutab': What is moist of plants, and it is 'Al-Khala' also shortened. And 'Al-Hashish': What is dry. And 'Al-Kala'' combines them. As for his saying: 'aw an tabi'ahu' (or that you sell it). He intended 'tabi'aha' (sell her/the sheep), so he deleted the Alif, and it is anomalous with no parallel in the speech of the Arabs, because only Ya and Waw connected to the pronoun are deleted, and Alif is not deleted due to its lightness. Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abd al-Rahman informed me from his uncle, and Abu Hatim from Abu Ubaydah, they said: There was a woman among the Arabs possessing beauty, perfection, lineage, and wealth. She swore she would not marry herself except to a generous man, and if a mean man proposed to her, she would cut off his nose. People avoided her until Zayd al-Khayl, Hatim ibn Abdullah, and Aws ibn Harithah ibn La'm al-Ta'i proposed to her. They traveled to her. When they entered upon her, she said: 'Welcome to you, you were not visitors [before], so what brought you?' They said: 'We came as visitors, suitors.' She said: 'Competent, noble ones.' She lodged them, separated them, and lavished hospitality on them and increased it. When it was the second day, she sent some of her slave girls disguised as beggars exposing themselves to them. Zayd and Aws gave her half of what was carried to each of them. When she came to Hatim's saddle, he gave her all the expenses he had and loaded with her all that was carried to him. When it was the third day, they entered upon her. She said: 'Let each of you describe himself in his poetry.' Zayd hastened and recited saying: [Poem in Basit meter] Have you not asked Banu Dhubyan what is my reckoning... at the stabbing when the throats turn red. And the horses came with their chest-meats reddened... with water pouring from their upper chests, blood. And the horses know that I was their knight... on the day of Al-Aks, having in it a horn of bravery. And the neighbor knows that I am not his forsaker... if a time befalls gnawing at the bone of the neighbor. This is the praise, so if you are pleased, then [be] pleased... or if you are angry, then to me belongs whoever bends the neck. Aws ibn Harithah said: 'You know that we are more noble in lineage and more famous in deeds than to describe ourselves to you. I am the one about whom the poet says: [Poem in Wafir meter] To Aws ibn Harithah ibn La'm... to fulfill my need, and indeed he fulfilled it. No one has trodden the pebbles like Ibn Sa'da... nor wore sandals nor put them on.' 'And I am the one whose 'Aqiqah' was slaughtered, so a soul (slave) was freed for every hair of it.' Then he recited saying: [Poem in Tawil meter] So if you marry, O Mawiyah of Goodness, Hatim... then there is no one like him among us nor among the non-Arabs. Diverse, Time does not cease to be his greatest concern... ransoming a prisoner or aiding a debtor. And if you marry Zayd, then the knight of his people... when war one day makes every stander sit. And the companion of Nabhan, by whom is protected... the harm of the matter when it becomes great and aggravated. And do not marry me, [lest] you marry a non-sinner... nor a sweeper sweeping the clan, destroying. Nor one fearing a day when war tucks up... about ourselves, myself like the action of the ill-omened. And if a night-visitor of guests seeks refuge at his saddle... you will find Ibn Sa'da not delaying hospitality. So whichever youth Allah has gifted you, accept... for we are nobles from the heads of nobles. And Hatim recited saying: [Poem in Tawil meter] O Mawiyah, avoidance and abandonment have become long... and an excuse has excused me in seeking you. O Mawiyah, as for a preventer, it is clear... and as for a giving, rebuking does not restrain it.

O Mawiyah, wealth does not avail the youth... when [the soul] rattles one day and the chest becomes tight with it. And the people have known that if Hatim... wanted the abundance of wealth, he would have a surplus. Until he reached the end of the poem, and it is famous. She said: 'As for you, O Zayd, you have wronged the Arabs, and your staying with a free woman is little. As for you, O Aws, you are a man of co-wives, and entering upon them is difficult. As for you, O Hatim, you are of pleasing character, praiseworthy traits, generous soul, and I have married myself to you.' Niftawayh informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us from Ibn al-A'rabi, saying: The Arabs say: Saltiness (Malahah) is in the mouth, Sweetness (Halawah) is in the eyes, and Beauty (Jamal) is in the nose. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Bawadir': The flesh between the shoulders and the neck, singular is 'Badirah', and likewise 'Al-Ba'adil', singular is 'Badil'. 'Al-'Alaq': Blood. 'Al-Kashar': Shortness of teeth and their sticking to their roots; it is said from it: A man is 'Akshar'. 'Al-Bal': Length of the front teeth, and likewise 'Al-Rawq'. Abu Abdullah al-Yazidi informed us, saying my uncle Al-Fadl ibn Muhammad informed me, saying Sulayman ibn Abdullah ibn Tahir recited to me by his father: [Poem in Tawil meter] Indeed, man is but a sheath for his heart... and there is no good in a sheath if there is no blade. So if a man has a heart, then his heart... is the blade, and the human after that is surplus. Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abd al-Rahman informed me from his uncle, saying: A Bedouin stood before Marwan ibn al-Hakam while he was allotting [stipends] to the people in Medina. He said to him: 'Allot for me.' He said: 'We have folded the book.' He said: 'Allot for me.' He said: 'We have folded the book.' He said: 'Do you not know that I am the one who said: [Poem in Wafir meter] If the generous is shaken, he increases in good... and if the mean is shaken, he does not increase.' Marwan said to him: 'I conjure you by Allah, are you the one who said it?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Allot for him.' Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abd al-Rahman informed me from Al-Asma'i, saying: My uncle used to see bad omens in me and regard me as unlucky. Necessity used to call me to meet him to read to him, so I would not come to him until he finished his prayer. I came early one day while he was praying the morning prayer. I sat until he finished his prayer, then he turned to me and said: 'Abd al-Rahman, I seek refuge in Allah from you.' Then he turned his face to the right side, so I stood and sat opposite him. He turned his face to his left side, so I stood and sat opposite him. He turned his face away from me and put his back to me, so I stood and sat opposite him. He said: 'Bring what you have, O cursed one, and read it.' Then he recited saying: [Poem in Majzu' al-Raml] The eye's looking at this... lines the eye with a disease. Lord, You have given him to us... and he is of the worst giving. Naked, O Lord, take him... in a shirt and a cloak. Abu Ja'far Ahmad ibn Abdullah ibn Muslim ibn Qutaybah informed us, saying my father informed me, saying Al-Sijistani informed me, saying: I was with Al-Akhfash Sa'id ibn Mas'adah and Al-Tawwazi was with him. Al-Tawwazi said: 'What have you done regarding the Book of Masculine and Feminine, O Abu Hatim?' I said: 'We have collected something of it.' He said: 'So what do you say about Al-Firdaws?' I said: 'It is masculine.' He said: 'But Allah says: (Those who inherit Al-Firdaws, they will abide therein [fiha - fem.]) [Quran 23:11].' I said: 'He went to the meaning of Paradise (Al-Jannah - fem.), so He made it feminine, just as the Almighty said: (Whoever comes with a good deed will have ten like it [amthaliha - fem.]) [Quran 6:160], so He made it feminine while 'Mithl' (like) is masculine, because He went to the meaning of good deeds (Hasanat - fem.). And as Ibn Abi Rabi'ah said: [Poem in Tawil meter] So my shield was, before who I was fearing... three figures (shukhus - masc.), two buxom girls and a pubescent girl. So he made it feminine [implied in context of adjectives 'ka'iban'] while 'Shukhus' is masculine because he went to the [meaning of] women, and clarified that by his saying "two buxom girls and a pubescent girl". And as the other said: [Poem in Tawil meter] And indeed these Kilab are ten bellies (abtun - masc.)... and you are innocent of its ten tribes. So he made 'Batn' feminine while it is masculine because he meant by it the tribe.' He said to me: 'O heedless one, people say: I ask You for the Highest Firdaws (Al-Firdaws Al-A'la - masc.).' I said: 'O sleeping one, this is my proof, because 'Al-A'la' is of the attributes of masculine because it is 'Af'al', and if it were feminine He would have said 'Al-'Ulya' as 'Al-Akbar' and 'Al-Kubra', and 'Al-Asghar' and 'Al-Sughra' are said.' So he fell silent in shame. Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Mahmud al-Wasiti informed us from Ahmad ibn Salih from Abd al-Razzaq from Ma'mar, saying: I asked Abu Amr ibn al-A'la about 'Al-'Athan', what is it? He remained silent for an hour then said: 'It is smoke without fire.' Abu al-Qasim said: It is said it is smoke ('Dukhan') and its plural is 'Dawakhin', and 'Al-'Athan' and its plural is 'Awathin', and no parallel is known for them in plurals because 'Fu'al' is not pluralized as 'Fawa'il' except these two letters. And smoke is called 'Al-Dukh' and 'Al-Dakh' and 'Al-Nuhas'. Ibn al-A'rabi recited to us: It shines like the lamp of oil... Allah did not put 'Nuhas' (smoke) in it. And he also recited: [Rajaz] There is no good in the Sheikh when he becomes crooked (ijlakha)... and the tear duct of his eye flows and creates gum (lakhaha).

And he was eating all of it and defecating (shakkha)... under the portico of the house covering the smoke (dukha). Abu al-Qasim said: 'Ijlakha': Became crooked. 'Lakkha' says: His eye stuck together. 'Shakkha': Says his excrement increased. 'Yaghsha al-Dukh': Says he covers the oven saying: Feed me. Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Al-Sijistani informed us from Al-Asma'i, saying: I said to some Bedouins: 'Which days are coldest?' He said: 'Al-Ahass al-Ward' and 'Al-Azibb al-Halluf'. I said: 'Explain it to me.' He said: 'Al-Ahass al-Ward' is a day whose north wind clears, its atmosphere turns red, and its sun rises, but the one who comes to it never ceases [to feel cold] because you do not find a touch [warmth] for it. And 'Al-Azibb al-Halluf' is a day in which its crosswind blows driving the waterless clouds. Ibn Durayd said: The origin of 'Hasas' is lack of hair, so as if when there were no clouds in it, he likened it to the red bald/hairless one. And 'Al-Halluf' is the camel with much fur; it is said: A 'Hallufah' beard if it is thick with hair. So he likened it to the clouds in it with this. 'Al-Jaham': Clouds with no water. Niftawayh informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us, saying Ibn Najdah informed me from Abu Zayd al-Ansari, saying: The Arabs call the two months of cold: Shayban and Milhan, due to what is seen in them of the whiteness of snow and frost. The derivation of Shayban is from 'Shayb' (gray hair) and Milhan from 'Milh' (salt). They are also called the months of 'Qimah' because water in them is disliked and abandoned, taken from 'Muqamaha' of camels, which is when they are brought to water but do not drink and raise their heads. Bishr ibn Abi Khazim said describing a ship he and his companions were in: [Poem in Wafir meter] And we are on its sides sitting... lowering the gaze like the camels refusing to drink (Qimah). The scholars of Anwa' (weather stars) claim that the duration of these two months is from the setting of Pleiades and the rising of Al-Iklil to the setting of Al-Sarf and the rising of Sa'd Bula', and those are five Anwa'. He said: And the Arabs call the opposites of these two months in heat and its intensity the days of Najir, taken from 'Najr' which is severe thirst. Dhul-Rummah said describing water he arrived at: [Poem in Tawil meter] Stagnant, altered water, the man turns his face from it... even if a thirsty man tasted it in the month of Najir. He made them wish for the fifth [day watering] and the fifth after it... and for settling and traveling the days of Najir. He repeated the rhyme twice because he committed 'Ita' (repetition) in his poetry, and the Arabs call this 'Ita'. Al-Suli recited to us, saying Ibn al-Mu'tazz recited to us for himself: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a night, those warming themselves by its fire wished... if only they were its fuel until the morning. I raised my fire in it for the one seeking hospitality... on a high place until its delegations came to me. Al-Suli said: And Tha'lab recited to me, saying Ibn al-A'rabi recited to me: [Rajaz] Your night, O lighter, is a night of cold... and the wind with that has a screech. Light [the fire], whoever passes sees your fire... if you brought a guest, you are free. Abu Ghanim al-Ma'nawi recited to us: [Poem in Munsarih meter] A day of bitter cold (*Zamharir*), chilly... upon it the pocket of the sky is buttoned. And its sun is a secluded free woman... having no light due to fog. As if the atmosphere, its filling is needles... and the earth beneath it is glass bottles. Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Tha'lab recited to us for Nuwayfi' ibn Nufay', saying: [Poem in Kamil meter] A south wind departed for its intent in the morning... and you were moved with joy, while you did not know you were joyful. And we were neighbors, and she abandons our house... until she departs or it is said [he is] suspicious. And visiting the house in which is not sought... other than their conversation is defective. And youth sways with me to childish passion... sometimes, then experience judges my opinion. And the young girl pillowed me her right hand... and her left, the plump, tender one. Protruding of the rear, you do not see for her ankles... a sharpness, and her shin has no shinbone edge. Her buttocks became large and her creation complete... and the two parents are a noble woman and a noble man. When gray hair unloaded its weights upon me... and I knew that my youth was the stolen one. She said: 'You have aged, and every owner of pleasure... Layla, returns, and that is the graying.' Is there for me a doctor for the destroying old age... so I return naive, and youth is wonderful. My peers and youth have gone, so I have no... counterpart among those you see of people. And when the years persist in seeking the youth... the years catch up and the sought is overtaken. So away with you! For no knower knows... from where his written fortune is gathered. The youth strives to attain the best of his endeavor... Far is that! And before that are calamities. He strives and hopes while death is behind him... ascending the hills, having a watcher over him. Neither is death despising of the small so turning... away from him, nor is the age of the old respected.
