And if I have aged, I have lived long as if I were... a branch the winds shade, moist. And likewise truly whoever lives long, the turning... of time upon him and the overturning wears him out. Until he returns from decay as if he is... in the hand, a broken arrow-notch, without head, bound. Stripped of feathers, there is no artifice in it... neither the feathers benefit it nor the binding. Shu'ub (Death) went with his family and his wealth... Indeed deaths are Shu'ub (separators) for men. And the man, from the doubt of time, is as if he is... a camel the shepherds took turns on, ridden. A target for every death shot at... until his erected blackness (person) is hit. Abu al-Qasim said: Nothing came in the speech of the Arabs pluralized on 'Fi'al' except six letters. That is their saying: 'Zi'r' and 'Zi'ar' (wet nurse), 'Anz Rubba' and 'A'nuz Ribab': for the newly birthing, 'Tu'am' and 'Tu'am' (twin), 'Arq' and 'Iraq' (sweat/root?), 'Rakhl' and 'Rikhal' (female lamb), and 'Farir' and 'Firar': for the calf of the wild cow. And among what came as dual and no singular was articulated for it is their saying: He came striking his 'Azdarayh' (shoulders/sides), if he came empty-handed. Likewise he came striking his 'Asdarayh'. And it is said of a man if he threatens and there is nothing behind that: He came shaking his 'Mudhrawayh', and it is also said like that if he came empty with nothing with him. And it is said: 'Al-Shiyy' (Listening/Look?), 'Hawalayna' (around us) in the dual form only, and no singular was isolated for it except in anomalous poetry. [Rajaz] They demolished your house, may you have no father... and they claimed that I, may I have no maternal uncle. And I walk the wolf-walk around you (*Hawalaka*). And from that: 'Dawalayka', and the meaning is turn after turn, and no singular is isolated for it. Abd Bani al-Has-has said: [Poem in Tawil meter] As if the Subayri women, the day they met us... were gazelles that lent their gaze to the wild cows. And they are the daughters of the people; if they sense us... there will be among the daughters of the people one of the calamities. How many a shining cloak we have torn... and a veil from a young girl, not a spinster. If a garment is torn, the like of it is torn with the garment... turn after turn (*Dawalayka*) until all of us are not wearing. And from that is 'Hananayk', and its meaning is compassion after compassion. It is only used like this, accusative in the dual form because it is a verbal noun (Masdar). And 'Dadd' was singularized and used established. Sibawayh recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] So Hanan (Compassion) said: What brought you here... are you of lineage or do you know the tribe? Its estimation is: Our matter is compassion (*Hananun*), so he raised it as inchoative and predicate. The meaning of 'Hanan' is mercy and affection. And from that is 'Hadhadhayk', he only means cutting (*Hadhdhan*) after cutting. 'Al-Hadhdh' is cutting, and its singular is used. Sibawayh recited: [Split Rajaz] A striking (*Hadhadhayk*) and stabbing and piercing. And from that is 'Labbayk' and 'Sa'dayk'. They are only used like this in the dual form. Sibawayh said: I asked Al-Khalil about its derivation and meaning. He said: The meaning of 'Labbayk' is from 'Al-Ilbab'. It is said 'Alabba al-rajulu bi-al-makan ilbaban': If he stayed in it. So if he says 'Labbayk', it is as if he said: I am staying upon Your obedience and at Your command. And 'Sa'dayk' is taken from 'Al-Is'ad', and 'Al-Is'ad' and 'Al-Musa'adah' (assistance) are the same. So if he says to Allah Mighty and Majestic 'Labbayk wa Sa'dayk' in the Talbiyah, it is as if he said: I am staying at Your command and following it, so he has drawn near to Him by his desire not his body. This is the meaning of Al-Khalil's saying and his explanation. Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Mahmud al-Wasiti told us, saying Muhammad ibn Isra'il al-Jawhari told us, saying Mu'awiyah told us from his father from Qatadah from Abd al-Malik ibn Umayr from some of Banu Abi al-Mu'alla: A man from the Ansar from his father from his grandfather said: The Prophet (PBUH) said while on the pulpit: 'Indeed my foot is upon a 'Tur'ah' (step/basin) of the 'Tur'as' of the Haud (Basin).' And he said: 'Indeed a servant from the servants of Allah, Allah gave him the choice between living in the world as long as he wishes to live and eating from the world as long as he wishes to eat, and between meeting his Lord. So the servant chose meeting his Lord.' He said: So Abu Bakr wept when he said it: We ransom you, O Messenger of Allah, with our fathers. Abu al-Qasim said: And the narration is connected from more than one path that the Prophet (PBUH) said this in his illness in which he died, announcing his death to his companions. And this Hadith has another wording. Abu Abdullah ibn Muhammad al-Razi told us from Ali ibn Abd al-Aziz from Abu Ubayd al-Qasim ibn Sallam, saying Isma'il ibn Ja'far ibn Amr ibn Alqamah told me regarding this: Upon a 'Tur'ah' of the 'Tur'as' of Paradise. Abu al-Qasim said: And scholars have three opinions regarding 'Al-Tur'ah': Abu Amr al-Shaybani said: 'Al-Tur'ah': The step/degree. And others said 'Al-Tur'ah': The door. And Abu Ubaydah said 'Al-Tur'ah': The garden (Rawdah) that is in a high place specifically. If it is in a low place, it is a 'Rawdah'. He recites for Al-A'sha: [Poem in Basit meter] Not a garden ('Rawdah') of the gardens of the rugged ground, grassy... green, upon which a pouring rain was generous.

A bright star laughs at the sun from it... wrapped in dense plants, mature. [Not] a day more pleasant than her in spreading scent... nor more beautiful than her when the evening approached. Al-Asma'i said: Abu Amr ibn al-A'la said: Nothing has been said in describing the beauty of women and the goodness of their scent better than this poetry nor more eloquent. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying Al-Mada'ini said: It was narrated from Ali ibn Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: The rational person must have three qualities: To be knowing of his time, master of his tongue, attentive to his affair. And Umar ibn al-Khattab said: Whoever his manners sit him down (hold him back), his lineage will not raise him up. And Abu Bakr al-Siddiq said: Piety is the lineage (Hasab). Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abu Hatim informed us, saying Abu Ubaydah informed me, saying: Al-Kumayt went out to Aban ibn Abdullah al-Bajali while he was over Khurasan, so he made him among his night-companions. Al-Kumayt had envy. While he was one night chatting with him, Aban dozed off, and the people debated about generosity and munificence. One of them said: Generosity died the day Al-Fayyad (generous one) died. He raised his voice, so Al-Bajali woke up and said: 'What are you discussing?' Al-Kumayt said: [Poem in Khafif meter] Al-Nadr, Al-Mughira, Al-Nu'man, Al-Buhturi, and Ibn Iyad claimed... He said: 'Woe to you! What did they claim, O Abu al-Mustahill?' He said: That the generosity of mankind died entirely... the day the death of Al-Fayyad went. He said: 'So what did you say to them, O Abu al-Mustahill?' He said: I said: They lied, by the One whom the riders answer... quickly in the wide open spaces. Dew and generosity do not die as long as... Aban lives, the rain of the destitute. So if the God calls Aban... He announces that generosity after him is extinct. He said to him: 'You have done well, so ask your need.' He said: 'You give me ten thousand dirhams for every verse.' He said: 'I will do it and increase you ten thousand from myself.' So he ordered sixty thousand dirhams for him. Al-Akhfash informed me, saying my father informed me from my grandfather from Isma'il ibn Nubakht, saying: Abu Nuwas aimed for one of the Nubakhtis among the scribes. Some ancestors of that scribe used to write for some of the Chosroes. Chosroes became angry at some of his concubines, so he handed her to that Nubakhti scribe and ordered him to kill her. He disliked killing her, and the King's soul followed (desired) her, and he feared that if he kept her alive, he would accuse him regarding her. So he kept her alive and castrated himself. Then the King's soul followed her, so he carried her to him, and informed him of what he did to himself. He considered that great and said: 'Your reward is nothing but that I gather my elite and seat you on my neck.' The King's ministers envied him and said to him: 'This is ugly, but let the King order that a crown be crafted for him and his image be depicted in it, then place it on his head.' He did so. So Abu Nuwas said mentioning this story: [Poem in Kamil meter] What need does 'Alaq al-Huda' have in its success... compared to a need attached to Abu Tammam? Indeed men saw your father with eyes... lined for them with the kohl-sticks of bones. So if you extend a hand to me with a gift... I have indeed shaken you the shake of the sharp sword. So he sent him four thousand dirhams, and he did not own other than them. Ibn Shuqayr informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us from Ibn Shabbah, saying: Ramlah bint Ubayd Allah ibn Ma'mar was married to Hisham ibn Sulayman ibn Abd al-Malik. One day a conversation occurred between them, and he said to her: 'You are a mule, you do not give birth.' So she said: 'Shh! My nobility refuses to mix with your baseness.' Abu al-Abbas said: Similar to this among silencing answers is what is narrated about Al-Khansa when she entered upon Aisha and recited to her her saying about her brother Sakhr: [Poem in Wafir meter] O Sakhr, if you have made my eye weep... you have indeed made me laugh for a long time. I wept for you among wailing women... and I was the most deserving of those who showed wailing. I repelled calamities with you while you were alive... so who will repel the great calamity? When weeping over a killed one is ugly... I saw your weeping as good and beautiful. So Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said to her: 'Do you weep for Sakhr while he is a coal in the Fire?' She said: 'O Mother of the Believers: That is stronger for my grief over him and more inciting for my weeping.' Ibn Durayd recited to us, saying Abd al-Rahman recited to us from his uncle by Muhammad ibn Bashir ibn Adwan: [Poem in Kamil meter] What an excellent youth his brothers were bereaved of... on the day of Al-Baqi' by the accidents of days. Easy of courtyard when you settle at his door... open-handed, having disciplined servants. And if you saw his full brother and his friend... you would not know which of them are the possessors of wombs (relatives). Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi, saying: 'Al-Fasit' with Fa: Nail clipping. 'Al-Saffit' with the delayed Fa: The generous man. 'Al-Saqit' with Qaf: The foolish man. 'Al-Safit' also: Snow and frost. 'Al-Rabit': The monk. And 'Al-Arbat': The fool.

And the Arabs say: So-and-so, due to his gluttony (*shartatihi*), does not know his 'Latta' from his 'Lahat'. And some of them say: He does not know his 'Qata' from his 'Latta'. 'Al-Qata': The anus. 'Al-Latta': The forehead. 'Al-Batit': Wonder. 'Al-Atit': Hunger. 'Al-Atit' also: The sound of the stretching of leather and similar things. 'Al-Hadirah': The small group raiding. He recites: [Poem in Kamil meter] He comes to the waters as a raiding group (*Hadirah*) and a scout group (*Nafidah*)... the coming of the sandgrouse when the shadow (*al-Taba'*) shrinks (*isma'alla*). 'Al-Taba'': The shadow. 'Isma'alla': Shrunk. Abu Ja'far Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Rustam al-Tabari informed us, saying Al-Mazini informed us, saying: I was with Al-Akhfash and Al-Riyashi was with us. Al-Akhfash said: That 'Mudh' (since), if nominative is used with it, it is an inchoative noun and what follows it is a predicate, like your saying: 'I haven't seen him *mudh yawmani* (since two days).' And if genitive is used with it, it is a preposition particle, a meaning not a noun, like your saying: 'I haven't seen him *mudh al-yawmi* (since today).' Al-Riyashi said: 'Why shouldn't it be a noun in both places? For we see nouns taking accusative and genitive, like our saying: This is *daribu Zaydin* (hitter of Zayd) *amsi* (yesterday). So why shouldn't *Mudh* be in this status?' Al-Akhfash did not bring a convincing answer. So I said: '*Mudh* does not resemble what you mentioned of nouns, because we have not seen nouns sticking to one position like this unless they resemble meaning particles like *Ayna* (where) and *Kayfa* (how). Likewise *Mudh* resembles particles, so it stuck to one position.' Abu Ja'far said: So Abu Ya'la ibn Abi Zur'ah said to Al-Mazini: 'Have you seen a meaning particle performing two opposing functions?' He said: 'Yes, like your saying: The people stood *hasha Zaydin* (except Zayd - genitive) and *hasha Zaydan* (accusative verb meaning), and *ala Zaydin thawbun* (on Zayd is a garment - prep), and *ala Zaydun al-jabala* (Zayd ascended the mountain - verb). So it is once a particle and once a verb with one wording.' Abu al-Qasim said: This which Abu Uthman said is correct, except that he was obliged to clarify which particle *Mudh* resembled? Just as we knew that *Mata* and *Kayfa* resemble the Hamza of interrogation. And to clarify what is the mode of nominative with *Mudh* and what is the operator in it? The saying in that is that *Mudh*, when genitive is used with it in your saying: 'I haven't seen him *mudh al-yawmi*', resembles *Min* (from) because *Min* is for the beginning of limits, and *Mudh*, if the Nun is with it (*Mundhu*), is for the beginning of limits in time specifically. So *Mudh* occurred with the meaning of *Mundhu* in this place. And *Mundhu* is in the status of *Min*, so their resemblance is clear. As for the saying regarding the nominative with it in your saying: 'I haven't seen him *mudh yawmani*', this is not valid except as two sentences, because if you made the seeing fall upon *Mudh*, it would be cut off from what follows it and it would have no nominative operator. But it is on the estimation of your saying: 'I haven't seen him', then you say to the speaker: 'How long is the duration of that?' He says: 'Two days', i.e., the duration of that is two days. So he raised it as inchoative and predicate. Niftawayh informed us, saying Tha'lab said: Some of our companions asked me about the saying of the poet: [Rajaz] She brought it ashy, baked in hot ash (*mamulla*)... not raw (*ma niyya*) *allin* (?), *khamma* (?) when *ala* (?). I did not know what he was saying, so I went to Ibn al-A'rabi and asked him about it. He explained it to me saying: This describes a loaf of bread a woman baked but did not cook thoroughly. He said: 'She brought it *murammadan* i.e., soiled with ash. *Mamulla* in the *Mallah*, which is the embers and hot ash. Then he said: *Ma niyya allin*: *Ma* is extra, as if he said *Niyya*. And *Al-All*: Its face, meaning the face of the loaf. And his saying *khamma*: Means it changed/spoiled. *Hina ala* i.e., when she was slow in cooking. It is said *ala al-rajulu*: If he slackened and slowed in work. He recited: [Wafir] My sons did not slacken (*ma alu*) nor did they do evil. Al-Akhfash recited to us for Abu Nuwas: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a house of drinking companions they left empty and departed at night... in it is a trace of them, new and effaced. Drag marks of dragging waterskins on the soil... and bundles of basil, fresh and dry. My companions stopped me at it, so I renewed their covenant... and indeed I am at the likes of those, stopping. And I did not know what they were other than what testified to it... the balconies of the Sabat (covered passage) of the houses, the empty lands. We stayed in it a day and a day and its third... and a day to which the day of departure was a fifth. Wine is circulated among us in an 'Asjadiyyah' (golden cup)... which Persia endowed with types of pictures. Its bottom is Khosrow, and on its sides... are wild cows ('Maha') which horsemen drive with bows. So the wine covers what his pockets were buttoned over... and the water covers what the caps circled upon. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Dar': The dwelling of the people, whether built or unbuilt. And it is said:

'Dar' and 'Darah'. 'Al-Basabis': The wastelands, singular 'Basbas', and like it 'Al-Sabasib', singular 'Sabsab', and its origin is the wide smooth desert. 'Al-'Asjadiyyah': A cup made of 'Asjad' which is gold. His saying: 'Qararatuha Kisra' (Its bottom is Khosrow) is accusative as an adverb/place, meaning that in the bottom of the cup—which is its floor—was the picture of Khosrow. And on its sides, meaning its edges, was a picture of 'Maha' which are wild cows, and pictures of horsemen with bows and arrows in their hands shooting those Maha. This is the meaning of his saying 'Tudriha bi-al-qisiyyi al-fawaris'. 'Al-Dari'ah': The thing that is shot at. Meaning that he poured wine into the cup until it reached the picture of the throats of the horsemen, which is the place of the buttons. Then he poured water to the amount of the heads of the figures, which is what the caps cover. Isma'il al-Warraq told us, saying Ibrahim ibn Muhammad al-Basri in Mecca told us, saying Isma'il ibn Abdullah ibn Khalid told us from his father from his grandfather from Yunus ibn Yasar from Abu Huraira who said: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: 'Feed food, spread peace, and be, O servants of Allah, brothers as Allah commanded you. Do not practice Najsh (bidding up prices), do not turn your backs on one another, and let not some of you sell over the sale of others.' Abu al-Qasim said: The meaning of his saying: 'Do not practice Najsh' says: Let not one of you increase the price of a commodity if he does not intend to buy it, lest one who has no insight into the commodity looks at him and is deceived by him. The origin of 'Najsh' is: stirring up a thing, and from it is Al-Najashi. Muhammad ibn Ishaq used to say: The name Al-Najashi is the name of the king, like their saying Caesar and Heraclius, and it seems his name was Ashamah in their language and its interpretation in Arabic is 'Atiyyah' (Gift). His saying 'Do not turn your backs on one another' says: Do not cut off ties and do not abandon one another, for those abandoning each other, if each turns away from his companion, he has turned his back to him. It is said: 'Bi'tu al-shay'a': If you sold it and removed it from your hand. And 'Bi'tuhu': If you bought it. It is used for both opposites together. And it is said 'Aba'tu al-shay'a': If you offered it for sale. He recites: [Poem in Kamil meter] I was pleased with the boons of the Kumayt (horse), so whoever sells... a horse, our steed is not 'Mumba'' (sold/offered for sale). i.e., offered for sale. Abu al-Qasim al-Sa'igh informed us, saying Ibn Qutaybah informed us, saying: It was narrated that the delegation of Hamdan came to the Prophet (PBUH) and met him returning from Tabuk. Malik ibn Namat al-Hamdani stood up and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, a choice group (Nasiyah) from Hamdan from every settled and Bedouin [area], came to you on swift young camels, connected by the ropes of Islam, from the Mikhlaf of Kharif and Yam. The blame of a blamer does not take them in [the path of] Allah. Their covenant is not broken by the year of a barren drought (*Mahil*), nor a dark calamity (*Sawda' 'Anqafir*), as long as [Mount] La'la' stands, and the gazelle runs on the smooth land.' So the Prophet (PBUH) wrote to him: 'This is a writing from Muhammad the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to the Mikhlaf of Kharif and the people of Jinab al-Hadb and Hiqaf al-Raml with their delegate Malik ibn Namat and those of his people who embraced Islam. That for them is their rough ground (*'Azaz*), their low ground (*Wahata*), and their high ground (*Fira'*), as long as they establish prayer and give Zakat. They graze their *'Ilaf* (fodder/trees?) and eat their *'Afa'* (fruit?). And for us from their *Dif'* (camels) and *Siram* (palms/harvest) is what they handed over by pact and trust. And for them from the Sadaqah is the *Thalb* (old camel), the *Nab* (old she-camel), the *Fasil* (weaned camel), the *Farid* (old?) *Dajin* (domestic), and the *Kabsh al-Huwari*. And upon them is the *Saligh* (six-year-old) and the *Qarih* (five-year-old?).' His saying: 'Nasiyah'. He says we are a 'Nasiyah' from Hamdan, so he raised it because it is a predicate of a deleted inchoative. 'Al-Nasiyah': The chosen leaders. It is said: 'Intasaytu al-shay'a' if you chose it. Its origin is from 'Al-Nasiyah' (forelock) just as 'Al-Ru'asa' (leaders) is from 'Al-Ra's' (head). 'Al-Qulus': A group of 'Qalus', which is the young female camel. Al-Asma'i said: The 'Qalus' among she-camels is like the young woman among women, and the 'Jamal' is like the man, and the 'Ba'ir' is like the human, applying to male and female. 'Al-Nawaji': The swift ones, singular 'Najiyah'. 'Al-Naja'': Speed, lengthened and shortened. Some thieves of the regions said: [Rajaz] If you take the spoil, then speed, speed (*Al-Naja Al-Naja*)... Indeed I fear the seeker, the swift ostrich-like (*Al-Safanja*). Kharif and Yam are two tribes. 'Al-Mikhlaf' for the people of Yemen is like 'Al-Ajnad' for the people of Syria, 'Al-Kuwar' for the people of Iraq, 'Al-Tasasij' for the people of Ahwaz, and 'Al-Rasatitiq' for the people of Jibal. His saying: 'Their covenant is not broken by the year of a *Mahil* (barren one).' 'Al-Mahil': The slanderer/intriguer. It is said: 'Mahala bihi' to the Sultan. 'Al-Sawda' al-'Anqafir': The calamity. 'Al-Sunnah': The way/year (context implies year of drought or method). He wants that they do not deviate from the covenant due to the striving of a slanderer, nor due to a great hardship that befalls them. 'La'la'': A specific mountain. 'Al-Ya'fur': The calf of the cow/gazelle. 'Al-Sala'': The smooth earth. 'Al-Fira'': The tops of mountains and high things, singular 'Far'ah'. 'Al-Far'ah' in other contexts: The louse, and from it Hassan ibn al-Fari'ah. 'Al-Wahata': What is depressed of the earth. 'Al-'Azaz': What is hard of it, and it is like the skin. 'Al-Dif'': Camels, named so because what is used for warmth is taken from their fur. 'Al-Siram': Palm trees because they are harvested (*Tusram*), and it is possible that 'Al-Siram' is the dates themselves. 'Al-Thalb': The old male camel. 'Al-Nab': The old she-camel.

'Al-Farid': The old one that is not young. 'Al-Dajin': That which is fed in the house and not sent to pastures. 'Al-Sali' ' from cows and sheep is what completed and finished a year, and that is in the sixth year. 'Al-Qarih' is like it from horses. 'Al-Kabsh al-Huwari': Ibn Qutaybah mentioned that it is a type of ram with red skin, and I do not know from what it is derived since what is known in the language is that 'Al-Hawar' is whiteness, and from it the bleachers were called 'Hawariyun' for their whitening of clothes. Al-Yazidi informed us, saying my uncle Al-Fadl ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Muhammad al-Yazidi informed me from his father from his grandfather, saying: Some of our companions informed me saying: I passed in the region of Najd by a Bedouin girl as if she were a piece of the moon, looking with two large eyes with eyelashes like the primary feathers of the vulture. I never saw more perfect perfection than her. I stood looking at her and her beauty, and beside her was an old woman. The old woman said: 'What is your standing over this Najdi gazelle, when you have no share in it?' The girl said: 'Leave him, by Allah, O mother, let it be what Dhul-Rummah said: [Poem in Tawil meter] My two friends, my need from your passion passed me... and who consoles the soul except its friend? Dismount at Mayy's [abode] before distance casts... us a casting place, or before separation removes her. And even if it is only a stop for an hour... a little, for indeed a little of her is beneficial to me.' Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us, saying Hammad ibn Ishaq ibn Ibrahim al-Mawsili told me from his father, saying: A man from the family of Abu Ja'far loved a singing girl. Her matter became long for him and her cost heavy. So he said one day to some of his brothers: 'This one has distracted me from many of my affairs, so come with us to her so I may reveal myself to her and leave her, for I have found some solace.' When he came to her, he said to her: 'Do you sing the saying of the poet: [Poem in Wafir meter] I used to love you, but I have found solace from you... Peace be upon you in your dwellings.' She said: 'No, but I sing the saying of the sayer: [Poem in Wafir meter] Her people departed from me so they separated... upon traces which the dust has obliterated.' The youth became shy and lowered his head and increased in wonder and fondness for her. He said to her: 'Do you sing the saying of the sayer: [Poem in Tawil meter] And I submit to the blame if I was unjust... and if I was wronged, I was the one who apologizes.' She said: 'Yes, and the saying of the sayer: [Poem in Tawil meter] If you approach with love, we approach with the like... and if you turn away, I go to a worn-out state.' So they broke up in two verses and united in two verses, and no one was aware of them. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying: I entered in my youth, I and a friend of mine from the people of literature, into some monasteries to look at madmen who were described to us. We saw wonders among them, until we reached a young man in a room among them, clean of face and clothing, on a clean mat, holding a mirror and a comb, looking in the mirror and combing his beard. I said: 'What seats you here while you are different from these?' He raised his glance and inclined another and recited saying: [Poem in Kamil meter] Allah knows that I am lovesick... unable to spread what I find. Two souls I have; a soul a land divides it... and another a land has possessed. And if the resident one, patience does not benefit it... it finds what I find. I said to him: 'I see you are in love.' He said: 'Yes.' I said: 'With whom?' He said: 'You are indeed inquisitive.' I said: 'Beneficent if you informed.' He said: 'My father contracted a marriage for me to a female cousin of mine, but he died before I could consummate the marriage with her. He left great wealth. So my uncle seized all the wealth and imprisoned me in this monastery and claimed that I am mad. And the custodian of the monastery meanwhile says to us: "Beware of him for he is changing now."' Then he said to me: 'Recite something to me for I think you are of the people of literature.' I said to my companion: 'Recite.' So he recited: [Poem] I kissed her mouth in fear, stealing... like the seeker of fire who did not perceive due to haste. What is upon a watcher in the house if they neglected... me so I kissed her ten times slowly? Lower your eyelids from me and look from near... for lovers are only exposed by eyes. He said to me: 'Father of whom [is your Kunya], may I be your ransom?' I said: 'Abu al-Abbas.' He said: 'O Abu al-Abbas, I and this youth are at the two extremes. This one is neighboring the one he loves, facing obtaining from him, and I am distant, excluded. So by Allah, you recite something to me.' Nothing came to me at the time except the saying of Umar ibn Abi Rabi'ah: [Poem in Kamil meter] Sukaynah said while tears were shedding... running upon the cheeks and the Jilbab. Would that Al-Mughiri whom I did not reward... in what prolonged my patience and my seeking. His days used to return desires to us... when no blame was cast on a passion and one was struck [by love]. I was told what she said, so I spent the night as if... shooting the vitals with right-hitting arrows. O Sukaynah, the water of the Euphrates and its goodness... is not—to a thirsty one and love is a drink—More delicious than you, even if you are far, and rarely... do women observe the trust of the absent. Then I said to him: 'You recite something else to us.' So he recited saying: [Poem in Majzu' al-Wafir meter] Clarify to me, O Ruins... about the loved ones, what did they do? Do you see they traveled, do you see they settled... in the land of Sham or departed? My companion said to him jokingly and playfully: 'They died.' He said: 'Woe to you, they died?' He said: 'Yes, they died.' He became agitated and his eyes turned red and he intended to leap, so we moved away from him. He began striking his head on the ground saying: 'Woe to you, they died.' Until his matter terrified us, so we left him. Then we returned after days and asked the owner of the monastery about him. He said: 'That remained his state until he died.' Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abu Hatim informed me from Al-Asma'i, saying: The Arabs say: So-and-so returned 'fi hafiratahi' (in his original state), and returned 'adrajahu' (his steps), and returned 'awdahu 'ala bad'ihi' (his return upon his beginning) if he returned on the road from which he came. He said: And 'Al-Nafir' and plural 'Anfar': Those who mobilize for their needs, in raiding and other than that. As for their saying: 'La fi al-'ir wa la fi al-nafir' (Neither in the caravan nor in the mobilization), it was said on the Day of Badr. A conversation occurred in Islam between Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan and Amr al-Ashdaq. Amr said to Yazid: 'Be silent, for you are neither in the caravan nor in the mobilization.' Yazid said to his sitters: 'Indeed this fool heard a word so he loved to exemplify with it, but he did not know how to place it in its place. He says to me: I am not in the caravan nor in the mobilization. Yet the owner of the caravan was my grandfather Abu Sufyan, and the owner of the mobilization was my grandfather Utbah ibn Rabi'ah.' Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi regarding the saying of the poet: [Rajaz] What is wrong with the camels, their walking is slow (*wa'ida*)... Is it boulders they carry or iron? Or 'Sarfan' (lead/death/dates), cold, severe... Or men, crouching, sitting? He said: 'Al-Sarfan': Lead. Some linguists say: 'Al-Sarfan': Death. Some of them said regarding this verse: The dates: Al-Sarfan itself. Most scholars are on the first opinion. 'Al-Shanf': What is hung in the ear from its top. 'Al-Qurt': What is hung in its bottom. 'Al-'Arr': The ring of the earring. Abu al-Qasim said: His saying 'mashyuha' (their walking) he made genitive as a substitute (*Badal*) for 'Al-Jamal' (the camels) because the meaning encompasses it. The estimation is: What is wrong with the walking of the camels being slow (*wa'ida*), i.e., heavy. And he made 'wa'ida' accusative as a state (*Hal*). 'Al-Qabus': Groups, as if it is plural of 'Qabis' like 'Darib' and 'Durrab', and 'Sa'im' and 'Suwwam'. 'Al-Qibs' with Kasra on Qaf and Sukun on Ba: The large number of people. Abu Muhammad Isma'il ibn al-Najm al-Sharabi informed us, saying: We were in the assembly of Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad on a severely cold day. Isma'il ibn Zarzur the singer passed by us, wearing a fine linen undergarment and a brocade saddle-cover (?), and on his head a Dabiqi handkerchief, and on his foot a squeaking sandal. He passed and did not greet. Al-Mubarrad said to us: 'Who is this?' We said: 'Ibn Zarzur the singer.' He said: 'Write: Your singing earns you accusations of adultery... and slapping and expulsion from buildings. And slandering you is more beautiful than being righteous... and insulting you is more fitting than using Kunya (honorifics). So the day of your birth is for condolences... and the day of your death is for congratulations.' Another recited to us for Ibn Bassam: [Poem in Kamil meter] Equal are the one whose earning is by slapping... or the one who has slaughter in his singing. Their states in slapping are one... there is no span between their earners. Niftawayh told us, saying Al-Hunayni told us from Al-Husayn ibn Muhammad from Shayban from Qatadah regarding the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic (And you see the sun when it rises, declining (*tazzawaru*) away from their cave to the right, and when it sets, lending them (*taqriduhum*) to the left) [Quran 18:17]. He said: Its meaning is leaving them to the left while they are in a gap within it. When he said [gap], he means: in a space of the cave. Abu al-Qasim said: The origin of *tazzawaru* is *tatazawaru*, so the second Ta was changed to Zay and assimilated into the one after it, so it was said *tazzawaru*. And 'Al-Azwar': The inclined/crooked. Regarding *taqriduhum*, there are opinions. Some linguists said: Its meaning is leaving them to the right as Qatadah said. Others said: Passing them to the left, which is the school of Abu Ubaydah. He said: And it is said: Did you pass by such and such place? The questioned one says: *Qaradtuhu* at night, i.e., passed it at night. Another recited for Dhul-Rummah: [Poem in Tawil meter] To litters passing (*yaqridna*) the middle parts of Mushrif... quickly, while on their right sides are the horsemen. Others said: *Taqriduhum* to the left, i.e., turns away from them.

“Oh poor one, is the water of the Euphrates and its sweetness... a favor to a thirst, and the love of a drink / More delicious than you? Even if you are far, and rarely... do women keep the trust of those absent.” Then I said to him, “Recite something else for us.” So he began to say (in the Majzu’ al-Wafir meter): “Explain to me, O ruins... regarding the loved ones, what have they done? / Do you see that they traveled? Do you see that they settled... in the land of Sham, or have they departed?” My companion said to him, jokingly and playfully: “They died.” He said: “Woe to you, they died?” He replied: “Yes, they died.” He became agitated, his eyes turned red, and he attempted to jump up, so we moved away from him. He began striking his head against the ground saying, “Woe to you, they died,” until his condition terrified us and we left him. We returned after a few days and asked the owner of the monastery about him. He said: “That remained his state until he died.” Ibn Durayd told us, saying Abu Hatim told me on the authority of Al-Asma'i, who said: The Arabs say, “So-and-so returned in his tracks [fi hafiratibhi],” “returned his steps [adrajahu],” and “returned his ending to his beginning [‘awdahu ‘ala bad’ihi]” when he returns on the path he came from. He said: The 'Nafir' and the plural 'Anfar' are those who mobilize for their needs, in raids and otherwise. As for their saying: “Neither in the 'Ir [caravan] nor in the Nafir [mobilization],” it was said on the Day of Badr. In the Islamic era, a dispute occurred between Yazid bin Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan and ‘Amr al-Ashdaq. ‘Amr said to Yazid: “Be silent, for you are neither in the ‘Ir nor in the Nafir.” Yazid said to those sitting with him: “This fool heard a phrase and wanted to use it as a proverb, but he did not know how to place it in its context. He says to me, 'You are neither in the ‘Ir nor in the Nafir,' yet the leader of the ‘Ir was my grandfather Abu Sufyan, and the leader of the Nafir was my grandfather Utbah bin Rabi’ah.” Niftawayh told us on the authority of Tha’lab on the authority of Ibn al-A’rabi regarding the poet’s saying (in Rajaz meter): “What is wrong with the camels walking slowly [wa’idan]... Are they carrying rocks or iron? / Or cold, hard ‘Sarfan’... or men sitting heavily?” He said: ‘Sarfan’ is lead. Some linguists say: ‘Sarfan’ is death. Some said regarding this verse: It is the dates called ‘Sarfan’ itself, but most scholars hold the first view. The ‘Shanf’ is what is hung from the upper part of the ear. The ‘Qurt’ is what is hung from the lower part. The ‘Urr’ is the ring of the Qurt. Abu al-Qasim said: The phrase “mashiya-ha” [their walking] is in the genitive case as a substitute [Badal] for “the camels” because the meaning encompasses it. The estimation is: “What is wrong with the walking of the camels being slow [wa’idan]?” meaning heavy. “Wa’idan” is in the accusative case as a circumstantial adverb [Hal]. ‘Qabs’: groups, as if it is the plural of ‘Qabis’, similar to ‘Darib’ and ‘Darrab’, and ‘Sa’im’ and ‘Sawwam’. ‘Qibs’ with a kasra on the Qaf and sukoon on the Ba is a large number of people. Abu Muhammad Ismail bin al-Najm al-Sharabi told us: We were in the gathering of Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad on a very cold day. Ismail bin Zarzur the singer passed by us wearing a tunic of Qasab [fine linen/gut] and a brocade saddle-cover, with a Dabiqi kerchief on his head and squeaking sandals on his feet. He passed without greeting. Al-Mubarrad said to us: “Who is this?” We said: “Ibn Zarzur the singer.” He said: “Write down: 'Your singing earns you accusation... and a slap and expulsion from the buildings / Casting you out is more beautiful than being kind to you... and insulting you is more fitting than using a polite title / The day of your birth is for condolences... and the day of your death is for congratulations.'” Someone else recited to us lines by Ibn Bassam: “It is the same whether one earns by being slapped... or one for whom slaughter is the reward for his singing / The condition of both in regards to slapping is one... there is only a span between their earners.” Niftawayh told us, saying Al-Hunaini told us on the authority of Al-Hussein bin Muhammad on the authority of Shayban on the authority of Qatada regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: {And you see the sun when it rises, inclining away [tazzawaru] from their cave to the right, and when it sets, passing them [taqriduhum] to the left} [Al-Kahf: 17]. He said: It means it leaves them to the left while they are in an open space within it. He says: In a spacious part of the cave. Abu al-Qasim said: The origin of ‘tazzawaru’ is ‘tatazawaru’, so the second Ta was changed to a Zay and assimilated into the one following it, so it was said ‘tazzawaru’. The ‘Azwar’ is the slanted/inclined one. Regarding ‘taqriduhum’ there are opinions. Some linguists said: It means it leaves them to the right, as Qatada said. Others said: It bypasses them to the left, which is the school of Abu Ubaida. He said: It is said, “Did you pass by such and such place?” The questioned one says: “Qaradtuhu [I passed it] at night,” meaning I bypassed it at night. Someone else recited lines by Dhu al-Rummah: “Toward women in howdahs who cut across [yaqridna] the middle of Mushrif... quickly, while the horsemen are on their right.” Others said: ‘Taqriduhum’ to the left means it turns away from them.

Ibn Shuqayr narrated from Tha'lab that he said: Al-Kisa'i and Al-Farra said: It is from alignment. It is said: 'Qaradana' the thing and 'Hadhani', 'Yaqriduni' and 'Yahdhuni', and 'Hadhani' 'Yuhadhini' with one meaning. It is said: The sun 'Gharabat' (set) 'Ghuruban', and 'Ghabat' (disappeared) 'Ghuyuban' and 'Ghayban' and 'Maghiban', and 'Wajabat' (fell) 'Wujuban', and 'Abat' (returned) 'Iyaban', and 'Waqabat' (entered) 'Wuquban', and 'Qanabat' 'Qunuban', and 'Alqat yadan fi ka'ir' (Cast a hand in a hole/sunset). All that is with one meaning. And it is said: The star 'Afala' (set) 'Ya'fulu' and 'Ya'filu' 'Aflan' and 'Ufulan'. And 'Gharaba', and 'Ightamasa' (dipped), and 'Khafaqa' (dropped). If the sun approaches setting and has not yet set, it is said: 'Zabbat' and 'Azabbat' and 'Tadayyafat' and 'Malat' and 'Janahat' and 'Tafelat'. Al-Akhfash and Al-Zajjaj informed us, they said Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying: It was told to us from more than one source with disconnected wordings and agreeing meanings, some adding to others, that when the Prophet (PBUH) died, Al-Abbas, Ali, and Al-Fadl undertook his washing. Ali said: 'I did not see his mouth frequenting the change that frequents the dead.' When he finished washing him, Ali uncovered the sheet from his face then said: 'May my father and mother be your ransom, you were good alive and good dead. By your death, what was not cut off by the death of anyone else of Prophets and Prophethood has been cut off. You were specific until you became a consoler for [the loss of] anyone else, and you were general until the calamity regarding you became equal [for all]. Were it not that you commanded patience and forbade panic, we would have exhausted the tears (shu'un) over you. But what is inevitable is grief and turning away (?), allies, and they are the disease of the term. And little, by Allah, for you. May my father and mother be your ransom, remember us with your Lord and make us of your concern.' Then he glanced a mote, so he cast it out with his tongue and returned the sheet over his face. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Shu'un': Tears, singular 'Sha'n'. It is said they are the ducts of tears. And it is said they are the sutures of the skull and from them is the beginning of the tear duct. Then tears were named 'Shu'un' because of that. He recites for Aws ibn Hajar: [Poem in Kamil meter] Do not grieve me with separation, for I... my tears (shu'uni) do not flow from separation. Al-Zajjaj informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad told us, saying Lut ibn Yahya ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Jundub told us from his father, saying: I entered upon Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, when Ibn Muljam struck him, to ask about him, but I did not sit with him. Because a veiled girl entered upon him, so he called Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn, blessings of Allah be upon them, then said to them: 'I advise you to fear Allah, and do not seek the world even if it seeks you, and do not weep for anything of it that was kept away from you. Speak the truth, have mercy on the orphan, help the maker (or stricken), and work for the Hereafter. Be an opponent to the oppressor and a helper to the oppressed, and let not the blame of a blamer take you in [the path of] Allah.' Then he looked to Ibn al-Hanafiyyah and said: 'Did you hear what I advised them with?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'I advise you with the like, and to honor the affair of your two brothers, and do not decide a matter without them.' Then he said to them: 'And I advise you regarding him, for he is your brother and the son of your father, and you know that his father used to love him, so love him.' Al-Yazidi informed us, saying my uncle Al-Fadl ibn Muhammad informed me from his father from Abu Muhammad al-Yazidi, saying: Abu al-Atahiyah suffered estrangement from Amr ibn Mas'adah, so he wrote to him: [Poem in Tawil meter] You became rich from the old affection, you became rich... and wasted an affection that was mine, and forgot. And I was, in days of weakness of powers... more kind and fulfilling than you when you became strong. I knew you in non-authority as preserving... so you closed the door of affection when you were appointed. You feigned ignorance of what you used to describe well... and died from benevolence when you lived. And from the wonder of days is that he who is loyal perished... and whom I used to tend for him, while you remained. Your richness to one who hopes for you is poverty and need... and humiliation and despair of you the day you were hoped for. Al-Yazidi informed us from his uncle from his father from his grandfather, saying: Al-Nu'man ibn al-Mundhir appointed some Bedouins over the Gate of Al-Hirah adjacent to the desert. He caught a lizard (Dabb) and sent it to Al-Nu'man and wrote to him: [Poem in Tawil meter] The workers of land-tax collected the money, and my collection... is cut-eared [lizards], yellow of flanks. They grazed the hills and the herbs until as if... a Sultan clothed them in the garments of Al-Marajil. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Ruba' plural of 'Rabwah': It is what rose of the ground. It is said: 'Rabwah', 'Rubwah', and 'Rabawah'. It is narrated in some Tafsirs that the meaning of Allah Almighty's saying (And We sheltered them to a high ground (Rabwah) having level ground and flowing water) [Quran 23:50] is Damascus. 'Al-Shawakil': Plural of 'Shakilah' which is the flank. 'Thiyab al-Marajil': Striped garments made in Yemen. It is said that Al-Marajil is a place there where clothes are made, so they were attributed to it. Niftawayh recited to us for Al-Mu'ammil: [Poem in Basit meter] Do not get angry at a people you love... for anger from you does not benefit against them. And do not dispute with them a day even if they wronged... for judges, when disputed, overcome. O unjust ones against us in their judgment... and injustice is the ugliest of what is done and committed.

We do not flee from you to other than you when... you oppress, but to you from you is the flight. This is exactly the saying of Al-Buhturi: [Poem in Mukhalla' al-Basit meter] O oppressor of me without a crime... to you from your oppression is the escape. And this meaning is derived from the speech of Allah Almighty (So flee to Allah, indeed I am to you from Him a clear warner) [Quran 51:50]. Niftawayh recited to us for Abu al-Atahiyah: [Poem in Kamil meter] Annihilation was written upon the creation, all of it... and people are between advanced and left behind. Glory be to the Possessor of the Kingdoms! Which night... churned with the face of the morning of the Day of Standing? It is narrated instead of 'all of it' (kulluha), 'its Lord' (rabbuha). Abdullah ibn Muhammad al-Naysaburi told us, saying Ali ibn Sa'id ibn Jarir al-Nasa'i told us, saying Abd al-Samad ibn Abd al-Warith told us from Shu'bah from Abd al-Malik ibn Umar from Rib'i: That Abu Musa fainted, so his wife wept for him. He said: I am innocent to you of what the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was innocent of: of one who shaved, and screamed (*salaqa*), and tore [clothes]. Abu al-Qasim said: Shaved is from shaving the head for women over the dead. As for 'Al-Salaq': It is raising the voice in weeping and wailing. Allah Almighty said: (They assaulted you (*salaqukum*) with sharp tongues) [Quran 33:19]. Likewise 'Al-Naq'': Raising the voice in weeping and wailing. This was forbidden in the beginning of Islam, I mean weeping over the dead, then it was permitted as long as it is not excessive, exceeding the limit in screaming and wailing. Umar ibn al-Khattab said: 'There is no harm on the women of Al-Mughira that they shed their tears over Abu Sulayman as long as there is no 'Naq'' nor 'Laqlaqah'.' 'Al-Naq'' is what we mentioned. 'Al-Laqlaqah': Moving the tongue and ululating. Abu Sulayman is Khalid ibn al-Walid ibn al-Mughira. 'Al-Sallaq': With Fatha on Lam and Sin: The level ground, its plural is 'Silqan'. 'Al-Falaq': A depression between two hills, and its plural is 'Falqan'. Muhammad ibn Mahmud al-Wasiti told us, saying Abu Isma'il al-Yazidi told us, saying Affan told us from Hammam from Thabit from Anas: That Abu Bakr told them saying: I said to the Prophet (PBUH) while we were in the cave: 'If one of them looked at his feet, he would see us under his feet.' He said: 'O Abu Bakr, what is your thought of two, Allah is their third?' Niftawayh informed us, saying Isma'il ibn Muhammad al-Sami informed us, saying Rawk ibn al-Muhabbir informed me, saying I heard Shu'bah say: 'Learn Arabic, for it increases the intellect.' Ibn al-Anbari and Ibn Shuqayr told us, saying Ahmad ibn Ubayd told us: It was on the arm band of Buzurjmihr: 'If fortunes are by luck, then why the greed? And if things are not lasting, then why the joy? And if the Abode is deceptive, then why tranquility in it?' Ibn al-Anbari told us, saying Ahmad ibn Abdullah al-Harbi told us, saying Abu Abdullah al-Qurashi told us, saying: Abu al-Hasan al-Mada'ini said: Abd al-Malik sent his brother Muhammad ibn Marwan to Mus'ab ibn al-Zubayr offering him safety. Mus'ab said: 'The likes of me do not return from this position except victorious or defeated.' Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Sukkari informed us from Al-Ziyadi from Al-Asma'i said: Al-Ahwas ibn Muhammad used to compose amorous poetry about the women of the nobles. He was complained about to Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz, so he exiled him to a village of the villages of Yemen. He said: And when he said: [Poem in Tawil meter] I circle, and were it not that I see Umm Ja'far... in your dwellings, I would not circle where I circle. And I was not a visitor, but the possessor of passion... if he does not visit, must be visiting. Umm Ja'far has prevented her kindness... and indeed I am in need of her kindness. Umm Ja'far came with a document of a right against Al-Ahwas for a debt due immediately, so she seized him and began demanding the debt mentioned in this book from him. He swore by Allah that he did not know her, nor ever saw her. She said to him: 'O wicked one, I am Umm Ja'far, so why did you mention me in your poetry when you never saw me?' Al-Yazidi informed us, saying Abu Muhammad ibn Hamdun Hizabiyah informed us, saying: Abu Nuwas recited to me for himself: [Poem in Kamil meter] I likened him to the full moon when it appeared... or the bride on the morning of the wedding. And I seek refuge for him from having... what is under her waist-wrapper of filth. Al-Yazidi informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us, saying: We were with Ibn al-A'rabi, so he recited to me the saying of Jarir: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a day like the thumb of the sandgrouse, I imagined... its forenoon, and its evenings became pleasant in the afternoon. We were provided in it with abundant game and we were not... like one whose arrows and ropes are deprived. Ibn al-A'rabi said: Better than it—and it is what Jarir took from—is the saying of the other: [Poem in Wafir meter] And a day at the house of Abu Nu'aym... short like the side-neck of the fly.

Abu al-Qasim said: And I say that this is the utmost in exaggeration, and a departure from the limit of correct simile. And its parallel in exaggeration in the opposite of this meaning is the saying of Abu Tammam: [Poem in Tawil meter] And a day like the length of time in the width of its like... and my longing is longer than this and that. Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Ibn Hatim al-Sijistani informed us from Abu Zayd al-Ansari, saying: 'Al-Bitriq': The strutting, self-impressed, arrogant man. They are 'Al-Batariqah' and 'Al-Batariq'. It has no verb and is not used for women. 'Al-Humam': The master man possessing courage and generosity. It has no verb and is not used for women. 'Al-Jahjah': The master, polite man. It has no verb and is not used for women. Al-Yazidi recited to us, saying my uncle recited to me: [Poem in Rajaz meter] Do you not see me weak of the eyes... dark of the cheek and the cheeks? Rough of the shirt, hard of the sandals... Indeed, a man is by the two small things (Asgharayn). Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Asgharan': The heart and the tongue. From it is the saying of Damrah ibn Damrah. He used to raid the garrisons of Al-Nu'man and diminish his extremities. He sought him but he exhausted and distressed him, so he offered him a hundred camels and safety. When he entered upon him, he scorned him because he was small and unsightly. Al-Nu'man said: "That you hear of Al-Mu'aydi is better than seeing him." He was the first to say it, so it became a proverb. Damrah said to him: "Gently, may you refuse the curse! For a man is by his two smallest things: his tongue and his heart; if he speaks with clarity, and if he fights with a heart." So he was impressed by him and gave him charge of his gate. Al-Zajjaj recited to us, saying Al-Mubarrad recited to me, saying Al-Akhfash recited to me two verses mentioned by Sibawayh in his book by some Bedouins, and they are: [Rajaz] Indeed the generous one, by your father, works... if he does not find one day upon whom to rely. Abu al-Qasim said: In this verse there are five aspects. One: The school of Yunus, and Al-Mubarrad used to hold it previously and mentioned it in the book "Refutation of Sibawayh" and chose it, then rejected it. It is that the estimation is: Indeed the generous one, by your father, relies if he does not find one day anything. Then he starts and says interrogatively: Upon whom does he rely? Upon this or upon that? So 'yattakilu' is in the nominative position but he silenced it for the rhyme, so he says: Meaning he writes. The second aspect: Al-Farra used to hold it. The meaning of 'lam yajid' is: did not know. As if he said: If he did not know upon whom to rely. He said: And it was said to a woman of the Arabs: Take your pot down from the fire. She said: 'La ajidu bima unziluha' (I do not find with what to take it down), i.e., I do not know with what to take it down. The third aspect: The school of Al-Mazini, and it is what Al-Mubarrad chose lately. The meaning: He did not find and did not know. As if he said: Indeed the generous one works if he does not know upon whom to rely. The fourth aspect: That 'lam yajid' means 'lam yuktab' (was not written/destined). As if he said: If it is not written upon whom he relies. The fifth aspect: The school of Sibawayh. We delayed it due to its obscurity because some people claim he erred in it. Its estimation according to Sibawayh is that 'yajid' is connected to 'man' by 'ala', as if its estimation is: If he does not find [anyone] whom he relies upon, so the estimation is: If he does not find whom to rely upon. And 'wajadtu' is not transitive with a preposition particle, so for this they opposed him. Al-Mazini said: And his estimation is correct and good because the transitive verb may be allowed not to be transitive, so as if he intended that then it appeared to him so he made it transitive with 'ala', as the Almighty said: (It may be that some of what you seek to hasten is close behind you [radifa lakum]) [Quran 27:72]. It was only permitted to delete 'alayhi' from his saying 'in lam yajid man yattakilu alayhi' because of its mention in the beginning of the speech. Based on this, he permitted that you say: 'Mata tamrur amrur' (When you pass, I pass) and 'Ala man tanzil anzil' (Upon whom you descend, I descend), implying 'bihi' (by him) and 'alayhi' (upon him) because their mention has occurred, and the norm is that they be brought. Niftawayh recited to us: [Poem in Tawil meter] And when we settled in a place bedewed by moisture... elegant, and a garden empty of blossoms. The beauty of the place and its goodness counted for us... desires, so we wished, and you were the wishes. And he recited to us also similar to it: [Poem in Munsarih meter] Allah is witness for me in that, and... the people of chastity and piety may witness. I was never in a gathering I was pleased with... except I wished you were with me. Niftawayh informed us, saying Tha'lab informed us, saying Salamah informed us from Al-Farra who said: It is said for the kid (goat): This is the 'Jady', and 'Al-'At'at', and 'Al-'Ath'ath', and 'Al-Amarr'. He said: And 'Al-Hanan': Awe. And 'Al-Hanan': Giving. And 'Al-Hanan': Provision. And 'Al-Hanan': Mercy. And he recites for Imru' al-Qays: [Poem in Wafir meter] And Banu Shamaja ibn Jarm grant it... their goats, Your mercy ('Hananaka'), O Possessor of Mercy ('Al-Hanan'). Ibn Durayd recited to us, saying Abd al-Rahman recited to us from his uncle: [Poem in Tawil meter] And Nasr ibn Dahman, a hundred ('hunaydah') he suffered... and fifty years, then he straightened and made a sound ('insata'). And the blackness of the head returned after its whiteness... and the prime of youth after it had passed.

And he exchanged abundant forbearance after his recklessness... but after all that, he died. Abu al-Qasim said: His saying: 'Insata' means: he stood up straight after he was bent. 'Al-Hunaydah': A hundred camels, so he borrowed it here for a hundred years. He says: He lived a hundred and fifty years. Mudrik recited to me for himself: [Poem in Raml meter] Indeed a sickness has become serious with me from play... from you with abandonment for a continuous magic. What was small yesterday forenoon became great... so what I am in today is more cunning and bitter. They promised, when they promised, to return... from doubt, so watch them and be patient. What is upon them if tears flowed in their tracks... running with pouring water? Then blood met it so they met... upon my cheek for a matter that was decreed. O Abu al-Qattan, patience, O youth... for perhaps your master will follow with victory. From a gazelle, clothed [in beauty], tender... his name in the Book (Mushaf) humans recite. Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Ahwal recited to us for Al-'Attawi, and it is said rather it is for Amr ibn Abd al-Malik al-Warraq regarding the Fitna of the Deposed (Al-Amin): [Poem in Basit meter] What afflicted you, O Baghdad, with the evil eye... Were you not for a time the delight of the eye? Was there not in you a people whom you were their dwelling... and their proximity was an adornment of adornment? I entrust to Allah a people whom I did not mention... except the water of the eye glistened from my eye. They were, so time tore them and split them... and time splits what is between two groups. He said: And Tha'lab recited to me regarding this: [Poem in Munsarih meter] I dispraise Baghdad and residing in it... after an experience and testing. There is not with their kings for a seeker... relief nor an opening for the distressed. The seeker of gifts with them needs... three [things] after approach. The treasures of Qarun to be his... and the life of Noah and the patience of Job. 'Al-Mukhtabit': The one who asks for what you have without acquaintance or cause. And it is permissible in 'Kunuz Qarun' (Treasures of Qarun) and what follows it to be nominative or genitive. Whoever made it nominative made it a predicate of an implied inchoative, as if he said: They are the treasures of Qarun. And whoever made it genitive made it a substitute for the 'Three'. Some experienced people who came to Baghdad and found it unhealthy recited to me: [Poem in Tawil meter] I see the countryside approaching every day and night... and I increase from Najd and its inhabitant in distance. Indeed Baghdad is a contrary land... to me, even if its living is abundant. A land where you see souls are cheap... and it increases in stench when it rains or becomes moist. Al-Yazidi recited to us, saying my uncle recited to me from his father: [Poem in Tawil meter] O separation which agitated the bowels... when are you, may Allah cut your luck, heedless? I see you towards the loved ones, my jealousy and hers... a lover, so killing deaths met you. Al-Akhfash told us, saying Tha'lab told us, saying Al-Riyashi informed us, saying Bishr ibn Umar told us, saying Abdullah ibn Tiqah told us, saying Abu Zur'ah ibn Jabir told us from Umar ibn Ali that Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: O Messenger of Allah, are the guides ('Hudat') from us or from others? He said: No, rather from us. By us the religion is sealed as it was opened by us. Saved from error. By us Allah brings hearts together after enmity, just as by us He brought their sons together after the enmity of polytheism. Ali said: O Messenger of Allah, so who remains, believers or disbelievers? He said: Tempted ('Maftun') and disbeliever. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Fitna' (Temptation/Trial) is of types in the speech of the Arabs. 'Al-Fitna': Affliction. 'Al-Fitna': Testing. 'Al-Fitna': Disbelief, from His saying, Exalted is His Name (And Fitna is worse than killing) [Quran 2:191]. And 'Al-Fitna': Punishment. And 'Al-Maftun': The one burned by fire, from His saying: (The Day they are on the fire 'yuftanun' [tried/burned]) [Quran 51:13]. It is said: They are punished, and it is said: They are burned. And 'Al-Hudat' is plural of 'Hadin' (Guide). This is a plural specific to the defective [roots], and it has no parallel in the sound [roots]. Like your saying: 'Ghaz' and 'Ghuzah' (Raiders), 'Qad' and 'Qudah' (Judges), 'Ram' and 'Rumah' (Archers), 'Had' and 'Hudah'. There is nothing in the sound [roots] pluralized on 'Fu'lah'.

Abu al-Harith Bishr ibn Marwan ibn al-Hakam ibn Bishr ibn Abi Amr ibn al-A'la informed us in Madinat al-Salam (Baghdad) on Thursday, fourteen nights remaining of the month of Ramadan, year three hundred and twelve, in the house of Abu al-Husayn ibn Abi Abbad. He said Muhammad ibn al-Walid al-Darawi informed me, saying Abu al-Miqdam, a Sheikh from the people of Hazbah, informed me, saying some of Banu Makhzum informed me in Mecca in the year one hundred and forty. He said: When a conflict occurred between Banu Udhrah and Khuza'ah regarding a boy belonging to a woman from Khuza'ah who used to gather wood (earn) for her and return his earnings to her, a man from Banu Udhrah hit him and killed him. Udhrah carried his value (blood money) to Khuza'ah, but they refused to accept it and said: 'That will never happen until we kill the boy of 'Umrah bint Qabisah ibn Sulayk.' The matter aggravated between them until they called upon their alliances. Hashim ibn Abd Manaf feared the corruption of the Sanctuary and that its sanctity would be violated. So he called for his pulpit, the 'Mirkan', and promised the people at the well of Banu Qusayy ibn Kilab, 'Al-Harad', which is at the meeting place of the groups. When the people gathered, he stood among them as a speaker and delivered his sermon which is called 'The Wise', singling out in it the two sons of Nizar to the exclusion of Qahtan, and Mudar to the exclusion of Rabi'ah, and Quraysh to the exclusion of other tribes. He said: "O assembly of people, we are the family of Abraham, the progeny of Ishmael, the children of Al-Nadr ibn Kinanah, and the sons of Qusayy ibn Kilab, the lords of Mecca and the authority of the Sanctuary. Ours is the peak of honor, the core of lineage, the mine of glory, and the utmost limit of might. We are the mountains of the earth, the pillars of truth, and the masters of nations. For everyone in every alliance, his support is obligatory, and answering his call, not driving towards disobedience of a clan or severing of a womb. I have gathered you for fear that haste, bad opinion, and ignorance of knowledge might lead you to 'Hass al-Qimmah' (shaving the top/eradicating leaders) and 'Jard al-Taba'ud' (stripping of distance/estrangement). So every man among you loads a saddle upon his brother, uprooting with it his tall branches and summoning with it the flow of war. I swear, if the 'Jurrah al-Khulub' (deceptive draught?) flows before the cauterization of the splinter, the 'Hammah' (venom/fever) will surely rise over the depth, and the 'Shaml al-Sahiq' (gathering of the distant) will surely disdain until the 'Qadhif al-Kabid' (liver-thrower) is deterred, or the old waterskins hang the splinters of the feathered [arrows?]... their notches, and the chimneys empty the main part of the smoke, and the merged waists reveal the guaranteed deposited of themselves. If that happens, the dream (prudence) of the polite will stray, the opinion of the correct one will go lost, the hole of the 'Sabubah' (bucket?) will widen, the draining of the bucket will diminish, and the welding of the smith will connect. And it will be said: The road has narrowed, so advance. There the commanders will overturn their command, and the stone will accept its crushing, and the arrow will own its aim, and every man will dig up what he buried. O Banu Khuza'ah, the sons of your father carried to you the value of a slave whom death struck by the hand of mistake, so it agreed with his term. If it was from an ambush of a seeker and a seeking of a pursuer, it would be intentional. Or have you refused accepting what is the Sunnah (custom) of the Arabs to enlarge the fires of death? So be the head of the Arabs whose sons call out, while I have judged accepting his value, and upon Banu Udhrah to pay that to you. Whoever success makes him quarrelsome and leaves what his heart judged, then I am an ally against him, and a reinforcement for Udhrah against him, until the travelers carry it and the sunken-eyed camels trot with it to the judges of the Arabs, so they become proverbs. O people, forbearance is honor, patience is victory, generosity is sovereignty, kindness is a treasure, war is deception, victory is a turn (of fortune), days are changing, and lineages—one is attributed to his deed and taken by his work. So consult forbearance, it will accomplish the awkward word for you. Leave meddling, fools will avoid you. Honor the sitter, your club will be populated. Stick to noble morals, for they are elevation. And beware of base morals, for they lower the noble and demolish glory. Behold, fear of the unintelligible (foreigner/silent?) has kept hearts without a watering place for the ninety(?). 'Shakim al-Shawa' (biting of extremities?) is dangerous, and his mouth knocks the training, and his neck shrinks from the pulling of the rope. So his compacted [hoof] pierced the crushed stones of the rugged grounds due to the distance of the night journey. So he made his rider go on foot, and his curve... a ride that made his family thirsty... the slipping of the rope of the 'Sabubah' due to leaving the tightening of the knot of the 'Karab' (rope). So it did not escape except with a taste of the one with raised corners of the mouth (camel?). Behold, the time of restraining the ignorant is easier than his crime. And the head of the clan bears its weight. The station of the wise is his rage for whom he benefited. And I love repairing the rift and gathering the division." Then he fell silent. Banu Udhrah and Banu Khuza'ah said: 'We are pleased with your judgment, O Abu Nadlah.' And the people departed in reconciliation. Abu al-Qasim said: This man did not dictate to us any of the strange vocabulary of this report, nor did we ask him about it. I also reckon that genealogists say that Abu Amr did not leave offspring. And Allah knows best how that was, but we say regarding what this report contained according to what we know.

As for his saying: "He used to gather wood (yahtubu) for her," 'Al-Hatab' means earning. It is said: So-and-so gathered wood for his family, i.e., earned for them. 'Al-Hatib', 'Al-Jarim', 'Al-Kasib', and 'Al-Jarih' are the same, due to the Arabs' saying: "So-and-so is the crime ('Jarimah' - earner) of his family," i.e., their earner. I earned the money ('Kasabtu'), and Zayd earned the money, without Alif. It has been narrated in an anomalous dialect 'Aksabtuhu' (I made him earn), but it is not good. 'Al-Sulayk' is the diminutive of 'Al-Silk', which is the chick of the sandgrouse, and the female is 'Silkah'. The 'Jarur' well seems to be the deep-bottomed one, derived from 'Al-Ijtiran' (drawing out?), as if he distances the place of pulling its rope. 'Al' (Family) of a man: his followers, his people, and his partisans. From it is His Almighty's saying (Enter the family of Pharaoh) [Quran 40:46], meaning his followers and people. 'Al-Al' can also be 'Al-Ahl' (family/people). You say: People of the village. In the diminutive of 'Ahl' is 'Uhayl'. It is as if the Hamza in it is substituted for the Ha, then substituted with Alif due to the meeting of two Hamzas in one word, as was done in 'Adam' and 'Akhar'. This indicates that the origin of 'Al' is 'Ahl'; the Ha was changed to Hamza, and it was applied to the meaning we mentioned. The parallel of the diminutive of 'Al' being 'Uhayl' is returning to the origin. Even if it were a different meaning, like the saying of Sibawayh regarding the diminutive of 'Mudh' if one is named by it: 'Munaydh'. He said because the origin in it is 'Mundhu', so the Nun was deleted from it when it was made a noun because 'Mundhu' according to him is a genitive particle, which is the school of most Arabs. And 'Mudh' is a noun for time, what follows it is raised by inchoative, so a separation was made between them for that. So if he transfers it from this position, he says in its diminutive 'Munaydh' because the diminutive is not on less than three letters. If a woman is named by it: 'Munaydhah', just as you say in the diminutive of Hind: 'Hunaydah'. Ibrahim is a foreign name. Grammarians have two opinions on its weight. Some said in its diminutive 'Ubayyirah', and 'Ubayyiriyyah' in compensation. If pluralized as a broken plural, he said 'Abarih'. Some said: The Hamza in it is extra, except that Hamza is not added at the beginning in what exceeds three letters, but it came in the beginning of this added anomalously. So its estimation according to him is 'If'alil', so he says in its diminutive 'Burayhim' and in the plural 'Barahimah'. Likewise the saying in Isma'il. It is said in its diminutive according to this second school: 'Sumay'il' in diminutive, and 'Sama'ilah' in plural. 'Al-Nadr': Gold. 'Al-Nudar' also. Likewise 'Al-Nudar' is a type of wood. 'Al-Kinanah': The quiver, and its plural is 'Kana'in'. Among the proverbs of the Arabs: "Before shooting, the quivers are filled." 'Qusayy': 'Fa'il' form from 'Al-Qasw', it is said: A 'Qaswa' camel, i.e., cut-eared. It is not said a camel is 'Aqsa'. It is possible its derivation is from 'Al-Iqsa', which is distancing, except that that is more correct in analogy and more consistent. 'Arbab': Plural of 'Rabb'. 'Al-Rabb': The owner of the thing. 'Al-Rabb': The reformer. 'Al-Rabb': The Master. Regarding the derivation of Mecca, there are two opinions. Some said: It is from your saying 'Imtakka' the foal what is in the udder of the she-camel of milk: if he drank it all. As if it attracts people to it from all horizons. Others said its origin is 'Bakkah' and the Mim is substituted for Ba, just as it is said 'Samada' his head and 'Sabada' it if he eradicated his hair. It was named that because it 'Tabukku' (crushes/breaks) the necks of tyrants, i.e., breaks them. Some said: It was named that because people 'Yatabakkun' (crowd) in it. 'Lubab' of a thing: Its pure part, and likewise its 'Lubb' (core). 'Al-Hasab': Generosity and honor. Linguists said: The derivation of 'Hasab' is from 'Hisab' (counting), from your saying 'Hasabtu' the thing if you counted it. So it is like the one who counts for himself feats and good deeds or counts noble fathers. 'Al-Ma'din': The place of residence, from your saying 'Adana' in the place: if he stayed in it. From it (Gardens of 'Adn') i.e., Gardens of residence. Thus he narrated it to us with Fatha. Every verb on the pattern 'Fa'ala Yaf'ilu' like 'Daraba Yadribu' and 'Nasaba Yansibu', the verbal noun/place/time from it is on 'Maf'il' with Kasra on the 'Ayn, like your saying: 'Darabtu Darban' and 'Madriban' if you intended the source (Masdar). 'Al-Madrib': The place where striking occurs. Likewise the time is built on 'Maf'il', like the Arabs' saying "The she-camel came at her 'Madrib'", i.e., at the time of her covering. As for the saying of Ziyad al-A'jam: [Poem in Tawil meter] The satirists did not leave for me, if I satirized him... a healthy place (*Masahhan*) I see in the skin of Al-Farazdaq. He intended a healthy/sound place. The source is 'Masahh' with Fatha as I mentioned. Whatever is 'Fa'ila Yaf'alu' like 'Alima Ya'lamu', and 'Shariba Yashrabu', or on 'Fa'ala Yaf'ulu' like 'Qatala Yaqtulu', the time and place and source from it are on 'Maf'al' all with open 'Ayn, like your saying: 'Al-Madhhab', 'Al-Mashrab', and 'Al-Ma'lam'. It is said 'Adana' in the place 'Ya'dinu' with Kasra in the present tense. So 'Al-Ma'din' according to this dialect must be with Kasra on Dal. And it is said 'Ya'dunu' with Damma. So 'Al-Ma'dan' from this dialect is with open Dal. Understand this, for both dialects have come in it. We consulted this Sheikh who dictated the report to us about it, but he refused to say anything but 'Ma'dana' with Fatha. He said: And that is how I heard it. And he was also eloquent. 'Al-Hilf': The ally. The Arabs in the Jahiliyyah used to ally, the tribe with those who were for some of them, that their hand be one. So they would fulfill that and not forsake each other, and they saw it as a religion they followed.

'Al-'Uquq': Cutting off parents or relatives. Its origin is from 'Al-'Aqq' which is splitting. It is said regarding his garment 'Aqq', and in his waterskin 'Aqq', i.e., split. 'Al-'Aqiqah': What remains of the ray of lightning in the clouds if it splits from it. From it the 'Ayyuq' stars were named 'Aqa'iq'. 'Al-'Aqiqah' also: The hair with which the newborn is born on his head. It is said 'Aqqa' regarding the newborn: if he shaves that hair and gives charity for it with something or a sheep is slaughtered and the like. In the Hadith, the Prophet (PBUH) performed 'Aqiqa' for Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn and gave charity of the weight of their hair in silver. As for his saying: "That haste leads you to 'Hass al-Qimmah' (shaving the top)": From their saying a man is 'Ahass': if he has little hair. 'Al-Hasas': Loss of hair. 'Al-Qimmah': The top of the head. This is a metaphor, as if he intended the eradication of the leaders and those by whom their affair stands. 'Al-Qimmah' is called 'Al-Sha'fah', plural 'Al-Sha'afat'. Likewise, the tops of everything like a mountain and such are called 'Sha'afat'. Al-Ajjaj said: [Split Rajaz] Penetrating into the earth except for peaks (*Sha'afa*). As for 'Al-Amam', it is the stature, the stature of a human. The poet said: [Poem in Mutaqarib meter] Indeed the noble Mu'awiyahs are beautiful... of faces, tall of statures (*Amam*). His saying: "And stripping the forearm (*Jard al-Sa'id*)": The Arabs say "So-and-so strikes at the soul of So-and-so and breaks ('yafuttu') his forearm," meaning by forearm the clan and people. 'Al-Jard': Scraping and peeling. From it is said: The man was stripped ('tajarrada') of his clothes. A woman beautiful of the stripped part ('Al-Mujarrad'). The stripped is from that. 'Al-Dabnah': Rancor. Like it is 'Al-Hasikah', 'Al-Dhaghinah', and 'Al-Wahar'. 'Al-Ijtithath': Cutting a thing from its root and uprooting it. From it is the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic (Uprooted from above the earth) [Quran 14:26]. 'Al-Basiqat': The tall ones. It is said: Tall palm trees (*basiqat*) from that. 'Al-Jarrah': Dragging a thing and pulling it towards you. 'Al-Jarrah' also: What the camel ruminates (drags up) from its stomach. 'Al-Hasm': Cutting. From it is said: I cut off ('hasamtu') the material/source of this matter. 'Al-Jammah': Gathering of water in a settlement or well or other. 'Al-'Umq': Depth of the well and the like, which is its extension downwards. This is but a metaphor he struck for the rising of evil and its dominance. His saying: "And the 'Shaml al-Sahiq' (gathering of the distant) will surely disdain ('la-yata'affanna')": He means they will gather upon the vile, contemptible matter to which the situation has reached extremities, and war making people destitute and disrupting their conditions. 'Al-Ta'aththuf': Gathering upon a thing and surrounding it from its sides, derived from 'Al-Athafi' (stones of the pot). Al-Nabigha said: [Poem in Basit meter] Do not cast me at a corner that has no competencies... and let not enemies surround you ('la ta'thafannaka') with support. 'Al-Samal': The worn-out garment. It is said 'Samala' the garment and 'Asmala' so it is 'Samal': If it became worn out. Like it is 'Nahja' and 'Anhaj', and 'Majja' and 'Amajja'. 'Akhlaqa' (became worn) 'Ikhlaqan' so it is 'Mukhliq'. And 'Khaliqa' 'Khuluqan' so it is 'Khaliq', and it is the lesser of the two dialects. It is said: A garment 'Khalaq' and 'Dir's' and 'Dir'is' and 'Daris' with the same meaning. Like it is 'Al-Hasif'. And 'Al-Ma'waz', plural 'Ma'awiz'. Al-Shammakh said: [Poem in Tawil meter] When the dews fell, they were protected and lined... with silk, and 'Ma'awiz' (worn garments) were not wrapped over them. Describing a bow he protects from dew with luxurious cloths not with worn-out ones. If the garment is torn with no worn-out part left, it is said a garment 'Munaq' and 'Samatit' and 'Ra'ahil' and 'Muraddam'. From it is the saying of Antarah: [Poem in Kamil meter] Did the poets leave any 'Mutaraddam' (place to be patched)... He says: Did they leave a facet for speech they did not speak in. His saying: "Until the 'Qadhif al-Kabid' (liver-thrower) is deterred": He says: Until it returns to where it exited from, reversed. From their saying: The arrow 'Irtada'a' if it returned and did not proceed on its course. And the man 'Irtada'a' (was deterred) from the ugly act. 'Al-Shinan': Plural of 'Shannah' which is the old waterskin. 'Al-Shazaya': Plural of 'Shaziyyah' (splinter). 'Al-Muqadhdhadhah afwaquha': meaning arrows. There is no meaning for the attachment of 'Al-Shinan' (waterskins) to arrows unless it is a metaphor for the existence of what cannot exist and its impossibility, or for the existence of strange things, if he intended by 'Al-Shinan' other than what we mentioned whose meaning is not clear to us. His saying: "And the chimneys empty the main part of the smoke": The thirst and the husk/scum (?). It is said: Between them is a truce on 'Dakhan' (smoke/grudge): If it is not pure of heart. 'Al-Dakhan': From 'Al-Dukhan' (smoke). 'Al-Ifragh' here: Emptying ('Istifragh'). It is said: So-and-so 'afragha' what was in his vessel, meaning emptied it. And I connected it gathered from the void. 'Mudmajat al-Khawasir': What the waists were folded upon, meaning what they concealed of cheating and enmity and other than that. From it is said: So-and-so is 'Mudmaj al-Khalq': i.e., folded of creation, wrapped. The Arabs describe the wrapped physique with 'Idmaj' and 'Idraj' as Ru'ba said describing a wild ass: [Rajaz] Round-eyed, compacted ('admaj') like the compacting of the rope ('Talq'). 'Al-Arib': The intelligent. 'Al-Arab': Intellect, and likewise 'Al-Hija' and 'Al-Nuha' and 'Al-Hawl'. As for his saying: "And the cut ('fary') of the 'Sabubah' widened": 'Al-Fary': The split, which is cutting. It is said: 'Faraytu' the leather if you cut it for repair. And 'Afraytuhu': If you cut it for spoiling.

'Al-Sabubah': The bucket. Likewise 'Al-Maqriyyah', and it is an adjective for it as if it is an object (maf'ulah) from 'qaraytu'. Likewise 'Al-Dhanub' which is the huge bucket. And 'Al-Gharb' is like it. And 'Al-Sajil' and 'Al-Sajilah'. If the bucket is small, it is 'Kat'ah' and 'Walighah'. He only intended by his saying: "The cut of the 'Sabubah' widened" the like of their saying: "The hole widened on the patcher." His saying: "And the 'Washal' (trickle) of the draining of the 'Gharb' (large bucket)": He says: The water of the large bucket became little because it does not encounter what fills it. He means the scarcity of good and its depletion. 'Al-Washal': A remnant of water in a pond, little. Like it is 'Al-Thamad'. It is said for it: The little 'Da'ath'. And 'Al-Hadaj' and 'Al-Hadaj' and 'Al-Mulbitah'. If the water is turbid, it is said: Water 'Tarq', and 'Rafq', and 'Raniq'. If it is a turbid remnant, it is said it is 'Rafqah', 'Gharnaqah', and 'Rajrajah'. 'Al-Amdan': Water soaking in the roots of trees. If the water is pure, it is said: Water 'Azraq' (Blue) and 'Akhdar' (Green). If it is sweet, it is said: Water 'Adhb', and 'Nuffah', and 'Salsal', and 'Salsal', and 'Salasil', and 'Furat'. Al-Lihyani narrated that it is said in its plural 'Furtan'. It is said: Water 'Masus' if it is growing in the [plants?] in their bodies. If it is salty, it is said: Water 'Milh', and 'Zu'aq', and 'Fuqa'', and 'Ujaj', and 'Huraq'. He recites: [Rajaz] Your sea is sweet water, how undutiful/salty ('a'aqqahu')... is your Lord, and the deprived is he who is not given drink. He means: 'ma afqahu' (how poor it is), so he inverted it. If the well is narrow at the head, it is called: 'Sukk'. If it is wide at the head, it is called 'Jilwakh'. If it is atop a hill, it is called 'Jamjamah'. 'Al-Zabar' and 'Al-Dars': The lining of the well. It is said: A well 'Madrusah' and 'Mazburah'. As for his saying: "And the welding of the 'Qayn' (smith) connected": 'Al-Qayn': The blacksmith. Some linguists claim that the Arabs call every craftsman a 'Qayn'. What is agreed upon with no dispute is that they call every cobbler an 'Iskaf'. Al-Shammakh said: [Poem in Sari' meter] Nothing remained except a belt and extremities... and two thin cloths and a delicate shirt. And two branches of Mays wood shaped by an Iskaf. 'Al-Qaynah': The slave girl, whether a singer or not. 'Al-Muqayyinah': The female hairstylist/comber. The Arabs say: The woman 'Qanat' (adorned) the girl 'Qaynan' if she adorned her.
