Ibn Kaysan said: The woman was only named 'Qaynah' because she works with her hands, so she combined adornment and beauty with working with her hands. 'Al-Shadikh': Crushed by a stone or other. 'Al-Shadikhah': The blaze (on a horse) that filled the face but did not take the eyes. If it took the eyes until their eyelids became white, that is 'Al-Ighrab'. The horse is 'Mughrab'. 'Al-Shadakh': The child as long as he is small suckling. 'Al-Amid': The lovestruck/intended ('Ma'mud'), aimed at. 'Al-Amid': The Master. 'Al-Amid': The sad one too. 'Al-Hanbathah': Mixing and confusion. Likewise 'Al-Hanhana' and 'Al-Hanhan'. He recited: [Poem in Basit meter] There was news after you and confusion ('Hanhana')... had you witnessed it, the sermons would not have multiplied. 'Al-Mahil': The intriguer/slanderer. 'Al-Khus': Plural of 'Akhwas' and 'Khawsa'', which is the sunken-eyed among camels. 'Al-Haws' with undotted Ha: Narrowness of the back of the eye. It is said a man 'Ahwas' and a woman 'Hawsa''. 'Al-Haws': Sewing. It is said: Sew ('Hus') the eye of your falcon. 'Al-Rikab': Camels, it has no singular from its wording, and its singular is 'Rahilah'. Linguists say: 'Rakib' (Rider) is not said except for the rider of the camel and the horse specifically, and it is not said for the rider of the donkey and mule. 'Al-Awra'': The ugly word. Hatim al-Ta'i said: [Poem in Tawil meter] And I forgive the ugly word ('Awra'') of the generous one, saving him... and I turn away from the insult of the mean one, honoring myself. 'Al-Shis'': A braided strap. 'Al-Shawa': The extremities, the hands and legs. 'Al-Shawa': The side among sides, and likewise 'Al-Hasha'. He recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] He whose family ended up in the rugged ground says... in which side ('Shawa') did the separating mixture end up? 'Al-Shawa': Plural of 'Shawah', which is the skin of the head specifically. From it is His Almighty's saying (Stripping away the scalp 'Shawa') [Quran 70:16]. 'Al-Shawa': The vile of cattle. The poet said: [Poem in Tawil meter] We ate the vile ('Shawa') until when we found no vile... we pointed to their best ones with fingers. It is said: He shot the game so he 'Ashwahu' (missed a kill shot) if he did not hit its fatal spot. He shot it so he 'Anmahu'. If he hit its fatal spot, it is said: He shot it so he 'Asmahu'. From it: Eat what you killed instantly ('Asmayta') and leave what you made decay ('Anmayta'). 'Al-Khattar': The camel stallion that shakes his tail during aggression and excitement. 'Al-Waqam': Humiliation. His saying: "And the pulling of the rope caused colic ('Allasa') in his neck": He says: It pained him until it swelled and inflamed. 'Al-Illaws': The pain that is in the belly from indigestion. Al-Khalil narrated in *Kitab al-Ayn* from some Bedouins that he said: I was brought a 'Fayjah' in which was 'Zughbadh', so I took from it 'Yam'u', so I became as if I had 'Illaws'. 'Al-Fayjah': The saucer. 'Al-Zughbadh': Butter/Cream. 'Al-Ma'w': Fresh dates. 'Al-Jabdh' and 'Al-Jadhb' are same (pulling). 'Al-Jarir': The rope. 'Radid al-Ama'iz': Pebbles. 'Al-Ama'iz': Plural of 'Am'az' which is the place of coarse pebbles. 'Al-Maras': The rope 'Yamrusu' 'Marsan': If it slips from its channel and gets stuck. If ordered to return it to its channel, it is said 'Amris' 'Amris'. He recited: [Rajaz]

Miserable is the standing of the Sheikh, return the rope, return... either on a 'Qa'w' (bucket?) or he sits back. Abu Zayd said: As for the front of the hand of spears, I do not weep for you except for the bucket and the rope ('Maras'). 'Al-Karab': To tie a rope after the first rope; if the first breaks, the 'Karab' holds the bucket. So the first is 'Al-'Inaj', and the second is 'Al-Karab'. Al-Hutay'ah said: [Poem in Basit meter] A people who, when they tie a knot for their neighbor... tighten the 'Inaj' and tighten above it the 'Karab'. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Bishr ibn Umar told us from Ahmad ibn Yahya, saying Al-Abbas ibn al-Faraj told us, saying Bishr ibn Umar ibn Abdullah ibn Tiqah told us from Abu Zur'ah Amr ibn Jabir from Abdullah ibn Umar [that] the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: 'The Hour will not be established until the Corner (Rukn) and the Maqam are lifted.' Abu Abdullah al-Husayn ibn Muhammad al-Razi told us from Ali ibn Abd al-Aziz from Abu Ubayd al-Qasim ibn Sallam, saying Ibn Abi Za'idah told us from Mujalid ibn Sa'id from Al-Sha'bi that Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, judged regarding the Pincher ('Qarisah'), the Jumper ('Qamisah'), and the Breaker ('Waqisah') with the blood money in thirds. Ibn Abi Za'idah said: The explanation of that is that three girls gathered playing. One of them rode the other, so the third pinched the ridden one, so she jumped, and the rider fell and broke her neck ('wuqisat') and died. So he placed upon the Pincher one-third of the blood money, and upon the Jumper the second third, and voided the third third because it is the share of the rider, because she helped against herself by her riding. Abu al-Qasim said: The origin of 'Waqs' is breaking/crushing. Everything you crushed you have 'waqastahu'. The way was to say 'Mawqusah' because it is said 'Wuqisat' so she is 'Mawqusah', but it came with the wording of the subject (active participle) with the meaning of the object (passive), just as it is said 'Ma' dafiq' (gushing water) meaning 'madfuq' (gushed), and ' 'Ishah radiyah' (content life) meaning 'mardiyyah' (contented with). Abdullah ibn Malik informed us, saying Al-Zubayr informed us, saying Mus'ab ibn Uthman informed me from his father Ja'far ibn al-Zubayr ibn al-Awwam, saying: When it was the Day of the Camel, Ali ibn Abi Talib called out to Al-Zubayr ibn al-Awwam. He went out to him. He said to him: 'O Abu Abdullah, for whom leaving us was lawful, fighting us is forbidden for you.' He said: 'Do you wish that I turn away from you?' He said: 'And why would I not wish that, when you are the Sword of the Messenger of Allah, and the Disciple of the Messenger of Allah, and the in-law of the Messenger of Allah, and the cousin of the Messenger of Allah, and the cousin of the Messenger of Allah?' So he turned away from him. His son Abdullah confronted him and said: 'What called you [to this], father?' He informed him of the news. He said: 'Nay, by Allah, Ibn Abi Talib knew you, knowing that you regarding this matter possess it more than him by the rein of your horse. And were it not for your error, lest people say Ibn Abi Talib made him cowardly, they would surely say he deceived him.' Al-Zubayr said: 'Let whoever wishes say whatever he wishes to say. By Allah, I will never buy my deed with anything. And the world to me is less significant than the excretion of a beetle ('sayhah sahsahah').' And he turned back. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Dayh': Milk with much water mixed in it so it spoils. 'Al-Sahsahah': From 'Al-Sahh' which is pouring. As if he said: The world is lighter to me than a mixture spoiled by water and poured out because there is no benefit in it. Al-Ma'nawi informed us, saying Ishaq ibn Isma'il al-Asbahani told me from Abu al-Qasim Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Karim al-Qurashi from Sa'id ibn Ufayr from Alwan ibn Dawood, saying: Umar ibn al-Khattab went out one night and heard a woman saying from a house: [Poem in Basit meter] Is there a way to wine so I may drink it... or is there a way to Nasr ibn Hajjaj? A woman with her said: 'Who is Nasr ibn Hajjaj?' She said: 'Yes, I wished that he was in a night of the nights of autumn, and the longest night of the nights of winter. And no one else is with him.' Umar summoned her and struck her with the whip a few strikes, then asked about her, but was told nothing but good about her. When it was the next day, he sent for Nasr ibn Hajjaj. He was brought, and he had a head of hair. He said: 'He is exemplified by you and sung about.' He ordered his hair, so it was shaved. Then he went to him in the evening, and saw him in the shaven state more beautiful than with hair. He said to him: 'Do not live with me in a town; choose whichever lands you wish.' The woman wrote to Umar: [Poem in Basit meter] Say to the Imam whose rages are feared... What do I have to do with wine or Nasr ibn Hajjaj? I only sang to Abu Hafs [Umar] with other than them... drinking milk and a glance short, languid. Do not make suspicion a truth or be certain of it... Indeed the way is the way of the fearful, the hopeful. Indeed passion, piety bridled it so trained it... until it acknowledged bridling and saddling. So Umar sent to her: 'Nothing but good has reached us about you.' Nasr ibn Hajjaj wrote to him: [Poem in Tawil meter] Just because Al-Dhalfa' sang one day with a wish... and some of the talk of women is passion. You thought of me the matter after which there is no... remaining, while I have no speech in the assembly. So I become exiled without suspicion... while I had a standing in the two Meccas.

And prevented me from what you think, piety... and fathers of truth, past, noble. And prevents her from her wishes, worship... and a state she has among her people and fasting. And these are our two states, so are you returning... while a hump and a camel's hump have been cut from us? So he sent to him: 'No return, so depart to Basra.' He stayed with a man from his people called Mujashi' ibn Mas'ud, who had a wife called Khadra' of Banu Sulaym. She was of the most beautiful women, and she was the first to wear transparent clothes (*Shufuf*). While they were eating dinner one night, Nasr wrote for her on the ground—and the woman could read and write—: "I love you a love that if it were above you it would shade you, and if it were beneath you it would carry you." The woman said: "And I, by Allah." The Sheikh said to her: "What is this?" She said: "He said to me: How good is the milk of your she-camel? So I said: And I [think so], by Allah." The Sheikh said: "What is this like this?" Then he overturned the bowl on the place he saw him writing in, and called for a teacher at the door of his house. He said: "Read this." He said: It is "I love you a love that if it were above you it would shade you, and if it were beneath you it would carry you." The Sheikh said: "Indeed." Then he turned to him and said: "O son of my brother, if divorce is thrice, then she is divorced thrice." He said: "And she is divorced if a house ever gathers me and her." Then he departed to Fars. Al-Yazidi informed us, saying: My uncle Abu al-Abbas al-Fadl ibn Muhammad al-Yazidi was asked about the meaning of the saying of the Prophet (PBUH): "Every Muslim is 'Muharram' upon a Muslim." He said: 'Al-Muharram' in the speech of the Arabs is the one refraining/holding back. Its meaning is: The Muslim holds back from the wealth of the Muslim, his honor, and his blood. He said: And Sawwar the Judge recited to me for Miskin al-Darimi: [Poem in Tawil meter] Insults came to me from men as if they were... beetles of the night having no scorpions. They settled on my honor, so I refrained ('Ahramtu') from them... and in Allah there is a Neighbor who does not sleep, and a Seeker. He said: And my grandfather recited to me for Al-Ra'i: [Poem in Kamil meter] They killed Ibn Affan the Caliph while he was refraining ('Muharram')... and he called, and I have not seen the like of him, forsaken. He said: And there are two opinions in it: That 'Al-Muharram' is the one holding back from fighting them. And the other: That he was named 'Muharram' only because he was killed in the middle of the sacred months. He said: So it was said to Al-Fadl: Do you have Jahili poetry regarding this? He said: Muhammad ibn Habib recited to me for Akhdar ibn Inad al-Mazini, and he is Jahili: [Poem in Tawil meter] My turning away and pardon has become long regarding her... who informs about him, while hearts are hearts. And my waiting for the turn of forbearance from you has become long... so that affection may return, and the return is near. And I do not see you refraining ('Muharramin') from that which... I hated, and from it are scars in the hearts. So do not feel safe from it, the repayment of your deed... so a killed one gloats or a beloved is saddened. And faults appear from us in sleep and from you... when we throw speech at each other. Abu al-Qasim said: Niftawayh recited to us, saying Tha'lab recited to us from Ibn al-A'rabi: [Poem in Tawil meter] O greet Layla, a departure has come from you... and distance, even if separation is hard, is long. And visit Layla, for a greeting... to her before the grazing of the swift camels is little. For you do not know when the white camels tuck up [to travel]... with us, whether it is destitution or enemies and distractions. Niftawayh recited to us for Al-Sayyid ibn Muhammad al-Himyari: [Poem in Tawil meter] I will take from myself for myself, perhaps it... by my taking for it from it, will be budged from a veil. Three days of the month, an oath... I fast, and sometimes I stand for the pre-dawn [prayer]. And verses of poetry, perfected, I say them... to the family of the Messenger of Allah, noble ones of the nobles. Abu Abdullah al-Kirmani said: What is counted in the creation (anatomy) of the horse from the names of birds: 'Al-Suradan': Two veins flanking the tongue. It is said: Whiteness in the back. And 'Al-Dhubab':

The pupil of the eye. 'Al-Dik' (Rooster): What curved of his jaws. 'Al-Hamah' (Owl): The 'Sujalah' (?) in the brain, as if it is the vein of the 'Baydaq' (?). It is said: They are behind the 'Qawnasah' of his head. 'Al-Ya'sub' (Drone bee/Queen bee): The thin elongated blaze. 'Al-Hamah': The rear of the brain, and it is said it is the brain. 'Al-'Usfur' (Sparrow): The growing place of the forelock and its base. 'Al-'Usfur': A protruding bone in every forehead. If the blaze rises and becomes thin and does not exceed the eyes, it is 'Al-'Usfur'. 'Al-Salsal': The rear of the forelock. 'Al-Jibah': The base of the ear. 'Al-Kharab' (Male bustard): The blackness in the ear from its outside. It is said: The backs of the two horns. 'Al-Shamamah': The whorl in the neck. 'Al-Khattaf' (Swallow): A whorl at the kicking place. 'Al-Qatah' (Sandgrouse): The seat of the rider. 'Al-Ghurab' (Crow): The tip of the hip from the outside. 'Al-Rakhamah' (Vulture): The muscle of the leg. 'Al-Namid' (?): The tip of the 'Qanab' (tail base). In *Al-Iqd al-Farid*: 'Al-Nahid': The chick of the sandgrouse. And it is said: 'Al-Kulfah' and 'Al-Nasr' (Vulture). The inside of the hoof like the pebbles and date stones. 'Al-Saq': The leg of the horse. 'Al-Rijl': The foot of the horse. 'Al-Farashah' (Butterfly/Moth): The bones of the forehead. 'Al-Asqa'': The white forelock. 'Al-'Uqaban' (Two Eagles): The two pupils. 'Al-Harran' (?): The ridges of the ear. 'Al-Saqran' (Two Hawks): The places of the voice from the two flanks. 'Al-Kursu'': The head of the forearm adjoining the pastern. 'Al-Sa'danah': What is stripped from the back of the forelegs of the horse, like the two 'Hamat' (calluses?), which are white hairs growing in the hand or leg. 'Al-Warasan' (Dove): The upper lid of the eye. It is said: 'Al-Dharaq': White marking (Tahjil) just below the hair. Another said: 'Al-Zarq' is whiteness that does not surround the whole bone but is a splash. It is said in other sources: 'Al-Salsalah': The forelock of the horse. And 'Al-Salsalah': The ring-dove.

Issue: Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad said: Sibawayh mentioned in the diminutive of 'Ahwa' (Dark/Reddish-black) doctrines; I have clarified the intent of their proponents in them, and what analogy necessitates. As for the doctrine of Isa ibn Umar, it is incorrect according to him [Sibawayh] and us, because he used to say in the diminutive of 'Ahwa': 'Ahayy' and make it tryptote (fully declinable/munsarif). The addition is in its beginning. He argues that it decreased from the weight [of the verb]. Sibawayh compelled him to make fully declinable a man named 'Yada'' or 'Yazin' because it has decreased from [the weight] 'Yaf'alu' while the addition is in its beginning. No one makes this fully declinable because the addition by which it resembled verbs is in its beginning, which is the Ya. Likewise 'Ahwa', if diminished, it is said 'Ahayy'. So making it fully declinable is not permissible because the Hamza is in its beginning. The preventer of it from being fully declinable according to us is the weight along with the addition. Do you not see that you make fully declinable a man you named 'Khubz' or 'Busr' because the addition along with the weight has ceased, even if you intend by it the meaning of 'Af'al'. Abu al-Abbas said: And the doctrine of Abu Amr ibn al-A'la, Sibawayh did not approve of it, and I follow him in that, because he used to say in the diminutive 'Ahiyy' and strengthen the Ya (Tashdid) and put it in the genitive [treat it as sound?]. Sibawayh compelled him by his analogy to say in the diminutive of 'Ata': 'Atiyy' with the genitive, and no one says this, yet it is necessary by his analogy. Abu Amr only did this because three Ya's gather, so the Tanwin goes to the last of them after assimilating the Ya of diminutive into the Waw, so he says: It is in my view from the category of 'Jawarin' and 'Qawasin'. It is not far from it in my view. It is said to him: The category of 'Jawarin' and 'Qawasin', why we called for it is that movement is impossible in it, so we made the Tanwin a compensation as we made it in 'Yawma'idhin' and in his saying: [Poem in Khafif meter] They sought our peace *wa lata awanin* (while it was not a time)... so we answered that it is not a time of survival. Since 'adhan' is not added to what explains it, then what clarifies it was deleted from it, it became necessary to build it and make the Tanwin in it a compensation for the deleted. Likewise his saying 'Yawma'idhin', it was only nunated when what clarifies it was deleted, so the Tanwin was made compensation for it. Moreover, 'Jawarin' and 'Ghawashin' have decreased from 'Fawa'il' and the addition of resemblance is not in it. Do you not see that you do not nunate 'Jawari' in the state of accusative due to its completeness? Even if you argued that three Ya's gathered, then delete and prevent declension as you do in 'Yadi'' and 'Ya'idu' if you name with either of them, according to what Sibawayh compelled you with, and it is necessary for you by your analogy. As for Yunus ibn Habib, he used to say in the diminutive of 'Ahwa': 'Ahyaw', making the Waw apparent and not assimilating because the Waw is voweled, sound in the plural in your saying 'Ahawin'. This is according to the dialect of one who says in 'Aswad': 'Usaywid'. To this was Sibawayh's doctrine, so he said: It is the analogy because he diminished based on the origin and removed the Lam of the verb due to the meeting of two sukun-letters, as it goes in 'Qadin' and 'Ramin' and in 'U'aymin', the diminutive of 'A'ma'. He argues with the like of what Abu Amr argued with and by appending it to the category of 'Jawarin' and 'Qawadin' and 'Ghawashin' because it is a Ya preceded by a Kasra and Waw. Abu al-Abbas said: This is closer to correctness and more touching to it, but what...

I choose and do not permit other than it is to say in the diminutive of 'Ahwa': 'Ahayya ya fata' (Ahayya, O youth), and I delete the last Ya which is the Lam, and I do not nunate because the addition in its beginning is like the addition of 'Yajidu' and 'Yada'u'. And because I have seen them, when Ya's gather, delete for lightening in the like of 'Qusayy' and 'Ghaniyy' when they attribute to them and to what is like them. I also found them deleting Lams and voweling 'Ayns in the like of 'Yad' and 'Dam' and what resembles them. So I delete, and vowel, and do not nunate.

Issue: Sibawayh said in his book: "Ma aghfalahu 'anka shay'an" (How oblivious he is of you!), meaning leave doubt. Scholars differed regarding Sibawayh's intent in this issue and its explanation. Al-Akhfash Sa'id ibn Mas'adah said: Since I understood, I have been asking about this, and I did not find anyone who knows it in reality. Yunus used to say: Those who knew this have gone. The reason for this is that this speech ran like a proverb, and in it is deletion whose usage explicitly is rare, so those who knew it passed away. Al-Mazini said: Sibawayh's purpose in this is clear because he said "Ma aghfalahu 'anka shay'an", meaning leave doubt. So the installer (Nasib) of 'shay'an' is the mentioned verb which is 'aghfala', its estimation is 'aghfala 'anka ghaflatan', so he installed 'ghaflah' as a verbal noun (Masdar), then put 'shay'an' in place of the Masdar. Al-Akhfash said: This speech is not exclamation. The meaning of the speech is "Alladhi aghfalahu 'anka shay'un" (That which he neglected of you is a thing/little), i.e., a small matter of matters. So the predicate of the inchoative is implied, and 'Ma' is interpreted as 'Alladhi' (relative pronoun) upon the news. Then he turns to a companion of his and says to him: Leave doubt regarding what I informed you of because it is true. Al-Zajjaj used to say: I did not see in these interpretations anything befitting the issue. Its explanation in reality is according to what Abu al-Abbas al-Mubarrad explained to us. He said: The estimation of this speech is that there is a man who has a friend advising him, and an enemy hating him but showing him affection hypocritically and concealing enmity. His friend said to him: 'So-and-so is an enemy to you.' He said: 'He is not an enemy to me but a friend.' His friend said to him in reality: 'Far from it! The matter is not as you estimated, and he is indeed an enemy against you.' Then he turned to him and said: 'Ma aghfalahu 'anka' (How oblivious he is of you!). Meaning: Indeed your enemy is oblivious of you; if he knew you were this confident in him, he would have destroyed you. Then he said to him after that 'shay'an' (a thing/little), so he put it in accusative by an implied verb, as if he said: Think a little ('shay'an') and look a little ('shay'an'). Meaning if you thought the slightest thought and looked the slightest look, it would become clear to you that he is an enemy to you, and you would not rely on him after this. 'Shay'' is used in the place of what is very small in amount, like your saying: This Dinar increases a carat and two grains. If the amount of increase is very small, it is said: This Dinar increases 'a thing' (shay'an). Likewise, the man placed 'Al-Shay'' in his issue in place of the slightest look and thought. This speech became obscure because the usage of this implied element we mentioned is rare in their speech. This is the meaning of Sibawayh's saying following it: 'Ma aghfalahu 'anka shay'an', i.e., leave doubt. This is clear and evident, and it is the meaning of the issue in reality. It is among the implied things that are hidden from one who has not heard them explicit. Do you not see that the installer of 'shay'an' is not the one mentioned in the beginning of the speech? Sibawayh only mentioned this speech in the chapter of 'Lawla', and the implied is after this. Parallel to it is the saying of the Arabs: 'Kana dhalika hina'idhin al-ana' (That was then, now). Do you not see that 'then' is a time that has passed, and 'now' is a time you are in. The meaning of the speech is only: That was then, and listen to me now. Or do you not see that the implied element to which 'now' connects is other than the speech mentioned first? Likewise the implied in the chapter of 'Lawla', because if you said: 'Lawla Zaydun la-akramtuka' (Were it not for Zayd, I would have honored you). You only raise Zayd by inchoative, and he has no predicate in appearance. The predicate is only estimated and implied. The estimation is: Were it not for Zayd, whom I fear and respect—or something similar—I would have honored you. So the Lam is the answer, and the predicate is implied as I mentioned to you. This implication is necessary, otherwise the speech would not be straight. The implied in the speech of the Arabs is more than can be counted, except that three principles encompass it. Implied that is permitted to be explicit or implied, like your saying to a man you saw hitting a man: 'Al-Ra'sa' (The head), you mean: Hit the head. Or you saw people expecting the crescent moon then they said 'Allahu Akbar', so you said: 'Al-Hilala' (The crescent), you mean: They saw the crescent. Or you see a man in travel gear so you said: 'Makkata' (Mecca), i.e., and my Lord, meaning you want Mecca. If you wish you make this implied explicit, and if you wish you imply it. Al-Asma'i said: A man from Banu Tamim said on the Day of Jabalah when a one-eyed camel fought desperately against them: 'O Banu Tamim, a one-eyed one and possessor of a tusk?' by way of omen. He said: Then I said to some Bedouins: Do you know him in such-and-such place or 'Jadha', which is a place filled with water? He said: 'Yes, wa jadha', i.e., I knew him at Jadha. And implied that is not permitted to be explicit, which is your saying: 'A-Zaydan darabtahu?' (Is it Zayd you hit him?), 'A-Abdallah akramtahu?' (Is it Abdullah you honored him?) and the like. It is accusative by a verb that does not appear. The poet said: [Poem in Wafir meter] Is it Tha'labah, the horsemen, or Riyah... you equated Tuhayyah and the Khushab with? Likewise the saying of the other: [Poem in Munsarih meter] I have become bearing no weapon nor... owning the head of the camel if it shies.

And the wolf, I fear him if I am alone with him... alone, and I fear the winds and the rain. Likewise what resembles it is accusative by an implied verb that is not permitted to be explicit. Likewise their saying: 'Iyyaka wa al-sharra' (Beware of evil) and 'Iyyaka wa al-mira'a' (Beware of dispute), accusative by a verb that does not appear. Likewise his saying: [Poem in Tawil meter] Beware, beware of dispute, for it... is a call to evil and a bringer of evil. Showing the installer of 'Iyyaka' is not permitted. And 'Al-Mira'' is accusative by an implied verb other than the one that installed 'Iyyaka', and the estimation is 'Leave the dispute', and showing it is permitted. Parallels of this implied that is not permitted to be explicit are many in their speech, and it is like his saying: 'Ma aghfalahu 'anka shay'an' (How oblivious he is of you!), in their leaving the showing of the installer for 'shay'an', and their using it implied according to what I explained to you. And implied that is not permitted to be used except after the agreement of the addressee on it. That is if you come to a man to whose mind hitting Zayd or honoring him has not occurred, it is not permissible for you to say to him: 'Zaydan' (Zayd - acc.), installing it by an implied verb because there is no indication of it. So upon these three aspects is the implication of verbs in the speech of the Arabs; analogize upon it, Allah willing. Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Mahmud ibn Muhammad al-Wasiti told us in Wasit, saying Ahmad ibn Sa'id al-Zuhri told us, saying Mukram ibn Muhriz ibn al-Mahdi told us from Abd al-Rahman ibn Amr al-Khuza'i from the descendants of Umm Ma'bad at Qudayd, saying my father Muhriz ibn al-Mahdi told me from his grandfather Hakim ibn Hisham from his father Hubaysh ibn Khalid, the slain of Al-Batha' on the Day of Conquest, that the Prophet (PBUH) when he left Mecca, left it migrating, he and Abu Bakr and Abu Bakr's freed slave Amir ibn Fuhayrah, and their guide Abdullah ibn al-Arqat. They passed by the two tents of Umm Ma'bad al-Khuza'iyyah. She was a 'Barzah' (visible/mature) 'Jaldah' (strong) woman who sat in the courtyard of the dome (tent) then fed and gave drink. They asked her for meat and dates to buy from her, but they did not find anything of that with her. The people were provisionless ('Murmilin') and in a drought ('Mushtin'). He (PBUH) looked at a sheep in the corner of the tent and said: 'What is this sheep, O Umm Ma'bad?' She said: 'A sheep which fatigue has left behind the flock.' He said: 'Does it have any milk?' She said: 'It is more fatigued than that.' He said: 'Do you permit me to milk it?' She said: 'Yes, may my father and mother be your ransom, if you see any milking in it, then milk it.' So the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) called for it, wiped its udder with his hand, mentioned the name of Allah Almighty, and prayed for her regarding her sheep. It spread its legs for him, flowed [with milk], and ruminated. He called for a vessel that satisfies the group ('Yurbidu al-Raht'), and milked into it a pouring stream until the froth rose over it. Then he gave her drink until she was satisfied, and gave his companions drink until they were satisfied, and drank last of them, then drank again. Then he milked it a second time after the start until he filled the vessel, then left it with her, swore allegiance to her, and departed from her. He did not stay long until her husband Abu Ma'bad came driving lean goats, swaying from weakness, their marrow is little. When Abu Ma'bad saw [the milk], he wondered and said: 'From where did you get this, O Umm Ma'bad, while the sheep are distant and barren, and there is no milking one in the house?' She said: 'No, by Allah, except that a blessed man passed by us, whose condition was such and such.' He said: 'Describe him to me, O Umm Ma'bad.' She said: 'I saw a man of evident beauty, bright face, handsome face, not marred by a protruding belly ('Thajlah') nor disgraced by a small head ('Sa'lah'). Handsome, well-proportioned. Or she said: In the doubt of Abu Abrahah: In his eyes is intense blackness ('Da'aj'), and in his eyelashes is curve ('Ghataf'), and in his neck is length ('Sata''), and in his voice is huskiness ('Sahal'). Arched brows ('Azajj'), connected brows ('Aqran'). If he is silent, dignity is upon him, and if he speaks, he rises and brightness covers him. The most beautiful of people and most splendid from afar, and the best of them and sweetest from near. Sweet of logic, decisive ('Fasl'), neither little nor prattle. As if his logic is beads of a necklace descending from a string. Medium height, not conspicuous by length, nor does the eye despise him for shortness. A branch between two branches, so he is the freshest of the three in branch, and the best of them in stature. He has companions who surround him; if he speaks they listen to his speech, and if he commands they race to his command. Served, gathered around, neither frowning nor refuting.' Abu Ma'bad said: 'This, by Allah, is the companion of Quraysh whom we hear about in Mecca what we hear. I have intended to accompany him, and I will surely do that if I find a way to it.' A voice was heard in Mecca, high, and they did not know its owner, saying: [Poem in Tawil meter] May Allah, Lord of mankind, reward with the best of His reward... two companions who settled in the two tents of Umm Ma'bad. They descended by it with guidance, so she was guided by him... for he has succeeded who becomes the companion of Muhammad. So O family of Qusayy, what has Allah removed from you... through him of deeds that cannot be repaid and sovereignty. Let Banu Ka'b be congratulated for the place of their girl... and her seat for the believers as an observation post. Ask your sister about her sheep and her vessels... for if you ask the sheep, it will testify. He called a barren sheep, so it became pregnant... for him with pure milk, the udder of the sheep frothing. When Hassan ibn Thabit al-Ansari heard this poetry, he answered the caller with his saying: [Poem in Tawil meter] Indeed a people have failed, their Prophet departed from them... and he has succeeded who travels to him at night and morning.

He departed from a people whose minds strayed... and settled upon a people with a renewed light. Their Lord guided them by him after error... and He guided them; whoever follows the Truth is guided. And riding camels of guidance from them descended upon the people of Yathrib... settling upon them with the greatest happiness. Let Abu Bakr be congratulated for the happiness of his grandfather (luck)... by his companionship; whoever Allah makes happy is happy. Let Banu Ka'b be congratulated for the place of their girl... and her seat for the believers as an observation post. Abu al-Qasim said: As for her saying "Kanat barzatan jaldatan": 'Al-Barzah': The one appearing. He says: She was past [youth] so she would appear to people and show herself, and was not like the young veiled one. It is said: A 'Jald' man and a 'Jaldah' woman, of evident 'Jald', and that is from strength. I reckon the origin of that is from 'Al-Jald' which is what is hard of the earth. And his saying: "Al-Qawm Murmilin": He says: Their provision has run out. Abu Zayd al-Ansari said: The man 'Armala' and 'Aqwa': His provision ran out, whether in travel or residence. And 'Al-Musintun': Those entering the 'Sanah' (year). And 'Al-Sanah': Famine and drought. In another narration according to what Al-Sa'igh informed us from Ibn Qutaybah: And the people were 'Mushtin': i.e., entering into winter, because winter is a time of hardship and distress. Ibn Qutaybah recited as a witness to this narration: [Poem in Wafir meter] If winter descends at the abode of a people... avoid the abode of their people in winter. It is said: 'Kasar' and 'Kasr' just as it is said: 'Bizr' and 'Bazr', and 'Nift' and 'Naft', and 'Jisr' and 'Jasr'. A side of it. Ibn Qutaybah said: It is the flap that follows its edge on the ground. There are two dialects in it. It is said: 'Kasar' and 'Kasr' just as it is said: 'Bizr' and 'Bazr', and 'Nift' and 'Naft', and 'Jisr' and 'Jasr'. And his saying: "Fatafajjat 'alayhi", he says: She opened her legs to be milked. Likewise it is said: The man 'Nafaja': If he opened between his legs to urinate. And his saying: "Fada'a bi-ina'in yurbidu al-rahta": He means a large vessel from which the group drinks and they become satisfied until it prevents them from rising so they lie down ('Yarbidu'). Al-Riyashi said: It is said the sun 'Arbadat': If its heat becomes intense, so the sheep and gazelle lie down ('tarbidu'), making them lie down and not rise. Al-Kisa'i said: The largest of cups is 'Al-Taban', it satisfies twenty men. After it is 'Al-Sahn', close to it. Then 'Al-'Usf', it satisfies four. Then 'Al-Qadah', it satisfies two. Then 'Al-Qabab', it satisfies one. 'Al-Raht': Between three to ten. Likewise 'Al-Nafar'. 'Al-'Usbah': Above that to forty. And his saying "Fahalabat fihi thajjan": i.e., pouring. It is said: 'Bakhbakhtu' the water and other things if you poured it. And his saying: "Hatta 'alahu al-baha'": He says: The milk rose in the vessel, which is the whiteness of its foam. 'Al-Raghwah' and 'Al-Thumal' are one. And his saying: "Yasuqu a'nuzan 'ijafan": i.e., lean, no marrow in them. And his saying: "Yatasawakna": i.e., swaying from weakness. Ka'b said: [Poem in Kamil meter] Groups, the journey took turns on them, so their body... is bare, swaying, and the heart is snatched. Some narrate it: "Tatasawakna hazlan", i.e., they became equal in leanness as if they shared in it. 'Al-Sha'u 'Azib': i.e., far from the home in the pasture. 'Al-Hiyal' plural of 'Ha'il', which is the one that did not conceive. As for her saying in his description (PBUH): "Ra'aytu rajulan zahira al-wada'ah": 'Al-Wada'ah': Good looks and beauty. 'Al-Ablaj': The shining, from their saying 'taballaja' the morning and 'inbalaja': if it exploded. She did not mean by it the separation of eyebrows because she described him as 'Aqran' (connected eyebrows). And her saying: "Lam ya'ibhu thajlah": 'Al-Thajal': Greatness of the belly and relaxation of its lower part. It is said: A man 'Athjal' and a woman 'Thajla'', and 'Al-Thujlah' is like it. And her saying: "Wa lam yuzri bihi sa'lah": 'Al-Sa'lah': Smallness of the head. 'Al-Saqal': Thinness of the flank (*Saqlah*). 'Al-Wasim': The beautiful. Likewise 'Al-Muqassam', 'Al-Qasim', 'Al-Qasamah', and 'Al-Wasamah': Beauty. 'Al-Da'aj': Intensity of the blackness of the eye. 'Al-Ashfar': The edges of the eyelids on which hair grows, and the hair is 'Al-Hudb'. She made the 'Ashfar' here the hair itself because the Arabs name a thing by the name of the thing if it adjoins it or relates to it. 'Al-Wataf': That the eyelash of the eye is long until it curves. 'Al-Sata'': Length of the neck. 'Al-Sahal': Like huskiness in the voice. 'Al-Zajaj': Length of the eyebrows and abundance of their hair. 'Al-Qaran': That their tips meet. And her saying "La ya'lasu min tul": She says he is not of great length so his tall counterpart despairs of out-talling him. "Wa la taqtahimuhu 'aynun min qisar": i.e., the eye does not despise him nor scorn him for shortness. And her saying: "Mahshud Mahfud": 'Al-Mahfud': The served. 'Al-Hafadah': Servants and helpers. 'Al-Mahshud': From their saying a spring 'Hashd' with people, i.e., a large gathering. And her saying: "La 'abis wa la mughtadd": She says: Not frowning of face. 'Al-Mughtadd': The blamed. She says: He is not blamed for anything he does. Ibn Qutaybah narrated it "La 'abis wa la mu'tad" with 'Ayn, and went to 'Al-'Ada'' which is injustice. 'Al-Durr': The meat of the udder. 'Al-Sarih': The pure of milk and other things.

Abu al-Abbas Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Sa'id al-Kufi told us, saying Ahmad ibn Zakariya told us, saying Ali ibn Ubayd told us from Sulayman ibn Asir from Ibrahim from Alqamah and Masruq and Al-Aswad from Aisha, she said: The Prophet (PBUH) used to kiss me while he was fasting, but he was the most controlling of you for his need/desire (*Irb*). Abu al-Abbas ibn Khundah said: I heard Ahmad ibn Abd al-Hamid al-Harithi when a man asked him: Is it Sulayman ibn Yasir or Sulayman ibn Asir? He said: Ibn Asir with Alif. Abu al-Qasim said: 'Al-Irbah': Need. Likewise 'Al-Arab', 'Al-Irb', and 'Al-Ma'rabah'. As for 'Al-Urbah' with Damma: It is the knot. The origin of 'Sawm' (Fasting) in the speech of the Arabs: Withholding. It is said: The day fasted (*sama*) if the sun stood at noon. And the horses fasted if they stood still. Al-Nabigha said: [Poem in Basit meter] Horses fasting and horses not fasting... under the dust, and horses chewing the reins. Abu al-Qasim al-Sa'igh informed us: He said Ibn Qutaybah told us, he said it was narrated that Suwayd came to Mecca, so the Prophet (PBUH) addressed him (*tasadda lahu*) and offered him Islam. Suwayd said to him: 'Perhaps what you have is like what I have.' He said: 'And what do you have?' He said: 'The Scroll (*Majallah*) of Luqman.' His saying: 'Tasadda': Means addressed/exposed himself. 'Al-Majallah': A scroll containing some wisdom. He recites for Al-Nabigha: [Poem in Tawil meter] Their scroll (*Majallatuhum*) is the nature of God and their religion... is straight, so they hope for nothing but the outcomes. This is how some people narrate it with Jim. He said: Meaning their books which they used to read. Some narrated it "Mahallatuhum" (their place) with undotted Ha. He said: Meaning Jerusalem because it was their abode, meaning the city, so for that reason he said 'Mahallatuhum'. Abu Bakr Yusuf ibn Ya'qub ibn al-Bahlul al-Azraq told us, saying Humayd ibn al-Rabi' told us, saying Masinah told us from Abu al-Jahm from Al-Zuhri from Abu Salamah from Abu Huraira: The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: 'Imru' al-Qays is the leader of the poets to the Fire.' Abu al-Qasim said: There is no disagreement among scholars I know of that this wording came out generally but is specific; it only refers to the poetry of the disbelievers specifically, excluding the Islamic ones. The proof of that is that the Prophet (PBUH) was praised and gave rewards for poetry, for he rewarded Ka'b ibn Zuhayr with the Burda (mantle) which is with the Caliphs today, so he sold it for twenty thousand dirhams. And Al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib, Al-Abbas ibn Mirdas, and Hassan ibn Thabit praised him. And the Prophet (PBUH) said to Hassan: 'Answer Quraysh regarding their poetry, and the Holy Spirit is with you.' And most of the Companions recited poetry. Al-Akhfash informed us from Al-Mubarrad that the Prophet (PBUH) said to Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di: 'Recite to me.' So he recited to him: [Poem in Tawil meter] And there is no good in forbearance if it does not have... impulses (*bawadir*) protecting its purity from being muddied. And there is no good in the ignorance of one if he does not have... a forbearing one who, when the matter is brought, issues it. So he said to him: 'You have done well, may Allah not scatter your mouth.' He said: So Al-Nabigha lived long—and he said he lived long until the time of Ibn al-Zubayr—and his mouth was like cool hail (*barad*), no tooth fell out and his gums did not recede. Al-Ma'nawi informed us, saying Al-Fadl ibn al-Hubbab al-Jumahi informed us, saying Muhammad ibn Salam informed me, saying Abu Yahya al-Dabbi told us: Dhul-Rummah met Ru'ba ibn al-Ajjaj. Dhul-Rummah said to him: 'What is the meaning of the saying of Al-Ra'i: [Poem in Tawil meter] They made [camels] with little milk kneel at night on a hidden path... a little, while Canopus had set (*aq'a*) and turned away (*'arrada*)?' Ru'ba began to fall here and there once, until he said to him: 'Woe to you, it is a land between the grassy and the barren.' He said: 'It is so.' Al-Ma'nawi informed us, saying Abu Khalifah told us, saying Salam told me, saying Muhammad ibn Aban ibn al-Ahwas ibn Muhammad the poet told me: He used to love the sister of his wife and concealed that, and composed amorous poetry about her without explicitly naming her. She married "Matar", so the matter overcame him and he began to say: [Poem in Wafir meter] Is it that a dove called a mate (*hadila*) at Dhat Falj... with the sunrise on a branch of a bathhouse? You remained as if your tear was a string of arranged pearls... a sword fell so the arrangement gave it up. You die of longing and joy and live... and you, with the atmosphere of your disease, are infatuated. As if you, from remembering Umm Hafs... are watered by a land where the clouds settle. She settled the slope of Uhud, and the nearest of... her dwellings is Al-Shabikah or Sanam. Peace of Allah, O Matar, be upon her... and not upon you, O Matar, be peace. So may God not forgive those who married her... their sins, even if they prayed and fasted. As if the owners of the marriage of Salma... on the morning Matar sought her, were asleep. If marriage makes a thing lawful... then her marriage to Matar is forbidden ('Haram'). If they had married none but a match... her palms would have been [for] the King, the Gallant.

So divorce her, for you are not a match for her... otherwise, the sharp sword will cut your parting. As for his saying: "A-in nada hadilan", I heard Al-Akhfash say: I heard Al-Mubarrad say: Our companions say: The pigeon 'Hadala' 'Hadilan', and 'Hadara' 'Hadiran': if it made a sound. And the camel 'Hadara', but 'Hadala' is not said. Others of our companions permit it. If it trilled, it is said 'Gharrada' 'Taghridan'. 'Taghrid' can be for humans and its origin is from birds. Some of them say: 'Al-Hadil': The male pigeon. They argue with the saying of Al-Ra'i: [Poem in Kamil meter] Like a hoopoe, the archers broke his wing... calling on the middle of the road a 'Hadil'. And 'Saq Hurr': The male of the turtledoves and pigeons. From it is the saying of Al-Tirimmah likening the archers to pigeons: [Poem in Madid meter] Between archers (*az'ar*) in a dark place... like the backs of the leg, the leg of the pigeon. As for his saying: "Salamu Allahi ya Mataran 'alayha" (Peace of Allah, O Matar, upon her), it is a singular vocative and he nunated it for necessity. Al-Khalil, Al-Mazini, and Sibawayh choose to nunate it in the nominative ("Ya Matarun") and say: When we were forced to nunate it, we nunated it according to its wording. This is what Al-Farra used to hold and choose. As for Abu Amr ibn al-A'la, Yunus, and Isa ibn Amr al-Jarmi, they recite it: "Ya Mataran 'alayha" with accusative and Tanwin, and say: The Tanwin returned it to its origin, and its origin is accusative. It is like a noun that is diptote (does not accept Tanwin); if the poet is forced to nunate it, he nunates it and declines it fully and returns it to its origin. The poet said: [Poem in Kamil meter] I have not seen nor do I see in my time... like girls (*ka-jawarin*) playing in the desert. Do you not see how he nunated it and put it in the genitive? The saying in my view is the saying of Al-Khalil and his companions. The summary of that: The singular proper noun in the vocative is built on Damma due to its resemblance, according to Al-Khalil and Abu Amr and their companions, to sounds; and according to others due to its occurrence in the place of the pronoun. If Tanwin attaches to it in poetic necessity, the cause for which it was built still exists, so it is nunated according to its wording (nominative), because we have seen built words that are nunated like 'Ihin' and 'Ghaqin' and similar. It is not like the diptote, because the origin of the diptote is full declension. Many Arabs do not refrain from fully declining anything in poetic necessity or otherwise, except 'Af'ala minka'. On this dialect was read "Qawariran Qawariran min fiddah" [Quran 76:15-16] by nunating both of them. So if it is nunated, it is returned to its origin. The singular proper noun in the vocative was never pronounced accusative nunated except in poetic necessity. This is clear and evident. Abdullah ibn Malik informed us, saying Al-Zubayr ibn Bakkar informed us from his uncle, saying: Umar ibn Abdullah ibn Abi Rabi'ah went out to Syria. Jamil met him and said: 'Recite to me some of your poetry, O Jamil.' So he recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] My two friends, in your life, have you seen... a killed one crying out of love for his killer before me? Then he said: 'Recite to me, O Abu al-Khattab.' So he recited: [Poem in Tawil meter] Have you not asked the ruins and the dwelling place... at the belly of Hulayyat, effaced, empty? Is there a messenger from three buxom girls... and a fourth completing beauty altogether? When we stood together and I greeted, faces approached... beauty guarded them from being veiled. They feigned ignorance of each other in recognition when they recognized me... and said: 'A man seeking, gone astray and humbled.' And they brought close the causes of passion to the enslaved... measuring a cubit whenever they measured a finger. So I said to the one praising them in beauty: You have only... harmed, so are you able to benefit so you benefit? Jamil shouted: 'This, by Allah, is the one from whom the amorous poetry (*Nasib*) is taken,' and he recited nothing until they parted. It is said: The poet 'Nasaba' with the woman 'Yansibu' 'Nasiban': if he mentioned her beauties in his poetry. And he attributed the man 'Yansibuhu' 'Nasaban' and 'Nisbah'. Al-Akhfash recited to us, saying Al-Mubarrad recited to us, saying Al-Attawi recited to me for himself eulogizing Ahmad ibn Abi Du'ad: [Poem in Tawil meter] The creaking of the bier is not what you hear... but it is the loins of people breaking. And the scent of musk is not the fragrance of his embalming... but it is that praise left behind. Ibn Durayd recited to us for himself: [Poem in Majzu' al-Raml meter] Is it from the sun in the evening... those veils were uncovered? Or from the moon was removed... at midnight that head-covering? Or on the sides of the neck of a gazelle... were those earrings hung? Or did fate show you what... the standing people did not see? Indeed the ruling of wide eyes... is unjust upon creation. They brought close to... passion, and passion is far-throwing. So they removed patience from me... and it was for me a companion, an ally. Oh, what a drink of sickness... mixed with dissolved poison. Fate drove it to my soul... openly while it was averse. O daughter of the Yemeni king (*Qayl*), and for Time are turns.

If it became shining... it has one day an eclipse. Or if it blew as a breeze... it has one day a hot wind. Let not my tolerance deceive you, for my leader is violent... Perhaps a recalcitrant one is led... sometimes, then turns away. So beware the turning away of my soul... from you, for the soul is turning away. She aimed at a lion of a thicket... between his two lairs is a roar. A doe whom guards in the... Al-Amjiyyat (?) a glitter. Perhaps the sturdy one is destroyed by the arrow while the archer is weak. And wine that I aged... after ancestors passing. The Jinn had chosen it... before, while the earth was trembling. So it is a meaning which... the subtle imagination does not encompass. And it is wide in the body... and it is slow in the cup. And it is an opposite to the darkness of the night, while the night is crouching. The lover turns his glance away from it... while he is drained (drunk). We have transgressed reason regarding it... and Allah is Kind. And a station whose arrival is unhealthy, suspected, feared. Terms [lives] wept when... deaths laughed in it. The upper spears were lowered in it... and the swords rose in it. It was clothed [in armor/dust] while the eagles... of death hover in it. When for souls in the fright... of terror there is a palpitation. Indeed my house is in the peaks of Qahtan belonging to the lofty house. And I have the high skull and the thick glory. And I have the old wealth in glory, ancient and new. Every glory the Yemenis did not mark is thin. 'Al-Sujuf': Plural of 'Sijf' which is the curtain. It is said 'Sijf' and 'Sujf'. His saying: 'Tasarra' is from your saying: I cast off ('Sarawtu') my garment if I threw it. 'Al-Mawhin': From the beginning of the night to hours of it. 'Al-Nasif': The head-covering (Khimar). 'Al-Litan': The two sides of the neck. 'Al-Shunuf' plural of 'Shanf', which is what is hung in the upper ear. 'Al-Qadhif': The distant. 'Al-Halif': The adherent. 'Al-Shawb': Mixing. From His Almighty's saying: (Then indeed they will have on top of it a mixture (*shawban*) of boiling water) [Quran 37:67]. 'Al-'Ayuf': The one hating the thing. 'Al-Qayl': The king. It is said: 'Safa' away from the thing if he turned away from it. And 'Azafat nafsi' from the thing: If it hated it. 'Al-Ghab': Plural of 'Ghabah' which is the thicket, and likewise 'Al-Khis'. 'Al-Amjiyyat': A place. 'Al-Rafif': The movement of the thing and its glitter and clarity. It is said: So-and-so's teeth 'tariffu' (glitter). 'Al-Aslaf' plural of 'Salaf'. 'Al-Khuluf': Plural of 'Khalf' or 'Khalif'. 'Al-Khalf' with open Lam is used in good and evil. As for 'Al-Khalf' with silent Lam, it is only in blame. 'Al-Wasa'': The quick one. 'Al-Qatf': Closeness of steps and their approximation. 'Al-Nazif': The drunk. 'Al-Mustawbil': The disliked. 'Al-'Awali': Plural of 'Aliyah' which is the top of the spear. His saying: "Wa 'uqbanu al-rada fihi ta'ifu": 'Al-Rada' is destruction. 'Ta'ifu': i.e., circling around it and disliking arriving at it. Niftawayh told us, saying Abu Ya'qub told us, saying Al-Hasan ibn Muhammad told us, saying Shayban told us from Qatadah regarding His Almighty's saying (And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer (*li-yuqarribuna*) to Allah in position (*zulfa*)") [Quran 39:3]. He said: They used to say we do not worship these gods except to intercede for us with Allah. Abu al-Qasim said: In this verse are types of questions according to the school of Arabic. Among them is to be said: Where is the predicate of "Alladhina" (Those who) from what you see in the context of the speech? And among them is to be said: Which Lam is this in 'yuqarribuna'? And among them is to be asked about the position of "zulfa" in parsing (I'rab). The estimation of the verse - and Allah knows best - is that when He said: (So worship Allah, being sincere to Him in religion... the verse), sincere religion, so He informed that the religion is what is made pure for Allah Almighty. He started informing about the disbelievers, rebuking them and alerting to their misguidance, so He said: (And those who take protectors besides Allah [say] "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position"). "Alladhina" is inchoative and its predicate is 'yaquluna' (they say), so He implied it because of the indication in the speech upon it, as He Almighty said: (And the angels will enter upon them from every gate, [saying] "Peace be upon you") [Quran 13:23-24], i.e., saying Peace. The Lam in His saying: "li-yuqarribuna" is the Lam of Kai (purpose), its interpretation is 'li-kay yuqarribuna', and it is not the Lam of Juhud (denial) even if 'Ma' is before it. The difference between the Lam of Juhud and the Lam of Kai is that the Lam of Juhud can be dropped, like your saying: "Ma kana Zaydun li-yakhruja" (Zayd was not to go out); if you said "Ma kana Zaydun yakhruju", it would be complete speech. And the Lam of Kai cannot be dropped. If you said in your saying: "Qasadtuka li-tukrimani" (I intended you so you honor me), "Qasadtuka tukrimuni", it would not be permissible. Likewise, it is not permissible to drop it in this verse. 'Al-Zulfa': Proximity, and it is accusative as a verbal noun (Masdar) because the meaning of 'yuqarribuna' and 'yuzlifuna' is the same. 'Al-Zulaf': in His saying (And approaches (*zulafan*) of the night) [Quran 11:114] is plural of 'Zulfah', which are hours close to each other. Al-Ajjaj said: [Rajaz] A swift camel, fatigue folded it from what it suffered... the folding of nights, hour by hour (*zulafan fa-zulfa*).

The sky of the crescent until it curved. Abu Bakr Ahmad ibn al-Hasan ibn al-Abbas ibn al-Faraj al-Nahwi, known as Ibn Shuqayr, informed us, saying Ahmad ibn Ubayd ibn Nasih ibn Asidah told us from his sheikhs raising it to Muhammad ibn Ishaq, who said: Amr ibn al-Jamuh ibn Zayd was a noble master, and he had taken for himself an idol of wood called Manat which he worshipped in his house. His son Mu'adh ibn Amr had pledged allegiance to the Prophet (PBUH) and wanted his father to embrace Islam, but he refused. When Mu'adh ibn Jabal and a group of the youths of his people embraced Islam, they used to gather with Mu'adh ibn Amr and come at night to Amr's idol, so they would soil it with filth and smear it with impurities. When Amr woke up, he would say: 'Woe to you, who transgressed against my god tonight?' When that happened often to him, he said: 'Indeed, by Allah, I do not know who exposes himself to you, and if I knew that, I would defend you.' Then he washed it, cleaned it, perfumed it, and hung a sword on it and said to it: 'Defend yourself if there is good in you.' When night came, his son and Mu'adh and a group with them came, tied a dead dog to it, and threw it with the sword and the dog into a well belonging to Banu Salimah filled with excrement. When Amr woke up, he began going around searching for it. When he stood over it, he saw clearly and embraced Islam, and his Islam was good. He recited saying: [Poem in Mutaqarib meter] I repent to Allah from what has passed... and I ask forgiveness of Allah from His Fire. And I praise Him for His blessings... The God of the Hatim and its curtains. So glory be to Him, the number of the sinners... and the drops of the clouds and their pouring. He guided me while I was in darkness... an ally of Manat and its stones. And He saved me after the graying of the back of the head... from the shame of that and from its disgrace. And I almost perished in darkness... so He rectified that by His decree. So praise and thanks to Him as long as I remain... a saying of shame for His warning. I hope by that, when I said it... to neighbor Allah in His House. Then he turned to his idol and recited saying: [Rajaz] Uff to your abode as a god in filth... Now we have inspected you regarding the evil of fraud. By Allah, if you were a god, you would not be... you and a dog in the middle of a well in a rope (*Qaran*). Praise be to Allah, my God, Possessor of favors... The Giver, the Provider, the Judge of the Religion. He is the One who saved me before I... become in the darkness of a grave, pledged. Abu al-Qasim said: It is said 'akhta'a' the man in his action 'yukhti'u' 'ikhta'an' so he is 'mukhti''. And 'khati'a' in his religion 'yakhta'u' 'khat'an': if he sinned, so he is 'khati'' (sinner), O this one. So his saying: "Number of the sinners (*khati'in*)", he means the sinful. 'Al-'Ani': The submissive, humble. From it His saying: (And faces will be humbled (*'anat*)) [Quran 20:111]. From it the captive is called 'Anin'. 'Al-Daran': Dirt. 'Al-Qaran': The rope in which two camels are tied together, and he meant it in his poetry. 'Al-Qaran': Verbal noun of 'Al-Aqran' among men, who is the one whose ends of eyebrows meet. 'Al-Qarn': A solitary mountain. 'Al-Qarn' like 'Al-'Aql'—with silent Ra—: A dispute was brought to Shurayh regarding a slave girl who had a 'Qarn' (horn-like protrusion/hernia?), owned. He said: Sit her down; if it touches the ground it is a defect, otherwise it is not a defect. Abdullah ibn Malik informed us, saying Abu Muslim al-Harrani informed us, saying I was told from Abd al-Rahman ibn Salih from Yunus ibn Bukayr from Mujalid from Al-Sha'bi who said: I entered upon Mus'ab ibn al-Zubayr. He said to me: 'O Sha'bi, lift this curtain.' I lifted it, and behold, Aisha bint Talhah was there. He said: 'How do you see?' I said: 'I did not think there was anyone on earth resembling this one.' She said: 'As for me, I have not enjoyed life with him nor benefited from him ever, because I am a masculine man wanting the command to be mine, and she is a masculine woman wanting the command to be hers. So neither do I follow her, nor does she follow me.' Abu Muhammad al-Darir informed us, saying Abu Muslim al-Harrani informed us, saying it was narrated from Yunus ibn Bukayr from Muhammad ibn Ishaq from his father, saying: I saw Aisha bint Talhah reclining; if a slaughtered camel were made to kneel, it would not be seen [behind her due to her size/grandeur?]. Al-Akhfash and Niftawayh informed us from Tha'lab from Ibn al-A'rabi, saying: 'Al-Habnaqa' and 'Al-Habnaqa'ah': The arrogant fool, who is the one who sits on the tips of his toes and asks people. 'Al-Sakhal': Mixing the drink. 'Al-Sakhil': The young boy who befriends a man. 'Al-Khadil' with Kasra on Dad: Everything that does not drip; from it is said 'Shiwa' Khadil' (Moist roast): if it is moist, well-cooked. 'Al-Khadal': With Sukun on Dad: Pearls, singular 'Khadlah'. It is narrated that a woman presented her husband to Al-Hajjaj and said: Marry me upon a 'Fadlah' (surplus/favor?). It is said: 'Akmakha' the man: If he sat arrogantly. 'Al-Kaykham': From the names of greatness and authority. 'Al-Kamikh' according to the pure Bedouins is 'Al-Salamih'. It is narrated that a pure Bedouin entered a village and asked for food. They presented him bread and 'Kamikh' (pickles/condiment). He began to glance at it angrily thinking it was 'Salamih'. Some of them said to him: 'It is Kamikh.' [He said:] 'I know it is Kamikh, so which of you 'Kakhkha' (defecated) in it?'

Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Hamdan al-Basri and Abu Ghanim al-Ma'nawi informed us, saying Abu Khalifah al-Fadl ibn al-Hubbab informed us from Muhammad ibn Salam, saying: Suraqah al-Bariqi was a poet, witty, a visitor to kings, sweet of speech. He went out among those who went out to fight Al-Mukhtar, so he fell captive. He was brought to Al-Mukhtar. When he fell before him, he said: 'O Trustee of the Family of Muhammad. None of those in front of you captured me.' He said: 'Woe to you, then who captured you?' He said: 'I saw men on piebald horses fighting us; I do not see them now. They are the ones who captured me.' So Al-Mukhtar said to his companions: 'Indeed your enemy sees of this matter what you do not see.' Then he ordered his killing. He said: 'O Trustee of the Family of Muhammad, you know that this is not the time in which you kill me.' He said: 'So when do I kill you?' He said: 'When you conquer Damascus and demolish it stone by stone, then sit on a chair at one of its gates; there you will call me, kill me, and crucify me.' Al-Mukhtar said: 'You spoke the truth.' Then he turned to the chief of his police and said: 'Woe to you, who will let Suraqah go ('yukhriju sura') to the people?' Then he ordered the release of Suraqah. When he escaped, he recited saying—and Al-Mukhtar was nicknamed Abu Ishaq—: [Poem in Wafir meter] Inform Abu Ishaq that I... saw the piebald [horses] as pure black ones. My eye sees what they did not see... Both of us are knowledgeable about lies (*Turrahat*). I disbelieved in your revelation and made a vow... upon myself to fight you until death. As for his saying: "tara'ayahu" (they two saw it), he returned it to its origin. The Arabs did not use 'Yara' and 'Tara' and 'Ara' and 'Nara' except by dropping the Hamza for lightening. As for the past tense, the Hamza is affirmed. Al-Mazini used to say: The choice in my view is to narrate it "Tarayahu" without Hamza because the deviation (*Zihaf*) is easier than returning this to its origin. Likewise, he used to recite the saying of the other: [Poem in Tawil meter] Did you not see what I encountered while time is eras... and whoever enjoys life sees ('yar'a') and hears. With realizing the Hamza. Niftawayh told us, saying Abu Ya'qub al-Harami told us, saying Al-Husayn ibn Muhammad told us, saying Shayban told us from Qatadah regarding the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic (There was for Saba' in their dwelling a sign: two gardens on the right and on the left) [Quran 34:15] the two together. He said: They were a people whom Allah bestowed blessings upon, commanded them to obey Him, and forbade them from disobeying Him. But they turned away, i.e., associated partners in the command of Allah Mighty and Majestic. So Allah sent upon them the flood of Al-Arim. He said: Al-Arim is the valley of Saba' where floods or whatever gathered. So they proceeded to block what was between the two mountains with tar and stones and built gates upon it. They used to take from the water according to wisdom and block in its fold what was other than that. When they abandoned the command of Allah, Allah sent upon them a rat called 'Al-Khuld' (Mole/Rat). It bored into it from its bottom, so it drowned their gardens and ruined their land, and they were scattered in the lands. That was a punishment from Allah for them for their disbelief. He said: (And We dispersed them with every dispersion) [Quran 34:19]. Then He said: (And We exchanged for them, in place of their two gardens, two gardens yielding bitter fruit (*khamt*)). 'Al-Khamt': The Arak tree, and its fruit is 'Barir'. And 'Al-Athl': A tree resembling the Tamarisk (*Tarfa'*) except it is larger than it. And His saying: (and a little of Lote trees (*Sidr*)). He said: We built their land as the best land and their trees as the best trees; Allah ruined their land and made their trees the worst trees as a punishment for them for their disbelief. Abu al-Qasim said: Scholars have three opinions regarding 'Al-Arim'. Some said: 'Al-Arim': The dam break itself which burst upon them. Others said: 'Al-Arim': The dams (*Al-Musannayat*), a plural whose singular is 'Arimah' like 'Labinah' and 'Labin', and 'Nabiqah' and 'Nabiq'. This is the view of linguists, and they argued with the saying of Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di: [Poem in Munsarih meter] From Saba' the losers of Ma'rib when... they build the 'Arim' (Dam) before its flood. Al-Akhfash informed me, saying Tha'lab informed us, saying Al-Riyashi informed us, saying: I heard Abu Ubaydah Ma'mar ibn al-Muthanna mention from Abu al-Dahhak who said: I witnessed the dam break that burst in Yemen in the days of Saba', and found it like a river running in Basra. As for 'Saba'', it is hamzated and non-hamzated, except that the Arabs have two dialects in it: some make it a name of a male clan, so if they attribute to it, they make it fully declinable (Tasrifuhu). And some make it a name of a tribe, so they do not make it fully declinable. The readers have read with declension and leaving it. Likewise 'Thamud', its analogy is this exact analogy in declension and leaving declension. 'Al-Jannah' in the speech of the Arabs: The garden. As for 'Al-Juradh' (large rat) from rats, it is with Damma on the first and dotted Dhal. Likewise 'Al-Juradh' (spavin/swelling) in the legs of beasts is with dotted Dhal except it is open on the first (Fatha). Likewise 'Al-Zarad' (strangling?) with dotted Dhal only. Al-Yazidi informed me, saying my uncle Al-Fadl ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Muhammad al-Yazidi informed me

From Abu Muhammad ibn al-Mubarak al-Yazidi, saying: While I was circumambulating one morning at Mecca, Masin al-Zayyat met me and said to me: 'O Abu Muhammad, I am waiting for you at the Maqam, I will meet you at the Misirayn (?) when you finish circumambulation.' So I went to him and he said to me: 'O Abu Muhammad, I did not sleep last night because of something that agitated my chest, preventing me from sleeping by thinking about it. I wished only that morning would come.' I said: 'What is that?' He said: 'Is it permissible in the speech of the Arabs for a man to say: "I want to say such and such" for something he has already done? For that is not permissible except by a type of narration (*hikayah*) explained to you.' He said: 'So what do you say about the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic (Indeed, Pharaoh exalted himself in the land) until he reached His saying (And We wanted to confer favor upon those who were oppressed... the Verse) [Quran 28:4-5]. He addressed Muhammad with it while He had already done that before.' So I said to him: 'This is of the narration (*hikayah*) which I mentioned to you, because when He said (Indeed he was of the corrupters), the estimation of the speech was "And it was of Our judgment on that day that We confer favor," so He narrated that to Muhammad (PBUH). As He said in the story of Yahya (And peace be upon him the day he was born and the day he dies...) because the estimation of the speech is "And it was of Our judgment, peace be upon him," so He narrated that to Muhammad, peace be upon him.' He said to me: 'May Allah reward you with good, O Abu Muhammad, for you have relieved me by what you explained, and I will benefit you as you benefited me.' Abu Muhammad said: So he told me from the Prophet (PBUH) that most of his supplication was: "O Allah, I ask You for certainty, pardon, well-being, and the completion of blessing in the world and the Hereafter." Al-Ma'nawi informed us, saying Abu Khalifah informed us from Muhammad ibn Salam who said: Mayy, whom Dhul-Rummah composed poetry about, was the daughter of Talabah ibn Qays ibn Asim al-Minqari. And the mother of Dhul-Rummah was a client of the family of Qays ibn Asim. When she saw Dhul-Rummah's infatuation with her and his matter increasing, she wanted to create alienation between them, so she said on the tongue of Dhul-Rummah: [Poem in Tawil meter] Upon the face of Mayy is a trace of beauty... and under the clothes is shame if it were apparent. Have you not seen that water, its taste becomes foul... even if the color of the water in the eye is clear? So Mayy became angry at that. Dhul-Rummah kept apologizing and swearing that he did not say it. He said: 'How could that be when I have spent my life composing amorous poetry about her?' Abu al-Qasim said: And this poetry is the most resembling thing to the poetry of Dhul-Rummah; it is close to his nature, and resembling this meter and rhyme is the poetry of Dhul-Rummah. Al-Akhfash recited to us: [Poem in Tawil meter] An old woman says: 'My way is going at evening... to her door from my family and going at morning.' So I said to her: 'No, indeed my family are neighbors... to the dunes of Al-Dahna, all of them, and my wealth.' And I was not, since you saw me, in a dispute... wherein I return, O daughter of the people, to a judge. But I approached from the sides of Qasa... visiting a youth, Najdi, generous, Yemeni. From the family of Abu Musa, you see the people around him... as if they were Bustards that saw a Falcon. Struck with awe from a lion, upon him is dignity... the lions of the thicket avoid him, an avoidance. And they do not fear clumsiness from him nor is shame/hesitation... upon them, but it is an awe, what is it? Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abu Hatim informed us, saying Al-Asma'i informed us, saying: The Arabs say "The burdensome nakedness is better than the scandalous outfit." Ibn Durayd informed us, saying Abu Hatim informed us from Al-Asma'i, saying: Some people raised a petition to Al-Mansur asking him to build a mosque in their locality. He signed on it: "Of the signs of the Hour is the abundance of mosques, so increase in your steps, you will increase in reward." Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying Al-Mazini informed us from Al-Asma'i, saying my father and others informed me: Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf said to Yahya ibn Ya'mar: "Do I make grammatical errors ('alhanu') in my speech?" He said: "God forbid." He said: "I resolve upon you (to tell the truth)." He said: "You add Alif and subtract it." He said: "Catch up with Khurasan (Exile)." When it was after that, Qutaybah ibn Muslim wrote from Khurasan: "Indeed the enemy is at the 'Ar'arah' (peak) of the mountain, and we are at the 'Hadid' (bottom)." Al-Hajjaj said: "From whom?" And he denied that this was from his speech. It was said to him: "Yahya ibn Ya'mar." He said: "This is from his dictation." Al-Mubarrad said: 'Al-'Ar'arah': Top of the mountain. 'Al-Hadid': Its bottom where it leads to the plain. And 'Ar'arah' of the cow: Its hump. Al-Akhfash informed us from Al-Mubarrad from Al-Riyashi, saying Adi ibn al-Mufaddal said: I came to...

Umar ibn Abd al-Aziz asking him to dig a well at Al-Adhbah. He said to me: 'And where is Al-Adhbah?' I said: 'At a distance of two nights from Basra.' So he had it dug for me and blamed himself (or made me ensure) that there be no water in such a place, and stipulated on me that I guide the drinker of the wayfarers. Then I greeted him on a Friday and found him preaching, and I heard him say: "O people, you are dead, then you are resurrected, then you are held accountable. So if you are truthful, you have fallen short. And if you are liars, you have lied. O people, indeed whoever is destined a provision at the head of a mountain or bottom of a land, it will come to him, so be moderate in seeking." He said: So I stayed with him a month, having no concern but listening to his speech. Al-Akhfash informed us, saying Al-Mubarrad informed us, saying: The narrators transmitted that when Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Bakr al-Siddiq died and Aisha was not present, she visited his grave and said: 'O my brother, if I had attended your death, I would not have visited your grave.' And she began to say, quoting as an example: [Poem in Tawil meter] We were like the two drinking companions of Jadhimah for an era... of time, until it was said they will never separate. So when we separated, it was as if I and Malik... for the length of gathering, did not spend a night together. Then she attended Abu Bakr while he was breathing his last. She said: 'This, by Allah, is as Hatim said: [Poem in Tawil meter] O Mawiyah, wealth does not avail the youth... when [the soul] rattles one day and the chest becomes tight with it.' Abu Bakr said to her: 'O my daughter, do not say this, but say: (And the stupor of death will come in truth) [Quran 50:19].' And this is how Abu Bakr, may Allah have mercy on him, used to read it. Al-Akhfash and Al-Zajjaj recited to us, saying Al-Mubarrad recited to us for Abu al-Atahiyah eulogizing Ali ibn Thabit, who was a brother to him. Abu al-Abbas said: Ali was a polite, devout, witty poet: [Poem in Wafir meter] Oh, who is for me with your intimacy, O my little brother... and who is for me to reveal to him what I have? The calamities of your time folded you after spreading... Likewise are its calamities, spreading and folding. If deaths spread your powers for me... I would complain to you what they did to me. There were admonitions for me in your life... and you today are more admonishing than when you were alive. Abu al-Abbas said: He took this from the saying of some non-Arabs who attended a king of theirs who died. He said: 'The king yesterday was more speaking than he is today, and he is today more admonishing than yesterday.' Abu al-Atahiyah also said regarding him: [Poem in Khafif meter] O Ali ibn Thabit, where are you... You are among the graves where you were buried. O Ali ibn Thabit, there departed from me... a companion whose loss was great the day you departed. Indeed, by my life, you narrated to me the choking of death... and you moved me for it, and became still. Abu al-Abbas said: This is also taken from the saying of some non-Arabs who attended the death of a friend of his. When he passed, voices rose weeping for him. He said: 'He moved us by his stillness.' And Abu al-Atahiyah said regarding Ali ibn Thabit also: [Poem in Majzu' al-Khafif meter] A companion I had perished... and the path which he walked. Every living thing owned... will perish along with what he owned. O Ali ibn Thabit... May Allah forgive me and you. Abdullah ibn Malik informed us, saying Muhammad ibn Abi Ubayd al-Basri informed me from Asad ibn Sa'id ibn Hunayn from his father, saying Ibn Mughni, a man from the descendants of Sa'id ibn al-As, told me, saying Ishaq ibn Sa'd ibn Amr ibn Sa'id ibn al-As told me: Al-Arji, who is Abdullah ibn Umar ibn Uthman ibn Affan, used to compose amorous poetry about the wife of Muhammad ibn Hisham. Ibn Mughni said: As for Al-Hudhali Yazid ibn Abdullah, he told me that he used to compose amorous poetry about his Harithi wife, and he is the one who said: [Poem in Sari' meter] Turn to us, mistress of the litter... indeed, if you do not do so, you commit a sin. The easiest thing a lover said at... the separation of a lover is his saying: Turn. Let a need be decreed to him, or let him say... Is there for me a way out from what I am in? Who greeted you? You departed and it did not cease... the passion of my wandering, ripe heart. She could do nothing but signal... with the glance of the eye of a black-eyed young gazelle. She drives away a tear with the hail (teeth/cold?)... brought by the eye but not produced. For fear of the slanderers lest they notice... her complaint, and the angry hater. I say when I missed from them... what I was hoping for of their connection. Indeed, a Yemeni woman was made available to me... one of Banu al-Harith from Madhhij. I will perform Hajj if she performs Hajj; and what is it to me... a weakness (Wahinah) if she does not perform Hajj? Abdullah ibn al-A'rabi al-Harith al-Fihri informed us that Ibrahim ibn al-Mundhir told them, saying Muhammad ibn Ma'n al-Ghafari told me, saying Umar ibn Abdullah ibn Nasr informed me: I was sitting with Talhah ibn Umar ibn Ubayd Allah ibn Ma'mar. Kuthayyir entered upon us while I was exemplifying with the saying of Jamil: [Poem in Tawil meter]

And you two told me that Tayma is a home... for Layla when the summer casts the anchors. So these months of summer have passed from us... so what is with distance throwing Layla to the throwing-places? He (Kuthayyir) grabbed his saddle from behind him then shouted with emotion until he came to the 'Arsh', meaning the front of the room, then returned saying: 'He is, by Allah, the most amorous poet of the Arabs.' 1 12
